question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase I/Ib Study of Sarasar and Temodar in Patients with Recurrent or Temodar-Refractory Glioblastoma Multiforme
brief_summary: This phase I trial studies the side effects and best dose of lonafarnib when given together with temozolomide and to see how well they work in treating patients with glioblastoma multiforme that is has come back or did not respond to previous treatment with temozolomide. Lonafarnib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. Drugs used in chemotherapy, such as temozolomide, work in different ways to stop the growth of tumor cells, either by killi...

inclusion_criteria: Histologically proven supratentorial glioblastoma multiforme or gliosarcoma | Radiographic evidence of tumor recurrence or progression by MRI/CT after radiation therapy | Imaging within 14 days prior to registration with stable or decreasing steroid dose for >=5 days | Post-resection patients: >=2 weeks from surgery, recovered with adequate wound healing | Post-resection imaging: CT/MRI within 96 hours post-op or >=4 weeks post-op (within 14 days of registration) with stable steroids for 5 days | Karnofsky performance status >=60 | Recovered from prior therapy toxicities | Washouts: >=4 weeks from prior cytotoxic therapy; >=2 weeks from vincristine; >=6 weeks from nitrosoureas; >=3 weeks from procarbazine; >=1 week from non-cytotoxic agents
exclusion_criteria: Current use of enzyme-inducing anticonvulsants (primidone, carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin) or not off them for at least 72 hours prior to treatment | History of another cancer (except non-melanoma skin cancer or cervical carcinoma in situ) unless in complete remission and off all therapy for >=3 years | Uncontrolled active infection | Serious intercurrent medical illness or conditions that could obscure toxicity or alter drug metabolism | Any prior treatment with farnesyl transferase inhibitors | Prior recurrence while receiving a farnesyl transferase inhibitor | Use of oral contraceptives or other hormonal birth control methods (e.g., depot medroxyprogesterone)
prior_therapies: Prior temozolomide required; No prior farnesyl transferase inhibitor therapy allowed; Up to 2 prior chemotherapy regimens for recurrent/progressive disease allowed; Phase 1b expansion: at least 2 cycles of adjuvant temozolomide required; Washout: >=4 weeks from prior cytotoxic therapy; Washout: >=2 weeks from vincristine; Washout: >=6 weeks from nitrosoureas; Washout: >=3 weeks from procarbazine; Washout: >=1 week from non-cytotoxic agents

Other operational criteria (e.g., imaging timing, steroid stability, KPS) are unspecified but no conflicts are evident.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Recurrent glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; ECOG 1; Age 40; Male; Prior gross total resection; Completed adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Completed adjuvant temozolomide; Recurrence three months after completing adjuvant therapy; No other medical issues

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase III Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial of Carboplatin and Paclitaxel (or Gemcitabine) Alone or in Combination With Bevacizumab (NSC #704865) Followed by Bevacizumab and Secondary Cytoreductive Surgery in Platinum-Sensitive, Recurrent Ovarian, Peritoneal Primary and Fallopian Tube Cancer. NCI-Supplied Agents: Bevacizumab (NSC #704865)
brief_summary: This randomized phase III trial studies carboplatin, paclitaxel and gemcitabine hydrochloride when given together with or without bevacizumab after surgery to see how well it works in treating patients with ovarian, epithelial, primary peritoneal, or fallopian tube cancer that has come back. Drugs used in chemotherapy, such as carboplatin, paclitaxel and gemcitabine hydrochloride work in different ways to stop the growth of tumor cells, either by killing the cells, by stopping them from divid...

diseases_targeted: Ovarian Carcinoma (recurrent); Fallopian Tube Carcinoma (recurrent); Primary Peritoneal Carcinoma (recurrent)
inclusion_criteria: Candidate for cytoreductive surgery when applicable per protocol/randomization plan | Histologic epithelial ovarian, primary peritoneal, or fallopian tube carcinoma, recurrent | Eligible epithelial histologies include serous, endometrioid, mucinous, clear cell, transitional cell, undifferentiated, malignant Brenner tumor, mixed epithelial, or adenocarcinoma NOS | Complete response to front-line platinum-taxane therapy (>=3 cycles) | Treatment-free interval without progression >=6 months after completion of front-line chemotherapy (platinum and taxane) | Maintenance biologic or hormonal therapy allowed if recurrence >6 months and >=4 weeks since last biologic infusion | Clinically evident recurrent disease | Measurable disease per RECIST with at least one lesion: >=20 mm by conventional imaging/MRI/CT or >=10 mm by spiral CT | ANC >=1500/µL | Platelets >=100000/µL | Creatinine <=1.5 x ULN | Total bilirubin <=1.5 x ULN | AST <=2.5 x ULN | Alkaline phosphatase <=2.5 x ULN | Urine protein-to-creatinine ratio <1.0 mg/dL (if receiving bevacizumab) | ECOG 0–2
exclusion_criteria: More than one prior chemotherapy regimen (maintenance not counted as a separate regimen) | Concurrent immunotherapy or radiotherapy | Prior radiotherapy to any portion of the abdominal cavity or pelvis | Prior secondary cytoreductive surgery for recurrent disease | Requirement for parenteral hydration or nutrition with evidence of partial bowel obstruction or perforation | Prior chemotherapy for other abdominal or pelvic tumors (except ovarian, fallopian tube, primary peritoneal) | Synchronous or prior primary endometrial cancer unless all met: stage <= IB; no more than superficial myometrial invasion without vascular/lymphatic invasion; no poorly differentiated subtypes (papillary serous, clear cell, FIGO grade 3) | Uncontrolled infection | Severe uncontrolled comorbid medical conditions limiting compliance or increasing risk | Peripheral neuropathy >= grade 2 | History of hypersensitivity to carboplatin and/or paclitaxel unless successfully desensitized | Hypersensitivity to CHO cell products or other recombinant antibodies (applies to bevacizumab recipients) | Pregnant or breastfeeding; inadequate contraception | Other invasive malignancy within 5 years (except non-melanoma skin cancer) or prior cancer therapy contraindicating protocol therapy | Active bleeding or high-risk bleeding conditions/coagulopathy (applies to bevacizumab recipients) | CNS disease (including brain metastases), uncontrolled seizures, or stroke within 5 years (applies to bevacizumab recipients) | Significant cardiovascular disease, including conduction abnormalities (PR >0.24 s or 2nd/3rd-degree AV block), uncontrolled hypertension (systolic >150 mmHg or diastolic >90 mmHg), myocardial infarction/cardiac arrhythmia/unstable angina within 6 months, NYHA class >= II heart failure, serious arrhythmia requiring medication, peripheral vascular disease grade >= II, or cerebrovascular accident within 6 months (applies to bevacizumab recipients) | Major surgery, open biopsy, dental extractions/procedures resulting in open wound, or significant traumatic injury within 28 days before treatment; vascular access device placement or core biopsy within 7 days before treatment
prior_therapies: Complete response to front-line platinum-taxane therapy (>=3 cycles) required; Treatment-free interval >=6 months from completion of front-line platinum and taxane chemotherapy; Front-line therapy may have included bevacizumab; Maintenance cytotoxic chemotherapy must be discontinued >=6 months before documentation of recurrence; Maintenance biological or hormonal therapy allowed if recurrence >6 months and >=4 weeks since last biologic infusion
reasoning: Disease and histology match (recurrent epithelial ovarian, clear cell included), and age/sex and prior first-line platinum-taxane±bevacizumab are compatible. Platinum-sensitivity interval, measurable disease, and performance/labs are unspecified but not known mismatches.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Female; Age 36 years; Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; Cytology-positive pleural effusion (recurrent disease); BRCA1 positive; Prior optimal debulking surgery; Prior adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab
patient_prior_therapies: Optimal debulking surgery; Adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab
judge_comment: No hard exclusions. Disease and setting (recurrent epithelial ovarian, clear cell allowed) match. However, key line-of-therapy requirements—complete response to front-line platinum-taxane and ≥6-month platinum-free interval (platinum-sensitive)—are unknown, as is measurable disease. Thus only one core anchor (stage/setting) clearly matches; line/prior is not definitively met. Per rubric this is a B, not A.

trial_title: A Phase I Study of Intracranially Administered Carboxylesterase-Expressing Neural Stem Cells in Combination With Intravenous Irinotecan in Patients With Recurrent High-Grade Gliomas
brief_summary: This phase I trial studies the side effects and best dose of carboxylesterase-expressing allogeneic neural stem cells when given together with irinotecan hydrochloride in treating patients with high-grade gliomas that have come back. Placing genetically modified neural stem cells into brain tumor cells may make the tumor more sensitive to irinotecan hydrochloride. Irinotecan hydrochloride may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. Giving carboxy...

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 1 Trial of MLN0128 (TAK-228) in Combination With Osimertinib (AZD9291) in Advanced EGFR Mutation Positive Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) After Progression on a Previous EGFR Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitor
brief_summary: This phase I trial studies the side effects and best dose of sapanisertib when given together with osimertinib in treating patients with stage IV EGFR mutation positive non-small cell lung cancer that has progressed after treatment with an EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor. Sapanisertib and osimertinib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Proof-of-Concept, Pilot Study of Pembrolizumab (MK-3475) in Patients With Recurrent Malignant Glioma With a Hypermutator Phenotype
brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to test if the study drug called pembrolizumab could control the growth or shrink the cancer but it could also cause side effects. Researchers hope to learn if the study drug will shrink the cancer by half, or prevent it from growing for at least 6 months. Pembrolizumab is an antibody that targets the immune system and activates it to stop cancer growth and/or kill cancer cells.

trial_title: A Phase II Clinical Trial Evaluating the Efficacy of Combining Thermal Ablation and Spine Stereotactic Radiosurgery for Patients With Spine Metastases With Moderate to Severe Epidural Involvement
brief_summary: This phase II clinical trial studies how well thermal ablation and spine stereotactic radiosurgery work in treating patients with cancer that has spread to the spine (spine metastases) and is at risk for compressing the spinal cord. Thermal ablation uses a laser to heat tumor tissue and helps to shrink the tumor by destroying tumor cells. Stereotactic radiosurgery delivers a large dose of radiation in a short time precisely to the tumor, sparing healthy surrounding tissue. Combining thermal a...

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: Multidisciplinary Approach to Patient-Physician Partnership In Treating To Target In Rheumatoid Arthritis
brief_summary: This research will evaluate a multifaceted patient-centered intervention in a sample of socioeconomically disadvantaged Hispanic adults with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) that capitalizes on a partnership between the extended rheumatology healthcare team and each patient in order to promote understanding, uptake and adherence to the principles of treat-to-target strategy. The primary hypothesis of this study is that the addition of a multifaceted intervention incorporating integrated multidiscipl...

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Neurologic Bone Marrow Derived Stem Cell Treatment Study
brief_summary: This is a human clinical study involving the isolation of autologous bone marrow derived stem cells (BMSC) and transfer to the vascular system and inferior 1/3 of the nasal passages in order to determine if such a treatment will provide improvement in neurologic function for patients with certain neurologic conditions. http://mdstemcells.com/nest/

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. trial_title: A Randomized Phase 2 Trial of Cediranib and Olaparib Compared to Bevacizumab in Patients With Recurrent Glioblastoma Who Have Not Received Prior VEGF Therapy
brief_summary: This randomized phase II trial studies how well cediranib maleate and olaparib work compared to bevacizumab in treating patients with glioblastoma that has come back (recurrent). Cediranib maleate and olaparib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as bevacizumab, may help the body's immune system attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of tumor cells to grow and spread.

inclusion_criteria: Progressive disease on contrast-enhanced CT/MRI per RANO or recurrent glioblastoma on biopsy | Previous therapy with at least radiotherapy and temozolomide | >=12 weeks from radiotherapy unless progression is outside the high-dose field or biopsy confirms progression | Only first or second recurrence eligible | Washout: >=5 half-lives from investigational agents | Washout: >=4 weeks from cytotoxic therapy (>=23 days for temozolomide; >=6 weeks for nitrosoureas) | Washout: >=6 weeks from antibodies | Washout: >=4 weeks or >=5 half-lives (whichever is shorter) from other systemic anti-tumor therapies | May start treatment 1 day after discontinuation of the Optune device | Adverse events from prior therapy resolved to <= grade 1 (except alopecia) | Karnofsky performance status >= 60% | Life expectancy >= 3 months | Leukocytes >= 3,000/µL | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1,500/µL | Platelets >= 100,000/µL | Hemoglobin >= 10.0 g/dL without transfusion in the prior 28 days | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN | AST <= 2.5 x ULN | ALT <= 2.5 x ULN | Creatinine <= 1 x ULN or creatinine clearance >= 60 mL/min | Urine protein/creatinine ratio < 1 or urine dipstick protein <= 2+ | Baseline brain CT or MRI within 14 days prior to start of study drug | Corticosteroid dose stable or decreasing for at least 5 days before baseline MRI
exclusion_criteria: Prior use of PARP inhibitors | Prior therapy affecting the VEGF pathway (e.g., thalidomide, bevacizumab, sunitinib, sorafenib) | Allergic reactions to compounds similar to olaparib, cediranib, or bevacizumab | Uncontrolled hypertension (systolic BP > 140 mmHg or diastolic BP > 90 mmHg) or need for more than three antihypertensive medications | History of hypertensive crisis or hypertensive encephalopathy | Abdominal fistula or gastrointestinal perforation within 6 months | Intra-abdominal abscess within 6 months | History of pneumonitis | Current signs/symptoms of bowel obstruction or within 3 months | Dependency on IV hydration or total parenteral nutrition | Myelodysplastic syndrome or acute myeloid leukemia | Active or recent invasive malignancy other than allowed exceptions (limited-stage basal/squamous cell skin cancer, carcinoma in situ of breast/cervix, or prior cancer cured with no recurrence for 3 years) | Myocardial infarction within 6 months | Unstable angina | Cerebrovascular accident within 6 months | NYHA class II or greater heart failure | Significant vascular disease (e.g., aortic aneurysm, history of aortic dissection) or clinically significant peripheral vascular disease | Left ventricular ejection fraction below institutional normal or < 55% if unspecified | QTc > 470 msec or family history of long QT syndrome | Major surgery, open biopsy, or significant traumatic injury within 28 days prior to starting cediranib; anticipated need for major surgery | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness (including active infection, symptomatic heart failure, unstable angina, significant arrhythmia, or psychiatric illness limiting compliance) | Concurrent use of strong CYP3A4 inhibitors/inducers or moderate CYP3A4 inhibitors | Pregnant or breastfeeding | HIV-positive on combination antiretroviral therapy | Concurrent anti-cancer therapy while on study treatment | Concurrent use of herbal supplements (e.g., cannabis, St. John's wort, kava, ephedra, ginkgo, DHEA, yohimbe, saw palmetto, ginseng) during the study | Evidence of coagulopathy or bleeding diathesis (therapeutic anticoagulation permitted)
prior_therapies: Prior radiotherapy and temozolomide required; Only first or second recurrence permitted; Washout >= 5 half-lives from investigational agents; Washout >= 4 weeks from cytotoxic therapy (>= 23 days for temozolomide; >= 6 weeks for nitrosoureas); Washout >= 6 weeks from antibodies; Washout >= 4 weeks or >= 5 half-lives (whichever is shorter) from other systemic anti-tumor therapies; May start one day after discontinuing Optune device

brief_summary: This phase II trial studies how well durvalumab and tremelimumab work in treating participants with ovarian, primary peritoneal, or fallopian tube cancer that has come back or does not respond to treatment. Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as durvalumab and tremelimumab, may help the body's immune system attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of tumor cells to grow and spread. It is not yet known whether give durvalumab and tremelimumab in combination or sequentia...

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: BrUOG 354: A Phase II Randomized Trial of Nivolumab +/- Ipilimumab for Ovarian and Extra-renal Clear Cell Carcinomas
brief_summary: Preclinical and early-phase clinical data suggest that immune modulation represents a treatment strategy that is worthy of further investigation in relapsed epithelial ovarian cancer. One method by which tumor cells may evade immune surveillance is by activation of the programmed cell death (PD-1) pathway, mediated by expression of PD-1 on the surface of T lymphocytes, which conveys an inhibitory signal after binding to its ligand PD-L1 on the surface of tumor cells. Nivolumab and Ipilimumab ...

exclusion_criteria: Prior therapy with nivolumab, anti-PD-1, anti-PD-L1, anti-PD-L2, or anti-CTLA-4 | Chemotherapy or radiotherapy within 4 weeks (6 weeks for nitrosoureas or mitomycin C); endocrine therapy within 7 days | Not recovered from clinically significant adverse events to < grade 2 from prior therapies | Concurrent investigational agents | Known brain metastases | History of severe hypersensitivity reaction to any monoclonal antibody | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness (active infection requiring antibiotics, symptomatic CHF, unstable angina, serious arrhythmia, or significant psychiatric illness) | Pregnancy or breastfeeding | Other invasive malignancy within 3 years (exceptions for low-risk conditions as specified) | Prior chemotherapy within the last 3 years for cancers other than clear cell cancer | HIV infection not meeting: stable HAART, CD4 >350/µL, and undetectable viral load | Hepatitis B or C with detectable viral load or not definitively treated >=6 months | Active autoimmune disease or history likely to recur affecting vital organs or requiring immunosuppression | Systemic corticosteroids >10 mg prednisone equivalents daily or other immunosuppressive medications within 14 days prior to day 1 | Planned concomitant, non-protocol anti-cancer therapy | Grade >=2 peripheral neuropathy

trial_title: Phase I/II Study of Nivolumab and Ipilimumab Combined With Nintedanib in Non Small Cell Lung Cancer
brief_summary: The main purpose of this study is to see if the combination of nivolumab, ipilimumab and nintedanib is effective in people with non- small cell lung cancer. Researchers also want to find out if the combination of nivolumab, ipilimumab and nintedanib is safe and tolerable.
interventions: {'id': 206035679, 'name': 'Nivolumab', 'description': 'Intravenous nivolumab every 2 weeks.', 'other_names': ['Opdivo®'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206035680, 'name': 'Ipilimumab', 'description': 'Intravenous ipilimumab every 6 weeks.', 'other_names': ['Yervoy®'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206035681, 'name': 'Nintedanib', 'description': 'Nintedanib 100-200 mg capsules by mouth twice daily for two-week cycles.', 'other_names': ['Vargatef®', 'Ofev®', 'BIBF1120'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Histologic or cytologic diagnosis of advanced/metastatic Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer with no curative options | Age >= 18 years | Life expectancy >= 3 months | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Phase 1: Treatment-naive or previously treated with chemotherapy, immunotherapy, or targeted therapy for NSCLC allowed | Neoadjuvant/adjuvant chemo/radiation allowed if recurrence > 6 months after completion (considered treatment-naive in Stage IV) | Driver-positive NSCLC allowed if prior FDA-approved targeted therapy received (e.g., EGFR, ALK, ROS1, BRAF V600E) | Phase 2 Arm A: Newly diagnosed/treatment-naive; prior neoadjuvant/adjuvant allowed if recurrence > 6 months | Phase 2 Arm B: Prior immunotherapy exposure required (primary refractory or relapsed after initial disease control) | At least one measurable lesion per RECIST v1.1 | QTcB < 470 ms (males) or < 480 ms (females) | Adequate organ and marrow function | Negative pregnancy test for women of childbearing potential
exclusion_criteria: Concurrent use of other anticancer agents (chemotherapy, targeted therapy, radiotherapy, or immunotherapy) not specified in protocol | Participation in another clinical trial with a non–FDA-approved medication within 4 weeks | Chemo- or immunotherapy, monoclonal antibodies, or small molecule TKIs within 2 weeks prior to study treatment | Radiotherapy (except brain/extremities or stereotactic) within 2 weeks prior to study treatment | In immunotherapy-pretreated patients: prior dose-limiting toxicity to immunotherapy including grade 3/4 or irreversible immune-related adverse events, steroid-refractory grade >= 3 irAEs, or neurologic irAEs with significant sequelae | Prior treatment with nintedanib | Known hypersensitivity to nintedanib, nivolumab, ipilimumab, peanut, or soy, or excipients | Unresolved > CTCAE grade 2 toxicity from prior therapy (except allowable irreversible toxicities such as hearing loss, peripheral neuropathy, alopecia) | History of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis | Radiotherapy to a target lesion within 3 months prior to baseline imaging unless progression is demonstrated | Active brain metastases or symptomatic/uncontrolled CNS metastases | Current or prior use of immunosuppressive medication within 7 days before first dose of nivolumab or ipilimumab (with specified exceptions) | Active or prior documented autoimmune disease within the past 2 years (with specified exceptions) | Centrally located tumors with radiographic evidence of major blood vessel invasion | History or evidence of active, non-infectious pneumonitis | Therapeutic anticoagulation requiring INR monitoring or antiplatelet therapy (except low-dose aspirin < 325 mg/day or low-dose heparin/flushes) | Major surgery or significant injury within 4 weeks with incomplete wound healing or planned surgery during treatment | Clinically significant hemorrhagic or thromboembolic event within 6 months | Known inherited bleeding or thrombotic disorders | Significant cardiovascular disease (uncontrolled hypertension, unstable angina, recent MI < 3 months, CHF > NYHA II, serious arrhythmia) | Coagulation abnormalities: INR > 2 or PT/PTT > 50% above ULN | Another active malignancy within 2 years (except specified in situ or skin cancers) | Active serious infection requiring systemic therapy | Active hepatitis B or C infection | Known active primary immunodeficiency | History of allogeneic organ transplant | Live attenuated vaccination within 30 days before entry or during treatment window | GI disorders that would interfere with absorption of oral study drug | Serious non-oncologic illness or laboratory abnormality increasing study risk per investigator | Sexually active patients unwilling to use effective contraception during and after study therapy | Pregnancy or breastfeeding | Active alcohol or drug abuse | Significant weight loss > 20% of body weight within 6 months | History of active tuberculosis
prior_therapies: Phase 1: Prior chemotherapy, immunotherapy, or targeted therapy for NSCLC allowed; Neoadjuvant/adjuvant chemo/radiation allowed if recurrence > 6 months after completion; Phase 2 Arm A: Treatment-naive; Phase 2 Arm B: Prior immunotherapy required (primary refractory or relapsed after initial disease control); Driver-positive NSCLC: must have received prior FDA-approved targeted therapy (e.g., EGFR, ALK, ROS1, BRAF V600E)
reasoning: Disease and setting match (metastatic NSCLC), and prior therapy is compatible with Phase 1 (driver-positive NSCLC with prior EGFR TKI); ECOG 0 and age ≥18 also fit. No explicit exclusions are triggered based on available data (no prior nintedanib; CNS/other exclusionary factors not stated).
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; ECOG 0; De novo metastatic disease; Metastases to bone and liver; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years with complete response; Recent MRI shows numerous lesions; No past medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Osimertinib
judge_comment: Hard exclusion present: the trial excludes concurrent use of other anticancer agents and TKIs within 2 weeks prior to study treatment. The patient is currently on osimertinib, directly conflicting with this criterion. While disease and stage align and prior EGFR TKI fits Phase 1, the explicit exclusion overrides, so the correct grade is F, not A.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A PHASE I DOSE ESCALATION AND EXPANDED COHORT STUDY OF PF 06821497 (MEVROMETOSTAT) IN THE TREATMENT OF ADULT PATIENTS WITH RELAPSED/REFRACTORY SMALL CELL LUNG CANCER (SCLC), CASTRATION RESISTANT PROSTATE CANCER (CRPC) AND FOLLICULAR LYMPHOMA (FL)
brief_summary: A Phase 1 Dose Escalation and Expanded Cohort Study Of PF-06821497 (Mevrometostat) in Adult Patients With Relapsed/Refractory Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC), Castration Resistant Prostate Cancer (CRPC) And Follicular Lymphoma (FL).
interventions: {'id': 205738910, 'name': 'Mervometostat (PF-06821497)', 'description': 'Oral continuous', 'other_names': ['EZH2i'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205738911, 'name': 'Enzalutamide', 'description': 'Oral continuous', 'other_names': ['Xtandi'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
diseases_targeted: Follicular Lymphoma; Metastatic Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer; Small Cell Lung Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed advanced/metastatic disease of the specified tumor types by study part. | Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer with prior abiraterone and/or enzalutamide and evidence of progression per PCWG3 (part-dependent; includes Japan and China cohorts). | mCRPC may have received up to 1 prior line of chemotherapy (part-dependent). | Part 2B/2C: mCRPC with prior abiraterone, up to 1 prior chemotherapy line, no prior enzalutamide/apalutamide/darolutamide, and progression per PCWG3. | Radiographic evidence of disease required (Part 2B/2C). | CRPC resistant/intolerant to SOC or lacking available beneficial SOC; refusal of SOC may be eligible (cohort-dependent). | ECOG performance status 0–1.
exclusion_criteria: More than the allowed prior chemotherapy regimens: Part 1C/Japan/China (CRPC) >2 regimens; Part 2A (mCRPC) >1 regimen; Part 2B (mCRPC) >1 regimen. | Prior irradiation to >25% of bone marrow. | QTcF >480 msec at screening. | Uncontrolled hypertension >150/90 mmHg despite optimal therapy. | Known or suspected hypersensitivity to mevrometostat (PF-06821497) or components, or to enzalutamide (for CRPC cohorts). | Active inflammatory gastrointestinal disease, chronic diarrhea, known diverticular disease, or prior gastric resection/lap band surgery; GERD on proton pump inhibitors allowed. | Current use or anticipated need for strong CYP3A4/5 inducers or inhibitors, including within 10 days or 5 half-lives before first dose.
prior_therapies: Prior treatment with abiraterone and/or enzalutamide required with documented progression (PCWG3) for mCRPC.; Up to 1 prior line of chemotherapy allowed in some parts; up to 2 prior chemotherapy regimens allowed in specific cohorts (cohort-dependent).
reasoning: Disease and setting match mCRPC, and the patient (66M) meets line-of-therapy requirements with prior abiraterone and enzalutamide and progression, as well as age criteria. No explicit exclusions are evident; while some cohorts prohibit prior enzalutamide, other parts allow it.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Male sex; Age 66 years; Castration-resistant prostate cancer; Metastatic disease; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Androgen deprivation therapy (leuprolide); Abiraterone (Zytiga); Enzalutamide (progression on)
judge_comment: No hard exclusions. Disease and metastatic setting match. Prior-exposure anchor matches (prior abiraterone and enzalutamide with progression). Biomarker not required; mets pattern unrestricted. Cohort-specific prohibition of prior enzalutamide does not preclude eligibility since other cohorts allow it. Unknowns (PCWG3 documentation, ECOG) are neutral. Thus ≥2 core anchors match with no soft conflicts → A.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase II Open-Label Study of Sacituzumab Govitecan in Unresectable Locally Advanced/Metastatic Urothelial Cancer
brief_summary: The objective of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of sacituzumab govitecan-hziy monotherapy and with novel combinations in participants with metastatic urothelial cancer (mUC).
interventions: {'id': 206376431, 'name': 'Sacituzumab Govitecan-hziy', 'description': 'Administered intravenously.', 'other_names': ['IMMU-132', 'Trodelvy™'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206376432, 'name': 'Pembrolizumab', 'description': 'Administered per package insert', 'other_names': ['KEYTRUDA®'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206376433, 'name': 'Cisplatin', 'description': 'Administered per package insert', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206376434, 'name': 'Avelumab', 'description': 'Administered per package insert', 'other_names': ['BAVENCIO®'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206376435, 'name': 'Zimberelimab', 'description': 'Administered intravenously', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206376436, 'name': 'Carboplatin', 'description': 'Administered per package insert', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206376437, 'name': 'Gemcitabine', 'description': 'Administered per package insert', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206376438, 'name': 'Domvanalimab', 'description': 'Administered intravenously', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206376439, 'name': 'Enfortumab Vedotin', 'description': 'Administered intravenously', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Adequate renal and hepatic function | Adequate hematologic parameters without transfusional support | Life expectancy >= 3 months | Cohorts 4 and 6: Measurable disease by RECIST 1.1 | Cohorts 1, 2, 3, 5: Creatinine clearance >= 30 mL/min | Cohort 4: No prior platinum-based chemotherapy in the metastatic or unresectable locally advanced setting | Cohort 4: Creatinine clearance >= 50 mL/min; if receiving cisplatin 70 mg/m2 Day 1 q21d, creatinine clearance >= 60 mL/min; if creatinine clearance 50–59 mL/min, receive split-dose cisplatin | Cohorts 4, 5, 6, 7: Archival tumor tissue (muscle-invasive or metastatic urothelial carcinoma) or biopsy of metastatic urothelial carcinoma | Cohort 5: Completed 4–6 cycles of gemcitabine + cisplatin with CR/PR/SD and treatment-free interval of 4–10 weeks | Cohort 6: Cisplatin-ineligible; no prior therapy for metastatic or unresectable locally advanced disease; CPI-naive or >12 months from completion of adjuvant therapy | Cohort 7: No prior systemic therapy for locally advanced or metastatic urothelial cancer (recurrence >12 months after curative therapy allowed) | Cohort 7: Measurable disease by RECIST 1.1
exclusion_criteria: Pregnant or lactating | Active second malignancy | Known active hepatitis B or hepatitis C | Known active central nervous system metastases and/or carcinomatous meningitis | Other concurrent medical or psychiatric conditions that would preclude study participation | Prior anti-cancer monoclonal antibody within 4 weeks before Day 1 or unresolved > Grade 1 toxicities from prior therapy | Cohorts 3–6: Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment in past 2 years | Cohorts 3–6: Receipt of a live vaccine within 30 days prior to first dose | Cohorts 3–6: History or evidence of interstitial lung disease or non-infectious pneumonitis | Cohort 3: Prior anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy | Cohort 4: Refractory to platinum in neoadjuvant/adjuvant setting (relapse <= 12 months after completion) | Cohorts 4, 5, 6: If prior checkpoint inhibitor, treatment-free interval must be >12 months between last dose and date of recurrence | Cohort 7: Prior anticancer therapy within 12 months before C1D1 or prior radiation within 2 weeks before C1D1 | Cohort 7: History of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, organizing pneumonia, drug-induced or idiopathic pneumonitis, or active pneumonitis on screening CT | Cohort 7: Child-Pugh class B or C hepatic impairment | Cohort 7: Uncontrolled diabetes | Cohort 7: Active keratitis or corneal ulcerations | Cohort 7: Ongoing sensory or motor neuropathy Grade >= 2
prior_therapies: Cohort 1: Prior platinum-containing therapy and prior anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy with progression/recurrence; Cohort 2: Platinum-ineligible for first-line metastatic disease and progression after first-line anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy; no prior platinum for recurrent/metastatic/advanced disease; Cohort 3: Prior platinum-containing therapy with progression/recurrence; Cohort 4: No prior platinum-based chemotherapy in the metastatic or unresectable locally advanced setting; Cohort 5: Completed 4–6 cycles of gemcitabine + cisplatin without progressive disease; Cohort 6: No prior therapy for metastatic or unresectable locally advanced disease; CPI-naive or >12 months since completion of adjuvant therapy; Cohort 7: No prior systemic therapy for locally advanced or metastatic disease (curative-intent therapy allowed if recurrence >12 months)
reasoning: Metastatic urothelial cancer matches, and Cohort 1 specifically requires prior platinum and prior PD-1/PD-L1 therapy with progression, which the patient has; creatinine clearance ~35 mL/min meets the ≥30 mL/min threshold, and age/sex fit. No explicit exclusions are triggered; other requirements (ECOG, timing of last therapy) are unknown.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progression after second-line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab; Bone and liver metastases; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD; Age 55 years; Male sex
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: No hard exclusions. Disease matches. Stage/setting matches (metastatic). Line/prior exposure matches via Cohort 1 (prior platinum and prior PD-1 with progression). Renal function meets cohort threshold (>=30 mL/min). No identified soft mismatches. Grade A per rubric.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase I Dose Escalation / Dose Expansion Study of NBTXR3 Activated by Radiotherapy for Patients with Advanced Cancers Treated with an Anti-PD-1 Therapy
brief_summary: The 1100 study is an open-label, Phase I, dose escalation and expansion prospective clinical study to assess the safety of intratumoral injection of NBTXR3 activated by radiotherapy in combination with anti-PD-1 therapy.
interventions: {'id': 205979917, 'name': 'NBTXR3', 'description': 'Single intra Tumoral injection', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205979918, 'name': 'SABR', 'description': 'Radiotherapy given as a definite number of fractions at the dose defined for each radiation field', 'other_names': ['Stereotaxic Ablative Radiotherapy', 'Stereotaxic Body Radiation Therapy'], 'intervention_type': 'RADIATION'}; {'id': 205979919, 'name': 'Nivolumab', 'description': 'Anti-PD-1 monotherapy', 'other_names': ['Opdivo'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205979920, 'name': 'Pembrolizumab', 'description': 'Anti-PD-1 monotherapy', 'other_names': ['Keytruda'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
diseases_targeted: Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma (recurrent/metastatic); Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (metastatic); Melanoma (metastatic); Renal Cell Carcinoma (metastatic); Triple-Negative Breast Cancer (metastatic); Urothelial Carcinoma (metastatic); Cervical Cancer (metastatic); Hepatocellular Carcinoma (metastatic)
inclusion_criteria: Biopsy-confirmed cancer indicated for anti-PD-1 therapy | Inoperable locoregional recurrent or recurrent/metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma with a lesion amenable to irradiation (head and neck region, lung, or liver) | Metastatic disease to lung (including involved/mediastinal lymph nodes) or liver with a lesion in a previously non-irradiated field (dose escalation cohorts 2–3) | At least one measurable lesion per RECIST 1.1 that is amenable to intratumoral injection | Prior anti-PD-1 exposure status meeting cohort criteria (anti-PD-1 naive or primary/secondary resistance as specified) | ECOG performance status 0–2 | Life expectancy >12 weeks | Adequate organ and bone marrow function | Negative pregnancy test <= 7 days prior to NBTXR3 injection for women of child-bearing potential
exclusion_criteria: History of immune-related adverse events from anti-PD-1/L1 that led to termination and precludes further PD-1 exposure | Symptomatic central nervous system metastases or carcinomatous meningitis | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment within the past 1 year | Known HIV infection | Active hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection | Active infection requiring intravenous antibiotics | Receipt of a live virus vaccine within 30 days prior to study treatment | History of pneumonitis requiring steroids or current pneumonitis | Extensive metastatic disease burden (>5 lesions overall including the primary tumor) | Locoregional recurrent HNSCC with ulceration | Prior checkpoint inhibitor within 2 weeks before NBTXR3 injection | Prior systemic anti-neoplastic therapy (including investigational agents) within 4 weeks before NBTXR3 injection | Unresolved adverse events from prior anti-neoplastic therapies and/or interventions (including radiation) > Grade 1 or not at baseline at screening | Clinically significant cardiac arrhythmias | NYHA Class III or IV heart failure within 6 months prior to screening | Pregnant or nursing female | Women of child-bearing potential and men who are sexually active not willing/able to use acceptable contraception | Any condition for which participation would not be in the participant's best interest
prior_therapies: Prior anti-PD-1 therapy allowed; participants may be anti-PD-1 naive or have primary/secondary resistance per cohort; Expansion Cohorts 1 and 3 require prior anti-PD-1 primary or secondary resistance; Expansion Cohort 2 requires anti-PD-1 naive; Washout: no prior checkpoint inhibitor within 2 weeks before NBTXR3 injection; Washout: no prior systemic anti-neoplastic therapy (including investigational agents) within 4 weeks before NBTXR3 injection; Prior radiation allowed; injectable lesion may be in a previously irradiated field for specified HNSCC cohorts
reasoning: Disease and setting match (metastatic urothelial carcinoma), and prior anti-PD-1 exposure is allowed with cohorts for resistance, fitting the patient’s post–second-line status; age/sex are within limits. Final eligibility hinges on having a lesion amenable to intratumoral injection/radiotherapy and meeting organ function/ECOG requirements.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progression after second-line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab; Bone and liver metastases; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD; Age 55 years; Male sex
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab

Other requirements (injectable lesion, organ function/ECOG) are unknown, not mismatches. ≥2 core anchors match → A. Grader’s reasoning aligns with rubric.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Pilot Study Testing Feasibility of Individualized Therapy for Recurrent Glioblastoma
brief_summary: The current study will test the ability and likelihood of successfully implementing individualized combination treatment recommendations for adult patients with surgically-resectable recurrent glioblastoma in a timely fashion. Collected tumor tissue and blood will be examined using a new diagnostic testing called University of California, San Francisco (UCSF) 500 Cancer Gene Panel which is done at the UCSF Clinical Cancer Genomics Laboratory. The UCSF 500 Cancer Gene Panel will help identify ...
interventions: {'id': 206359044, 'name': 'Individualized therapy', 'description': '1. For a given proposed individualized combination of drugs the first priority to establish doses will be to identify the same combination of drugs in a peer-reviewed journal article or presented as a reviewed abstract.\n2. When a proposed individualized combination of drugs has not previously been reported, the process to establish doses will be to then identify individual members of the proposed combination that have been used in combination with other cytotoxic agents similar to those being considered for combination therapy.\n3. When a proposed individualized combination of drugs has no available combination data, dosing guidelines will start with the FDA-approved package insert recommended dose.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Histologically proven recurrent glioblastoma or gliosarcoma (WHO grade IV) that is surgically resectable | Surgeon anticipates resection of at least 500 mg of tumor | Karnofsky Performance Scale >= 70% | Estimated life expectancy >= 3 months | Received appropriate prior therapy for GBM at initial diagnosis, including radiation therapy | Adequate bone marrow function | Adequate hepatic function | Adequate renal function | Able to undergo MRI for tumor evaluation | Women of child-bearing potential: negative pregnancy test within 7 days prior to surgery | Women and men agree to use adequate contraception during treatment and for 3 months after completion | No New York Heart Association class II or greater congestive heart failure | No history of myocardial infarction or unstable angina within 12 months prior to enrollment
exclusion_criteria: Chemotherapy or radiotherapy <= 4 weeks prior to registration (exceptions: >= 23 days from last temozolomide; >= 6 weeks from last nitrosourea) | Not recovered to grade 1 or baseline from adverse effects of prior radiotherapy or chemotherapy | Less than 12 weeks from initial course of radiation | Multifocal tumor, primarily infratentorial or posterior fossa tumor, or leptomeningeal dissemination | Active malignancy other than GBM, excluding non-melanoma skin cancer or carcinoma in situ of cervix, prostate, or breast, unless disease-free/in remission for >= 2 years | Known HIV-positive | Uncontrolled concurrent illness, including psychiatric illness, that would limit compliance | Any acute or chronic medical or psychiatric condition or laboratory abnormality increasing risk or interfering with trial, per investigator judgment
prior_therapies: Prior radiation therapy for GBM required at initial diagnosis; Any number of prior therapies allowed; No chemotherapy or radiotherapy within 4 weeks before registration (>= 23 days for temozolomide; >= 6 weeks for nitrosourea)
reasoning: Disease and recurrent setting align, with prior standard RT/TMZ completed and adequate washout since last therapy; age and sex meet criteria and no explicit exclusions are triggered. Surgical resectability and KPS are not specified but there is no conflict with these requirements.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Recurrent glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; ECOG 1; Age 40; Male; Prior gross total resection; Completed adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Completed adjuvant temozolomide; Recurrence three months after completing adjuvant therapy; No other medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Prior gross total resection; Prior radiation therapy with concurrent temozolomide; Prior adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: Disease matches and prior exposure/washout align (Line/prior anchor = match). However, a key part of Stage/setting is surgical resectability, which is required by the trial and is unknown for the patient; KPS is also required and unspecified. With only one confirmed CORE ANCHOR match and no soft conflicts, the rubric supports grade B, not A.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: Precision Radiation for OligoMetastatIc and MetaStatic DiseasE (PROMISE)-004: Consolidative Use of Radiotherapy to Block (CURB) Oligoprogression
brief_summary: The purpose of this study is determine if receiving stereotactic body radiation(SBRT) when participants' metastatic tumors have just begun to grow increase the length of time before disease gets worse
interventions: {'id': 206380145, 'name': 'Sterotactic Body Radiotherapy/SBRT', 'description': 'In general, it is recommended using 9-10 Gy x 3 or 10 Gy x 5 fractions given every other day. Physicians should try to give the highest BED whenever possible while respecting normal tissue tolerance. All lesions are recommended to receive a biologically effective dose (BED) of 60 Gy or higher (BED10≥70), assuming α/β ratio of 10 and using the linear-quadratic model: BED = nd x \\[1 + d/(α/β)\\] where n is number of fractions and d is dose per fraction. Sometimes BED ≥80 Gy is preferred, with lower doses ≥50 Gy allowed at the discretion of the treating physician for concerns about normal tissue toxicity.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'RADIATION'}; {'id': 206380146, 'name': 'Standard of care', 'description': 'Standard of care per physician discretion', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
diseases_targeted: Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (metastatic); Triple-Negative Breast Cancer; Breast Cancer (metastatic)
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 | Metastatic disease confirmed on imaging and histology | Oligoprogression with progression in up to 5 lesions per RECIST or PERCIST definitions | Maximum 5 progressing metastases in any single extracranial organ system | All sites of oligoprogression can be safely treated with local therapy | No restriction on total number of metastases | Patients may have >5 total metastases provided only 1–5 lesions are progressive | Brain metastases permitted; brain lesions may be treated before randomization without counting toward the 5 progressive lesions | Symptomatic metastatic sites requiring urgent palliative radiation may be treated before randomization without counting toward the 5 progressive lesions | Prior systemic therapy: received at least first-line treatment (cytotoxic or targeted, including maintenance) | Patients who received prior immunotherapy are allowed | Patients who had prior radiation near or overlapping oligoprogressive sites are allowed | For NSCLC: either no known EGFR mutation or ALK/ROS1 rearrangement, or if present, progression on first-line tyrosine kinase inhibitor | Other local therapies (surgery or ablation) may be used if deemed more suitable after discussion with the investigator
exclusion_criteria: Pregnancy | Leptomeningeal disease | Serious comorbidities precluding radiotherapy (e.g., ataxia-telangiectasia, scleroderma) | Any condition that in the investigator's judgment makes the patient inappropriate for the study
prior_therapies: At least first-line prior systemic therapy required; Prior immunotherapy allowed; Prior radiation near or overlapping progressive sites allowed; Brain stereotactic radiation permitted prior to randomization; Palliative radiation for symptomatic sites permitted prior to randomization; For NSCLC with EGFR/ALK/ROS1 alterations: prior first-line tyrosine kinase inhibitor with progression required
reasoning: Metastatic NSCLC with EGFR exon 19 deletion and progression after first-line osimertinib meets stage/setting and prior-therapy requirements, and age/ECOG fit. The trial’s oligoprogression limit (≤5 progressive lesions) is not clearly violated since the number of progressive lesions is unspecified, so no soft conflict is confirmed.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; ECOG 0; De novo metastatic disease; Metastases to bone and liver; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years with complete response; Recent MRI shows numerous lesions; No past medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Osimertinib
judge_comment: Disease, stage (metastatic), and prior therapy (EGFR-mutant NSCLC with progression after first-line TKI) match, but the trial requires oligoprogression (≤5 progressive lesions). The patient’s “recent MRI shows numerous lesions” after prior complete response implies more than 5 progressive lesions, a metastatic-pattern soft mismatch. Per rubric, any clear soft mismatch → D, not A.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase I Clinical Trial of Allogeneic Bone Marrow Human Mesenchymal Stem Cells Loaded With A Tumor Selective Oncolytic Adenovirus, DNX-2401, Administered Via Intra-Arterial Injection in Patients With Recurrent High-Grade Glioma
brief_summary: This phase I trial studies best dose and side effects of oncolytic adenovirus DNX-2401 in treating patients with high-grade glioma that has come back (recurrent). Oncolytic adenovirus DNX-2401 is made from the common cold virus that has been changed in the laboratory to make it less likely to cause an infection (such as a cold). The virus is also changed to target brain cancer cells and attack them.

trial_title: Low Dose IL-2 for the Treatment of Crohn's Disease
brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and maximum effective dose (MED) of Interleukin-2 in subjects with moderate-to-severe crohn's disease.
interventions: {'id': 206165142, 'name': 'Interleukin-2 (aldesleukin).', 'description': 'Description of intervention is covered in "Arm", above.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Age 12-80 years. | Crohn disease diagnosed by standard clinical, radiologic, endoscopic, and histologic criteria. | Moderate-to-severe disease activity (CDAI 220-450). | Endoscopic inflammation accessible by ileocolonoscopy or ileoscopy with SES-CD >= 6 (or >= 4 for isolated ileal disease). | Ileostomy or colostomy subset permitted; ileostomy assessed as isolated ileal disease for SES-CD. | Failure to tolerate or respond to at least one conventional therapy or corticosteroid-dependent disease. | Stable doses of concomitant medications. | Negative pregnancy test for women of childbearing potential; effective contraception during treatment and for 6 months after.
exclusion_criteria: Ulcerative colitis or indeterminate colitis. | Immediate need for surgical, endoscopic, or radiologic intervention for perforation, sepsis, or intra-abdominal or perianal abscess. | History of colorectal cancer or dysplasia. | Positive stool test for Clostridium difficile by GDH/EIA method. | Current medically significant infection. | Hemoglobin < 7.0 g/dL. | White blood cell count < 2.5 x 10^3/µL. | Platelets < 50 x 10^3/µL. | Creatinine >= 2 x ULN. | Total bilirubin > 2.0 mg/dL. | ALT > 2 x ULN. | Abnormal thyroid function tests. | Positive serology for HIV, hepatitis B virus, or hepatitis C virus. | Positive tuberculosis screening test. | Malignancy within the last 5 years, excluding non-melanoma skin cancer. | Allergy to any component of the study drug. | Pregnant or lactating women. | Prior exposure to interleukin-2. | Uncontrolled angina or symptomatic congestive heart failure (NYHA Class III or IV).
prior_therapies: Failure or intolerance to at least one conventional therapy (e.g., corticosteroids, 5-aminosalicylates, azathioprine/6-mercaptopurine, TNF antagonists, anti-integrins, ustekinumab) or corticosteroid dependence.; Washout: no biologic medication within 4 weeks before first study dose.; Washout: no other investigational agent (IND) within 5 half-lives before baseline.
reasoning: Disease matches Crohn’s with moderate-to-severe activity (CDAI 350), age/sex within range, and prior failure of infliximab/ustekinumab meets the trial’s prior-therapy requirement. No explicit exclusions are triggered; SES-CD/endoscopic status and washout timing are unknown but not conflicting.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active draining perianal fistula with seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: No hard exclusions. Disease matches Crohn’s; stage/severity (CDAI 350 within 220–450) matches; prior therapy failure matches the trial’s requirement. Other criteria (SES-CD, washout) are unknown, not conflicting. ≥2 core anchors matched with no soft conflicts → A per rubric.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: DS3201 With Ipilimumab in Patients With Metastatic Aggressive Variant Prostate (AVPC), Urothelial (UC), and Renal Cell (RCC) Carcinomas
brief_summary: This phase Ib trial studies the side effects and best dose of DS3201 when given together with and ipilimumab for the treatment of patients with prostate, urothelial, or renal cell cancer that has spread to other places in the body (metastatic). DS3201 may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as ipilimumab, may help the body's immune system attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of t...

inclusion_criteria: ECOG performance status 0-1 | Histologically or cytologically confirmed prostate carcinoma, urothelial carcinoma, or clear cell renal cell carcinoma; variant prostate histologies (small cell/neuroendocrine) permitted | Metastatic disease by CT/MRI and/or bone scan, or locally advanced not amenable to locoregional therapy | Prostate carcinoma: castration-resistant disease and maintain castrate testosterone (<= 50 ng/dL or <= 2.0 nM) throughout the study; small cell histology exempt from progression on prior ADT but must maintain castrate levels | Aggressive variant prostate carcinoma requires molecular signature: loss or mutation in at least 2 of TP53, RB1, PTEN by CLIA-certified testing | Renal cell carcinoma: progressive disease during or after at least one anti-angiogenic agent and one PD-1 or PD-L1 inhibitor | Urothelial carcinoma: progressive disease during or after at least one PD-1 or PD-L1 inhibitor and prior platinum chemotherapy or platinum-ineligible | AVPC patients may have received prior PD-1 or PD-L1 inhibitor but not required | Evidence of disease progression by RECIST; for AVPC, rising PSA per PCWG3 may qualify if AVPC molecular criteria met | Known brain metastases allowed if stable >= 4 weeks after local therapy, off steroids or on stable/decreasing dose <= 10 mg prednisone equivalent daily, and without confounding neurologic dysfunction | Recovery from prior surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, or other anti-cancer therapy to baseline or <= grade 1 (other low-grade toxicities may be allowed if clinically insignificant) | Ability to swallow and retain oral medications | Disease site accessible for serial biopsies
exclusion_criteria: Pregnant or lactating | Carcinomatous meningitis | Prior treatment with an EZH2 inhibitor | PD-1, PD-L1, PD-L2, or CTLA-4 inhibitor within 4 weeks prior to day 1 | Monoclonal antibody within 4 weeks prior to day 1 | Investigational drug within 2 weeks prior to day 1 | Chemotherapy within 2 weeks prior to day 1 | Radiation therapy or radionuclide therapy within 2 weeks prior to day 1 | Receipt of live virus vaccine within 30 days prior to day 1 | Untreated symptomatic spinal cord compression or brain metastases | History of immune-related adverse event leading to permanent discontinuation of prior immunotherapy | History of >= grade 3 immune-related adverse event within past 16 weeks, any grade 4 life-threatening irAE, or neurologic/ocular irAE of any grade with prior immunotherapy (endocrine AEs allowed if on stable replacement, no adrenal crisis, asymptomatic) | Active, known, or suspected autoimmune disease (exceptions: vitiligo, type 1 diabetes, residual hypothyroidism on replacement, psoriasis/eczema not requiring systemic treatment, or conditions not expected to recur) | Requires chronic systemic corticosteroids > 10 mg prednisone equivalents daily or other immunosuppressive medications (physiologic adrenal replacement > 10 mg allowed without active autoimmune disease; unstable angina within 3 months; CHF NYHA class 3-4; clinically significant ventricular arrhythmias; uncontrolled hypertension (SBP >= 140 mmHg or DBP >= 90 mmHg); baseline ECG abnormalities including QTc > 470 msec, complete LBBB, ischemic ST-T changes, second- or third-degree AV block, or serious brady-/tachyarrhythmias | Active hepatitis B (positive HBsAg) or active hepatitis C (detectable HCV RNA) | Known HIV infection | Gastrointestinal disorder that negatively affects absorption (e.g., short bowel syndrome, severe diarrhea, TPN requirement) | Additional malignancy that is progressing, requires active treatment, or has >= 30% probability of recurrence within 24 months (exceptions: non-melanoma skin cancer after curative therapy, Ta urothelial carcinoma, stage 0 CLL) | Any other severe/uncontrolled medical condition that could compromise participation | Unwilling or unable to comply with the study protocol
prior_therapies: Renal cell carcinoma: prior treatment with at least one anti-angiogenic agent; Renal cell carcinoma: prior treatment with a PD-1 or PD-L1 inhibitor; Urothelial carcinoma: prior treatment with a PD-1 or PD-L1 inhibitor; Urothelial carcinoma: prior platinum-based chemotherapy or platinum-ineligible; Prostate cancer: maintain castrate testosterone during study; Washout: PD-1/PD-L1/PD-L2 or CTLA-4 inhibitors within 4 weeks prior to day 1 not allowed; Washout: monoclonal antibody within 4 weeks prior to day 1 not allowed; Washout: investigational drug within 2 weeks prior to day 1 not allowed; Washout: chemotherapy within 2 weeks prior to day 1 not allowed; Washout: radiation or radionuclide therapy within 2 weeks prior to day 1 not allowed
reasoning: Disease and setting match (metastatic urothelial carcinoma with progression), and prior-exposure requirements are met (prior platinum and PD-1 therapy). Age/sex fit, and no explicit exclusions are evident from the provided data.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progression after second-line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab; Bone and liver metastases; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD; Age 55 years; Male sex
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Assessment of Safety and Feasibility of Exablate Type 2 for Blood-Brain Barrier Disruption (BBBD) With Microbubble Resonators for the Treatment of Recurrent Glioblastoma (rGBM) in Subjects Undergoing Carboplatin Monotherapy
brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and feasibility of the Exablate Model 4000 Type 2 system when used as a tool to open the blood-brain-barrier (BBB) in subjects with recurrent glioblastoma (rGBM) undergoing carboplatin monotherapy.
interventions: {'id': 205255338, 'name': 'Carboplatin', 'description': 'Carboplatin infusion on the day of Exablate BBBD procedure to treat cancerous cells in the brain', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205255339, 'name': 'Exablate BBBD', 'description': 'BBB opening via Exablate Neuro Type 2 system with microbubble resonators.', 'other_names': ['Exablate Neuro'], 'intervention_type': 'DEVICE'}

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: Vagus Nerve Stimulation Using the SetPoint System for Moderate to Severe Rheumatoid Arthritis: The RESET-RA Study
brief_summary: The RESET-RA study will assess the safety and efficacy of the SetPoint System (study device) for the treatment of adult patients with active, moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis who have had an inadequate response or intolerance to biologic or targeted synthetic Disease-Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drugs (DMARDs). The study device contains a miniaturized stimulator (implant) that is surgically placed under general anesthesia on the vagus nerve through a small incision on the left side of the ...

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase II, Multicenter, Prospective Study of Sacituzumab Govitecan in Recurrent Glioblastoma
brief_summary: This is an open-label single arm study. All patients will receive the study drug. The aim of the study is to compare overall survival (OS) of patients with recurrent brain tumor, known as Glioblastoma (GBM) having high levels of a protein, Trophoblast cell surface antigen 2 (Trop-2), expression on treatment with Sacituzumab Govitecan (SG) versus lomustine only which has been used in the past.
interventions: {'id': 206509260, 'name': 'Sacituzumab Govitecan', 'description': 'Sacituzumab Govitecan will be administered by IV infusion over 3 hours for first administration and over 1 hour if tolerated. Subjects will be allowed to continue treatment until they have evidence of significant treatment-related toxicity or progressive disease.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Histologically confirmed IDH wild-type glioblastoma; molecular GBM per cIMPACT-NOW 3 allowed; gliosarcoma and epithelioid glioblastoma allowed | Progression after standard chemoradiation with temozolomide if MGMT methylated; if MGMT unmethylated, must have received standard-dose radiation | Prior tumor-treating fields allowed and not considered an additional line of therapy | No additional lines of therapy given for recurrent disease | Surgery for recurrence allowed if >= 2 weeks before enrollment with MRI within 48 hours post-surgery | No radiotherapy within the 3 months prior to the diagnosis of progression | Willing to forego tumor-treating field therapy during study participation | Stable or decreasing corticosteroid dose for >= 7 days prior to baseline MRI | Recovered from prior therapy toxicities to grade 0–1 (except neuropathy <= grade 2 and alopecia) | ECOG <=2 | Life expectancy >= 6 months | Bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN | AST <= 3.0 x ULN | ALT <= 3.0 x ULN | Creatinine clearance >= 30 mL/min | ANC >= 1500/µL | Platelets >= 100000/µL | Hemoglobin >= 9.0 g/dL | Availability of tumor tissue for central review/biomarker testing | Measurable recurrent or residual disease by RANO; multifocal and infratentorial disease allowed | Positive Trop-2 expression (H-score >= 200) by central review
exclusion_criteria: Prior treatment with bevacizumab or other VEGF/VEGFR pathway inhibitors | Use of warfarin or other coumarin anticoagulants if unable to switch to low molecular weight heparin before first dose | Evidence of acute intracranial or intratumoral hemorrhage on MRI or CT (resolving changes, punctate hemorrhage, or hemosiderin allowed) | Unable to undergo MRI (e.g., pacemaker) | Use of enzyme-inducing antiepileptic drugs within 14 days before study drug (e.g., carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, primidone) | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Uncontrolled hypertension (>150 mmHg systolic or >100 mmHg diastolic on >=2 readings at screening) despite optimal therapy | Non-healing wound, ulcer, or bone fracture | Significant cardiac arrhythmias | Untreated hypothyroidism | Unhealed rectal or perirectal abscess | Uncontrolled active infection | Symptomatic congestive heart failure or unstable angina within 3 months | Any history of cardiac arrhythmia or heart block | Stroke or transient ischemic attack within 6 months | Prior non-standard radiation therapy (brachytherapy, systemic radioisotope therapy, intra-operative radiotherapy); stereotactic radiosurgery allowed | Systemic therapy (including investigational agents and small-molecule kinase inhibitors) or non-cytotoxic hormonal therapy within 7 days or 5 half-lives (whichever is shorter) before first dose | Biologic agents (antibodies, immune modulators, vaccines, cytokines) within 21 days before first dose | Nitrosoureas or mitomycin C within 42 days before first dose | Metronomic/protracted low-dose chemotherapy within 14 days before first dose | Other cytotoxic chemotherapy within 28 days before first dose | Prior treatment with carmustine wafers | Radiographic or clinical leptomeningeal disease
prior_therapies: Prior standard-dose radiation required; Prior temozolomide required if MGMT methylated; Prior tumor-treating fields allowed; Surgery for recurrence allowed if >= 2 weeks before enrollment; Washout: systemic therapy within 7 days or 5 half-lives (whichever shorter) before first dose; Washout: biologic agents within 21 days before first dose; Washout: nitrosoureas or mitomycin C within 42 days before first dose; Washout: metronomic/protracted low-dose chemotherapy within 14 days before first dose; Washout: other cytotoxic chemotherapy within 28 days before first dose
reasoning: Disease and setting match (recurrent IDH-wildtype GBM), and prior therapy/line requirements are met (post standard chemoradiation and TMZ with no therapy for recurrence). No exclusions are evident; Trop-2 positivity and other labs are unknown and would need confirmation.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Recurrent glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; ECOG 1; Age 40; Male; Prior gross total resection; Completed adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Completed adjuvant temozolomide; Recurrence three months after completing adjuvant therapy; No other medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Prior gross total resection; Prior radiation therapy with concurrent temozolomide; Prior adjuvant temozolomide

Since A requires required biomarkers to be satisfied, A is not appropriate. With one clear core anchor (stage/setting) and no soft conflicts, B is the correct grade.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 2 Clinical Trial: Xanthohumol Metabolism and Signature (XMaS) in Crohn's Disease
brief_summary: A pilot study to assess the safety and tolerability of an orally administered natural product derived from hops, called xanthohumol, in humans with Crohn's Disease, in order to identify a biological signature of xanthohumol exposure, and to characterize the role of xanthohumol metabolism by intestinal microorganisms in that signature within adults with Crohn's Disease.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 1 / 2 Study of Visudyne (Liposomal Verteporfin) in Persons with Recurrent High Grade EGFR-Mutated Glioblastoma
brief_summary: This phase I/II trial studies the side effects and best dose of Visudyne (liposomal verteporfin) and to see how well it works in treating patients with high grade EGFR-mutated glioblastoma that has come back (recurrent). Visudyne is FDA approved in combination with light to treat eye diseases. In this study we use Visudyne by itself like chemotherapy to kill tumor cells which may be sensitive to verteporfin.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. brief_summary: The 2021 ACR RA treatment guideline, based on widely acknowledged low to moderate quality evidence, recommends switching to a non-tumor necrosis factor (TNFi) biologic (choose among existing medications, currently, rituximab, abatacept, tocilizumab, or sarilumab) or a targeted synthetic DMARD arm (tsDMARD; choose among existing medications, currently, tofacitinib, baricitinib, upadacitinib) in patients with active RA despite the use of a TNFi-biologic.
