question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: A Prospective, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Single-Center Study of Oral Epalrestat Therapy in Pediatric Subjects With Phosphomannomutase 2-congenital Disorder of Glycosylation (PMM2-CDG)
brief_summary: This is a prospective, single-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study designed to assess the safety, tolerability, and clinical and metabolic improvement of pediatric subjects with PMM2-CDG on oral epalrestat therapy vs. placebo.
interventions: {'id': 205234005, 'name': 'Epalrestat', 'description': "Epalrestat is a noncompetitive and reversible aldose reductase inhibitor (ARI) used for the treatment of diabetic neuropathy in Japan. The drug's ability to safely improve symptoms of neuropathy alone by reducing oxidative stress, increasing glutathione levels, and reducing intracellular sorbitol accumulation make it a desirable medication for PMM2-CDG patients who commonly suffer with various neuropathies. However, work recently conducted by Perlara, a public benefit company with the mandate to screen existing commercially available drugs for possible application in rare diseases, has demonstrated that Epalrestat can also elevate the level PMM2 produced endogenously. This may reduce the severity of the morbidities associated with PMM2-CDG.", 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205234006, 'name': 'Placebo', 'description': 'The placebo capsule with be identical in appearance to the Epalrestat capsule. It will contain microcrystalline cellulose filler in a gelatin capsule.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 2 and < 18 years | Molecularly confirmed biallelic PMM2 pathogenic variants | Negative urine pregnancy test (females of child-bearing potential) | Agrees to effective contraception or abstinence from prior to randomization through 3 months after treatment (subjects of child-bearing potential)
exclusion_criteria: Other known congenital disorders of glycosylation | Allergy to aldose reductase inhibitors | Hypersensitivity to epalrestat | AST > 5 x ULN within 6 months prior to screening | ALT > 5 x ULN within 6 months prior to screening | Total bilirubin > 2 x ULN within 6 months prior to screening | Albumin < 2.8 mmol/L at screening | Liver fibrosis by elastography (Fibroscan > 7 kPa) at screening | Serum creatinine > 0.5 mg/dL (<= 6 years) | Serum creatinine > 0.7 mg/dL (7-10 years) | Serum creatinine > 1.24 mg/dL (>= 11 years) | Platelet count < 125 x10^9/L | Hemoglobin < 10 g/dL | Any other clinically significant laboratory abnormality per investigator | Use of an investigational drug (including acetazolamide) within 28 days | Use of an investigational biologic within 12 months | Concurrent or planned participation in another interventional protocol or use of other unapproved therapeutics | Any other medical condition that interferes with protocol compliance, compromises safety, or interferes with interpretation of results
prior_therapies: Washout from investigational drugs >= 28 days; Washout from investigational biologics >= 12 months
reasoning: Disease and required biomarker (biallelic PMM2 variants) match, and the patient’s age (8) and sex are eligible. Line/prior exposure is compatible (no prior investigational therapy), with no identified soft conflicts.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; Moderate cerebellar dysfunction; ICARS score 35; Age 8 years; Female sex
patient_prior_therapies: (none)
judge_comment: No hard exclusions. Disease matches. Core anchors: (1) Line/prior exposure compatible (no investigational therapy) and (2) required biomarker (biallelic PMM2) satisfied. Stage/setting is neutral/unknown; no soft conflicts identified. Meets A per rubric.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase I Clinical Trial With a Window-of-Opportunity Component of Engineered NK Cells Containing Deleted TGF-ßR2 and NR3C1 in Recurrent Grade 4 Astrocytoma (Glioblastoma)
brief_summary: This phase I trial is to find out the best dose, possible benefits and/or side effects of engineered natural killer (NK) cells containing deleted TGF-betaR2 and NR3C1 (cord blood \[CB\]-NK-TGF-betaR2-/NR3C1-) in treating patients with glioblastoma that has come back (recurrent). CB-NK-TGF-betaR2-/NR3C1- cells are genetically changed immune cells that may help to control the disease.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: Multipart Exploratory Study to Evaluate Splenic Nerve Stimulation in Patients With Rheumatoid Arthritis
brief_summary: This study will evaluate the safety, tolerability, and effects of stimulating the splenic neurovascular bundle (NVB) with the Galvani System, which consists of a lead, implantable pulse generator, external components and accessories. The study will consist of 4 study periods, including a Randomized Control Trial period (Period 1), an Open Label period (Period 2), a Treat-to-target period (Period 3), and a Long-term Follow-up period (Period 4). Participants eligible for implant will have activ...

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A Phase 2 Study of XmAb20717 in Patients With Selected Gynecological Malignancies and Metastatic Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer
brief_summary: This is a Phase 2, multicenter, two-stage, open-label, parallel-group study designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of vudalimab (XmAb20717) in patients with selected advanced gynecologic and genitourinary malignancies.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase I/II Study to Evaluate the Safety and Clinical Efficacy of Atezolizumab (Anti-PD-L1) in Combination With Cabozantinib in Patients With Recurrent Glioblastoma (rGBM)
brief_summary: This phase I/II trial tests the safety and side effects of atezolizumab in combination with cabozantinib and whether they work to shrink tumors in patients with glioblastoma that has come back (recurrent). Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as atezolizumab, may help the body's immune system attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of tumor cells to grow and spread. Cabozantinib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. ...
interventions: {'id': 205869154, 'name': 'Atezolizumab', 'description': 'Given IV', 'other_names': ['RO5541267', 'Tecentriq', 'MPDL 3280A', 'MPDL 328OA', 'MPDL-3280A', 'MPDL3280A', 'MPDL328OA', 'RG7446'], 'intervention_type': 'BIOLOGICAL'}; {'id': 205869155, 'name': 'Cabozantinib', 'description': 'Given PO', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Pilot Study of Subcutaneously Administered Natural Progesterone for the Treatment of Recurrent GBM
brief_summary: This early phase I trial identifies the best dose, possible benefits and/or side effects of natural progesterone in treating patients with glioblastoma that has come back (recurrent). Progesterone is a type of hormone made by the body that plays a role in the menstrual cycle and pregnancy. Progesterone may help control tumor growth and spread in patients with glioblastoma.

trial_title: A Phase I Study of Multiple Doses of Neural Stem Cell-Based Oncolytic Virotherapy (NSC-CRAd-S-pk7) Administered Intracerebrally to Patients With Recurrent High-Grade Gliomas

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. trial_title: A Phase 1 Trial to Evaluate the Safety and Tolerability of Fb-PMT in Patients With Recurrent Glioblastoma
brief_summary: Glioblastoma is a highly aggressive and fatal form of primary malignant brain tumor with limited treatment options. fb-PMT affects a large group of cancer cell signaling pathways and thus may be effective in heterogeneous, treatment-resistant tumors such as Glioblastoma. fb-PMT also is actively transported across the blood-brain barrier into the brain. This study is being conducted to determine the dose level for further clinical development of fb-PMT to treat recurrent Glioblastoma.

trial_title: A Phase 2, Randomized, Open-Label, 24-Week Study to Assess the Pharmacodynamics, Safety, Tolerability, and Pharmacokinetics of Multiple Doses of GLM101 Administered Intravenously to Adult, Adolescent, and Pediatric Participants With PMM2-CDG
brief_summary: This is a Phase 2, randomized, open-label, 24-week treatment study to evaluate the potential pharmacodynamic (PD) activity, safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics (PK) of GLM101 in adult, adolescent, and pediatric, patients with a confirmed diagnosis of PMM2-CDG. The planned doses of GLM101 to be investigated are 10, 20, and 30 mg/kg. The study will consist of a Screening Period, a 24-week (6-month) Treatment Period, and a 30-day (1-month) Follow-Up Period.

brief_summary: The goal of the study is to test the efficacy of a dietary intervention in inducing clinical response and remission for patients with Crohn's disease in a randomized controlled trial. The intervention diet: DAIN has been adapted from the Inflammatory Bowel Disease Anti-Inflammatory Diet or IBD-AID™ taking into account the food availability and preferences of Puerto Ricans. DAIN also includes traditional foods commonly consumed in the typical Puerto Rican diet while maintaining the fundamental...

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? brief_summary: Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, the most common urea cycle disorder, is an inherited metabolic disorder caused by a genetic defect in a liver enzyme responsible for detoxification of ammonia. Individuals with OTC deficiency can build-up excess levels of ammonia in their blood, potentially resulting in devastating consequences, including cumulative and irreversible neurological damage, coma and death. The severe form of the condition emerges shortly after birth and is more common ...

trial_title: A Phase 1/2 Randomized, Umbrella Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of MK-2870 Plus Enfortumab Vedotin (EV) With and Without Pembrolizumab, as Treatment for Participants With Advanced Urothelial Carcinoma (KEYMAKER-U04): Substudy 04C
brief_summary: This study is a substudy being conducted under one pembrolizumab umbrella master study KEYMAKER-U04. The substudy will consist of 2 parts. exclusion_criteria: Prior use of belzutifan or another HIF-2a inhibitor. | Pulse oximeter reading <92% at rest or requires intermittent or chronic supplemental oxygen. | Anti-cancer treatment (chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or other investigational therapy) within 4 weeks prior to study entry (6 weeks for nitrosoureas or mitomycin C). | Prior small molecule kinase inhibitor within 2 weeks prior to study entry. | Radiation therapy within 2 weeks of start; endocrine AEs on replacement therapy and Grade 2 neuropathy allowed). | Receipt of live or live-attenuated vaccine within 30 days prior to first dose (non-live vaccines allowed). | Major surgery within 4 weeks or minor surgery (except port placement) within 1 week before treatment start. | Gastrointestinal disorder interfering with oral medication absorption or passage; inability to swallow; enteric tube, TPN, or IV fluid dependence. | Significant cardiovascular impairment (uncontrolled hypertension, CHF NYHA II or above, unstable angina, MI within 6 months, serious arrhythmia within 6 months). | Moderate to severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh B or C). | Receipt of colony-stimulating factors (e.g., G-CSF, GM-CSF, EPO) <=28 days prior to first dose. | Diagnosis of immunodeficiency. | Known HIV infection (including on antiretroviral therapy). | Known active HBV or HCV infection (allowed if prior HCV treated and cured with undetectable viral load). | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness including active infection or serious non-healing wounds/ulcers. | Psychiatric illness or social situation limiting compliance. | History of hypersensitivity to compounds with similar composition to belzutifan. | Pregnant or breastfeeding. | Any condition or laboratory abnormality that could confound results or interfere with participation per investigator judgment.
prior_therapies: At least one prior platinum-based chemotherapy regimen required.; Prior bevacizumab allowed.; Prior immunotherapy allowed.; Washout: >=4 weeks from chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or other investigational therapy (>=6 weeks for nitrosoureas or mitomycin C).; Washout: >=2 weeks from prior small molecule kinase inhibitor.; Radiation washout: >=2 weeks; palliative RT (<=2 weeks) to non-CNS disease allowed with >=1-week washout.; No participation in another interventional study within 4 weeks before first dose.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Autologous Stem Cell Transplantation with CD34-Selected Peripheral Blood Stem Cells (PBSC) in Pediatric and Adult Patients with Severe Crohn's Disease
brief_summary: The objective of this study is to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of administering high-dose chemotherapy followed by infusion of autologous CD34-selected peripheral blood stem cells (PBSC) in pediatric and adult patients with severe Crohn's disease.
interventions: {'id': 206002425, 'name': 'autologous CD34-selected peripheral blood stem cells transplant', 'description': 'high-dose immunotherapy followed by infusion of autologous CD34-selected peripheral blood stem cells (PBSC)', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'BIOLOGICAL'}; {'id': 206002426, 'name': 'Alemtuzumab', 'description': 'Transplant conditioning', 'other_names': ['Campath-1H'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206002427, 'name': 'ATG', 'description': 'Transplant conditioning', 'other_names': ['Anti-thymocyte globulin, rabbit; Thymoglobulin'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206002428, 'name': 'Melphalan', 'description': 'Transplant conditioning', 'other_names': ['L-phenylalanine mustard, phenylalanine mustard, L-PAM, or L-sarcolysin'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206002429, 'name': 'Thiotepa', 'description': 'Transplant conditioning', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206002430, 'name': 'Rituximab', 'description': 'Transplant conditioning', 'other_names': ['Rituxan'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206002431, 'name': 'Cyclophosphamide', 'description': 'Mobilization', 'other_names': ['Cytoxan'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206002432, 'name': 'G-CSF', 'description': 'Mobilization', 'other_names': ['Neupogen, Granix, Zarxio, Filgrastim'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206002433, 'name': 'Mesna', 'description': 'Mobilization', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Age 10–60 years | Severe, refractory Crohn's Disease appropriate for stem cell transplant therapy | Prior surgery with severe recurrent disease despite aggressive maintenance therapy | Diffuse small bowel and colonic disease refractory to aggressive medical treatment and not eligible for surgery without high risk of short bowel syndrome or other contraindications to surgery | Persistently high disease activity: HBI > 6 or CDAI > 250 or PCDAI > 45, or moderate disease (HBI <= 6, CDAI < 250, PCDAI 30–45) requiring daily corticosteroids and aggressive medical treatment to maintain status | Resistant complications unresponsive to medical management (e.g., multiple enteric fistulas, enterovesicular or enterovaginal fistulas, severe perianal disease, debilitating arthritis, severe skin lesions such as pyoderma, severe bony complications such as aseptic necrosis or pathologic fractures) | Severe complications from medical therapy (e.g., pancreatitis from 6-mercaptopurine, colitis from 5-ASA, severe hypersensitivity to TNF-alpha inhibitors, anti-integrin agents, or anti-IL12/23 agents) | Stoma present is allowed | No surgical therapeutic option due to risk of short bowel syndrome or patient refusal | Harvey Bradshaw Index > 5, or CDAI > 250, or PCDAI > 30 | Platelet count > 100,000/µL | Absolute neutrophil count > 1500/µL | Creatinine <= 2.0 mg/dL | No history of coronary artery disease; LVEF >= 40% or shortening fraction >= 26% | FEV1/FVC >= 60% predicted; DLCO >= 60% predicted | Negative pregnancy test for females of childbearing potential | Agreement to use effective contraception during treatment and for up to 24 months after PBSC transplant or while on any medication that may harm a pregnancy
exclusion_criteria: No prior adequate dosing of 6-mercaptopurine, 5-ASA products, and metronidazole | Sustained corticosteroid-free response to anti-TNF-alpha, anti-integrin, or anti-IL12/23 therapy after a 4-month course | Toxic megacolon | Intestinal perforation | Conjugated bilirubin > 2.0 mg/dL | Pregnancy or nursing | HIV seropositive, HTLV seropositive, HBsAg positive, or HCV RNA positive by PCR | Active infection within two weeks of mobilization and high-dose chemotherapy | Other significant medical problems or abnormal findings that increase risk, interfere with compliance, or impact data quality in the investigator's opinion
prior_therapies: Prior adequate dosing of 6-mercaptopurine, 5-ASA products, and metronidazole required; Prior surgery allowed
reasoning: Disease and severity match well (CDAI 350, severe perianal fistulizing disease; age 32 within 10–60). However, the trial requires prior adequate dosing of 6-mercaptopurine, 5-ASA, and metronidazole and specific organ function/infection criteria, which are unknown for this patient, so only one core anchor is confirmed.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active draining perianal fistula with seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: No hard exclusions. Disease matches Crohn’s. Stage/severity clearly matches (severe, refractory, fistulizing). Line/prior exposure has a required prior dosing (6-MP, 5-ASA, metronidazole) that is unknown, so cannot be counted as a match. No soft mismatches identified. Exactly one core anchor confirmed → Grade B per rubric.

trial_title: A Phase II Study of Reduced Intensity Conditioning in Pediatric Patients and Young Adults ≤55 Years of Age With Non-Malignant Disorders Undergoing Umbilical Cord Blood, Bone Marrow, or Peripheral Blood Stem Cell Transplantation
brief_summary: The objective of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of using a reduced-intensity condition (RIC) regimen with umbilical cord blood transplant (UCBT), double cord UCBT, matched unrelated donor (MUD) bone marrow transplant (BMT) or peripheral blood stem cell transplant (PBSCT) in patients with non-malignant disorders that are amenable to treatment with hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT). After transplant, subjects will be followed for late effects and for ongoing graft success.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: Prospective Post Market Clinical Follow-Up (PMCF) Study of the Zimmer® Trabecular Metal™ Total Ankle
brief_summary: The primary objective of this study is to obtain implant survivorship and clinical outcome data for commercially available Zimmer Trabecular Metal Total Ankle implants used in primary or revision total ankle arthroplasty. The assessment will include implant survivorship and clinical performance measured by pain and function, quality of life data, radiographic parameters and survivorship.

stable long-standing grade 2 neuropathy may be allowed | Blood pressure controlled (<= 140/90 mmHg) on up to 3 antihypertensive medications and able to monitor BP | Thyroid-stimulating hormone within normal limits and no symptoms of thyroid dysfunction | Able to swallow and retain oral medications; no GI illnesses precluding absorption | Age >= 18 years | Women of child-bearing potential: negative pregnancy test and agreement to use two reliable forms of contraception (timing per drug-specific requirements)
exclusion_criteria: Chemotherapy or radiotherapy within 4 weeks (6 weeks for nitrosoureas or mitomycin C) prior to starting treatment or unresolved toxicities from prior therapy > grade 1 | Hormonal therapy within 2 weeks prior to study entry (raloxifene for bone health allowed absent interactions) | Investigational agents within 4 weeks prior to study entry | Prior anti-angiogenic therapy targeting VEGF/VEGFR or angiopoietin pathways in the recurrent setting (e.g., thalidomide, bevacizumab, sunitinib, sorafenib, pazopanib, cediranib, nintedanib, trebananib); question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Open Label Study for the Use of Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors for Treatment of Cognitive Decline Due to Degenerative Dementias
brief_summary: The present study is designed as an open label study of patients with mild cognitive impairment or dementia to evaluate longer term tolerability and potential efficacy of tyrosine kinase inhibitors. Baseline and outcome measures in this study utilize validated tests that are appropriate for repeated measures which are not affected by practice effects. Advantages of this study include the fact that the neuropsychological testing instruments and advanced MRI imaging protocols that have been in ...

trial_title: Maintenance in Autologous Stem Cell Transplant for Crohn's Disease (MASCT - CD)
brief_summary: Crohn's Disease (CD) is an inflammatory bowel disease. It can lead to significant complications and discomfort in the stomach and intestines. Crohn's disease is a debilitating, incurable disease of immune cells; it affects almost 1 million people in the United States. CD is characterized by inflammation of the stomach and intestine as well as organs outside of the intestines such as the skin, eyes, and joints. Current therapies to treat CD aim to suppress the patient's immune cells but these ...

Drugs used to treat RA include non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS), glucocorticoids, and disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs), including biologics. question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A Phase 2 Study of M6620 (VX-970, Berzosertib) in Combination With Carboplatin Compared With Docetaxel in Combination With Carboplatin in Metastatic Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer
brief_summary: This phase II trial studies how well berzosertib (M6620) and carboplatin with or without docetaxel works in treating patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer that has spread to other places in the body (metastatic). M6620 may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. Drugs used in chemotherapy, such as carboplatin and docetaxel, work in different ways to stop the growth of tumor cells, either by killing the cells, by stopping them from di...

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: An Intervention to Reduce Discrepancy in Everyday Preferences
brief_summary: Dementia is a disabling, progressive major neurocognitive disorder. Although cognitive symptoms drive the diagnosis of dementia, neuropsychiatric symptoms (NPS), such as depression, agitation/aggression, and psychosis, are common and associated with a number of significant adverse outcomes. There are currently extremely limited FDA (Food and Drug Administration)-approved treatments for NPS of dementia; there remains a critical need for safe and effective interventions for NPS that can be easi...
interventions: {'id': 206280969, 'name': 'Templated, clinician-facilitated intervention to align everyday living preferences assessment', 'description': 'In step 1, persons living with dementia or cognitive impairment (PLWD/CI) will complete the PELI (hereafter, "assessment PELI-CI" for Cognitive Impairment) to articulate their preferences. In step 2, care partners will consider the preferences of PLWD/CI; care partners will complete concurrent but separate proxy PELI assessments from the perspective of the PLWD/CI (i.e., as if acting as surrogate decision-makers; hereafter "assessment PELI-CP" for Care Partner). In the Intervention (step 3), the study clinician will ask the PLWD/CI to identify up to 3 "social engagement" preferences that matter most to them. Second, in discussion with the PLWD/CI and care partner, the study clinician will review areas where there is a difference in ratings between the PELI-CI and PELI-CP. The study clinician will then ask the PLWD/CI to identify up to 3 items of disagreement that are most important for the care partner to know about. A 1-page Preferences Priorities document will then be created.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'BEHAVIORAL'}
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 55 years | Community-dwelling | Primary diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment or mild to moderate dementia | Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) > 10 | Identified care partner (family member or close friend) with contact at least three times per week | Fluent in written and oral English
exclusion_criteria: No neuropsychiatric symptoms at baseline (NPI-Q score = 0) | Living in long-term care environments (e.g., nursing home, assisted living) | Comorbid active primary psychiatric illness (e.g., major depressive disorder, bipolar disorder, psychotic disorders)
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease matches and stage/setting align (moderate dementia; age within range). MoCA >10 is required but not provided and there are no specific line/prior constraints, so only one core anchor is clearly satisfied.
patient_biomarkers: Elevated p-tau; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative
patient_inclusion_criteria: Male; Age 68 years; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated p-tau
patient_prior_therapies: (none)

trial_title: Impact of Novel Rehabilitative Approaches for Dysphagia in Patients With Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias
brief_summary: The overall purpose of this project is to develop effective dysphagia rehabilitative interventions for patients with Alzheimer's Disease and related dementias at risk for pneumonia development.
interventions: {'id': 206388222, 'name': 'Isometric tongue strengthening facilitated by Iowa Oral Performance Instrument (IOPI)', 'description': 'An air-filled pressure bulb is placed on the surface of the oral tongue and pressed against the hard palate during exercise. Each patient is given a target pressure value to aim for as determined by the baseline one repetition maximum (1RM) lingual pressures. During week one of the regimen, the target value of each repetition will be 60% of the 1RM. For the remaining seven weeks, the target value will be increased to 80% of the 1RM. At weeks three, five, and seven, the baseline will be re-measured by phone and the 80% target value re-calculated.', 'other_names': ['Tongue strengthening'], 'intervention_type': 'DEVICE'}; {'id': 206388223, 'name': 'Biotene Oral Balance Gel', 'description': 'Participants will be instructed to apply an amount equivalent to about 1 cm of Biotene® Oral Balance Gel with a finger to the tongue and most intensely affected areas of the oral cavity three times a day after brushing their teeth for 8 weeks.', 'other_names': ['Saliva substitute'], 'intervention_type': 'DEVICE'}
inclusion_criteria: Age 50–99 | Diagnosis of dementia or cognitive impairment or memory loss | Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) 0.5–2.0
exclusion_criteria: Primary vascular dementia etiology | History of head and neck cancer | Structural oropharyngeal deformity affecting swallowing | Allergy to barium | Pregnant or breastfeeding or planning pregnancy
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease matches (dementia is eligible) and stage/severity aligns with CDR 0.5–2.0 (moderate); other core anchors (prior therapy, biomarkers, metastatic pattern) are not specified. Age and sex fit and no listed exclusions apply.

patient_prior_therapies: (none)

trial_title: A Phase 1/2 Study of DZR123 (CPI-0209) in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors and Lymphomas
brief_summary: The purpose of this open-label, first-in-human (FIH) trial is to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and preliminary clinical activity of Tulmimetostat as a monotherapy in patients with advanced solid tumors and lymphomas.

history of T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma/leukemia | Active or chronic HIV, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C infection | Clinically active viral hepatitis or chronic liver disease | Any unstable or severe uncontrolled medical/psychiatric condition or significant abnormal labs increasing risk | Cohort M7: inability to remain fasted 2 hours before and 1 hour after dosing | Recent systemic anticancer therapy within 4 weeks or 5 half-lives (6 weeks for nitrosoureas/mitomycin C); question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase I Surgical Trial to Evaluate Early Immunologic Pharmacodynamic Parameters for the PD-1 Antibody Pembrolizumab With Autologous Tumor Lysate-Pulsed Dendritic Cell Vaccination in Patients With Surgically Accessible Recurrent/Progressive Glioblastoma
brief_summary: This phase I trial studies the side effects and how well of pembrolizumab and a vaccine therapy (ATL-DC vaccine) work in treating patients with glioblastoma that has come back (recurrent) and can be removed by surgery (surgically accessible). Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as pembrolizumab, may help the body's immune system attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of tumor cells to grow and spread. Vaccines, such as ATL-DC vaccine, may help the body build an effec...

inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed surgically accessible recurrent/progressive glioblastoma | First or second relapse | Undergoing clinically indicated surgery with expected ability to resect at least 2 g of tumor with low neurologic risk | MRI evidence of contrast-enhancing tumor progression per RANO within 14 days prior to randomization | Minimum tumor size 2 x 2 cm on MRI prior to surgery | At least 28 days from prior surgical resection before randomization | At least 7 days from prior stereotactic biopsy before randomization | At least 12 weeks from prior radiotherapy unless histologic confirmation of progression | At least 23 days from prior chemotherapy before randomization | At least 42 days from prior nitrosoureas before randomization | Karnofsky performance status >= 70 | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1500/µL within 14 days prior to start of study treatment | Platelets >= 100000/µL within 14 days prior to start of study treatment | Hemoglobin >= 9.0 g/dL within 14 days prior to start of study treatment without erythropoietin dependence and without PRBC transfusion within 2 weeks | Creatinine <= 1.5 x ULN or creatinine clearance >= 30 mL/min within 14 days prior to start of study treatment | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN or direct bilirubin <= ULN within 14 days prior to start of study treatment | AST <= 2.5 x ULN within 14 days prior to start of study treatment | ALT <= 2.5 x ULN within 14 days prior to start of study treatment | INR or PT <= 1.5 x ULN unless on anticoagulation with therapeutic range within 14 days prior to start of study treatment | aPTT <= 1.5 x ULN unless on anticoagulation with therapeutic range within 14 days prior to start of study treatment
exclusion_criteria: Positive pregnancy test within 72 hours prior to randomization | Prior therapy with anti-PD-1, anti-PD-L1, anti-PD-L2, or other T-cell co-inhibitory/stimulatory agents (e.g., CTLA-4, OX40, CD137) | Prior systemic anticancer therapy including investigational agents within 4 weeks prior to randomization | Not recovered from prior therapy adverse events to <= grade 1 (except <= grade 2 neuropathy) | Prior radiotherapy within 2 weeks of start of study treatment | Receipt of a live vaccine within 30 days prior to the first dose of study drug | Participation in another investigational study or use of an investigational device within 4 weeks prior to first dose | Diagnosis of immunodeficiency or chronic systemic steroid therapy > 10 mg prednisone equivalent daily or other immunosuppressive therapy within 7 days prior to first dose | Another malignancy that is progressing or requires active treatment within the past 3 years (except certain skin cancers or carcinoma in situ after curative therapy) | Tumor primarily localized to the brainstem or spinal cord | Severe hypersensitivity (>= grade 3) to pembrolizumab or its excipients | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment in the past 2 years | History of non-infectious pneumonitis requiring steroids or current pneumonitis | Active infection requiring systemic therapy | Known HIV infection | Known hepatitis B surface antigen positivity or active hepatitis C infection (HCV RNA detected) | Known active tuberculosis | Psychiatric or substance abuse disorder that would interfere with trial compliance | Pregnant or breastfeeding or planning to conceive/father children during treatment and for 120 days after last dose
prior_therapies: At least 28 days since prior surgical resection; At least 7 days since prior stereotactic biopsy; At least 12 weeks since prior radiotherapy unless histologic confirmation of progression; At least 23 days since prior chemotherapy; At least 42 days since prior nitrosoureas; At first or second relapse after initial therapy

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: An Open Label, Multicenter, Single Arm Phase II Study to Evaluate the Activity and Tolerability of the Novel mTOR Inhibitor, MLN0128 (TAK-228), in Patients With Locally Advanced or Metastatic Transitional Cell Carcinoma of the Urothelial Tract Whose Tumors Harbor a TSC1 and/or a TSC2 Mutation

Sapanisertib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth.

trial_title: Comprehensive Reverse Shoulder: Porous Augmented Glenoid Baseplate and Mini Humeral Tray Post-Market Clinical Follow-up Study
brief_summary: This study is a multicenter, prospective, non-randomized, non-controlled, dual cohort post market surveillance study. The primary objective of this study is to confirm the safety and performance of the Comprehensive Reverse Shoulder System when used with the Comprehensive Porous Augmented Glenoid Baseplate and/or Comprehensive Mini Humeral Tray in primary and revision reverse shoulder arthroplasty.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase II Trial to Evaluate Combination Therapy With Pemetrexed and Avelumab in Previously Treated Patients With MTAP-Deficient Advanced Urothelial Cancer
brief_summary: This phase II trial studies how well pemetrexed and avelumab work in treating patients with MTAP-deficient urothelial cancer that has spread to other places in the body. Pemetrexed may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as avelumab, may help the body's immune system attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of tumor cells to grow and spread. Giving pemetrexed and avelumab may work be...

He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Outcomes Mandate National Integration With Cannabis as Medicine
brief_summary: This will be a multistate, multicenter clinical study to determine the efficacy and safety of medical cannabis for a wide variety of chronic medical conditions.
interventions: {'id': 205395405, 'name': 'Cannabis, Medical', 'description': 'Patients will be given medical cannabis recommendations and certifications commensurate with the state law in which the encounter occurs. The variations in mechanisms between the states for recommending, registering, certifying, and developing mandated treatment plans or doses will be adhered to; however, variations in state law and cannabis programs should not cause variation in the study design because the end-result is still the same with patients being treated with medical cannabis.', 'other_names': ['Marijuana Medical', 'Marijuana Treatment'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205395406, 'name': 'RYAH-Medtech Inhaler', 'description': "Our research study will involve incorporation of RYAH-Medtech company's devices into our protocols. They are currently involved in clinical trials in Europe. OMNI Medical will integrate the partner with RYAH device for several reasons. Primary goals will involve using their integrated smart phone app to collect and secure large quantities of data. Secondary goals will include FDA approval as a medical device. The specific cannabis strain will be tracked using scannable QR codes programed into the smart phone app. This will allow us to track patient feedback and capture data on usage. OMNI Medical will have patients use RYAH's products as part of and FDA Investigational Device Exemption, which requires an IRB. Use of the devices would be completely voluntary by study participants.", 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DEVICE'}

trial_title: Web-based Cognitive Behavioral Treatment for Insomnia in Dementia Caregivers
brief_summary: Over the next 30 years, more than 10 million persons living with dementia in the United States will receive care at home from an unpaid and untrained family caregiver. At home care is preferred by caregivers and persons with dementia alike, but increases the caregiver's risk of insomnia and related negative health outcomes, including depression, anxiety, cognitive disturbances and poor quality of life. Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is a highly effective and established evi...

trial_title: Improving Hypertension Control for Patients With Rheumatoid Arthritis
brief_summary: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a autoimmune disease associated with an increased risk of developing coronary artery disease (CAD) and premature death,. Traditional CAD risk factors like hypertension (HTN) are both very common and poorly controlled among RA patients. Patients with RA face significant challenges in controlling HTN. The goal of this project is to identify barriers to HTN care in patients with RA to reduce CAD events.
interventions: {'id': 206177379, 'name': 'Blood pressure intervention arm', 'description': 'The intervention will focus on empowering patients to actively participate in their HTN care, facilitating patient-provider communication, and creating a cohesive care team to close the coordination loop for HTN management. brief_summary: This study seeks to improve clinical outcomes for an important, growing, and vulnerable population-nursing home residents with Alzheimer's disease or related dementias-by testing an evidence-based intervention to improve these residents' sleep. trial_title: Radical RADiotherapy and Immunotherapy for Metastatic CAncer of the Lung (RRADICAL)
brief_summary: This phase II trial studies how well radical-dose image guided radiation therapy works in treating patients with non-small cell lung cancer that has spread to other places in the body who are undergoing immunotherapy. Radiation therapy uses high energy x-rays to kill tumor cells and shrink tumors. Giving radical-dose image guided radiation therapy to patients with non-small cell lung cancer may help to improve response to immunotherapy anti-cancer treatment.

brief_summary: This phase I trial studies the side effects and best dose of memory-enriched T cells in treating patients with grade II-IV glioma that has come back (recurrent) or does not respond to treatment (refractory). exclusion_criteria: Active or uncontrolled intercurrent illness including active infections, coagulation disorders, or major cardiovascular, respiratory, or immune system illnesses | Active viral hepatitis | Left ventricular ejection fraction < 45% | History of prior adoptive cell therapies | Persistent prior therapy-related toxicities > grade 2 (except peripheral neuropathy, alopecia, vitiligo) | History of grade >= 2 diarrhea/colitis from prior immunotherapy unless asymptomatic >= 6 months or normal colonoscopy after checkpoint therapy | Primary immunodeficiency | History of organ or hematopoietic stem cell transplant | Chronic steroid therapy > 10 mg/day prednisone equivalent | Pregnant or nursing | Significant psychiatric disease precluding informed consent | Clinically significant autoimmune disease (exceptions: resolved CPI side effects, vitiligo, psoriasis, type 1 diabetes, resolved childhood asthma/atopy, hypothyroidism on replacement, Sjogren's syndrome) | Clinically significant COPD, asthma, interstitial lung disease, or other chronic lung disease | Second malignancy within 5 years (exceptions: certain skin cancers and in situ cervical cancer; thyroid cohort allows indolent cancers per investigator) | Active CNS metastases or carcinomatous meningitis (treated/stable brain metastases allowed per protocol and off steroids >= 7 days before lymphodepletion) | Receipt of live vaccine within 30 days before lymphodepletion | Hypersensitivity to components/excipients of study drugs including cyclophosphamide, mesna, fludarabine, IL-2, aminoglycosides, HSA, dextran-40, nivolumab, or ipilimumab | Any condition that significantly increases risk in the investigator's judgment
prior_therapies: Discontinue prior antitumor therapy >= 28 days before enrollment; Ovarian cancer: failed at least two prior lines of chemotherapy and platinum-resistant disease; Osteosarcoma: prior regimen including some combination of high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and/or ifosfamide; Other bone and soft tissue sarcomas: at least one prior line of therapy unless no standard first-line therapy exists; TNBC: 1-3 prior lines of systemic therapy for metastatic disease; Thyroid cancer cohort: prior neck external beam radiation allowed if separate measurable/biopsiable lesion remains; Palliative therapy during screening allowed with PI approval for non-target/non-TIL lesions
reasoning: Disease and setting (recurrent ovarian carcinoma) align, but the trial’s ovarian cohort requires platinum-resistant disease and at least two prior lines of chemotherapy; the patient has only received adjuvant carboplatin/paclitaxel/bevacizumab with no evidence of ≥2 lines or platinum resistance.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Female; Age 36 years; Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; Cytology-positive pleural effusion (recurrent disease); BRCA1 positive; Prior optimal debulking surgery; Prior adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab
patient_prior_therapies: Optimal debulking surgery; Adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab
judge_comment: No hard exclusions. Disease matches and setting (recurrent ovarian) aligns (1 anchor match). However, the ovarian cohort requires ≥2 prior lines and platinum-resistant disease; the patient has only one prior regimen, making a clear line-of-therapy mismatch (soft conflict). Platinum resistance status is unknown but not needed to trigger D. Thus D is appropriate.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: EFFORT: Efficacy of AZD1775 in Parp Resistance; A Randomized 2-Arm, Non-Comparative Phase 2 Study of AZD1775 Alone or AZD1775 and Olaparib in Women With Ovarian Cancer Who Have Progressed During PARP Inhibition
brief_summary: This phase II trial studies how well adavosertib with or without olaparib work in treating patients with ovarian, primary peritoneal, or fallopian tube cancer that has come back (recurrent). Adavosertib and olaparib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth.

PEG tube or TPN use not allowed. | Symptomatic uncontrolled brain metastases; treated/stable CNS mets allowed per protocol criteria. | Concomitant use of sensitive CYP3A4 substrates or narrow therapeutic index CYP3A4 substrates, or moderate/strong CYP3A4 inhibitors/inducers that cannot be stopped per washout requirements; aprepitant/fosaprepitant prohibited. | Use of herbal supplements that significantly modulate CYP3A activity within 7 days prior to first dose. | Known hypersensitivity to adavosertib (AZD1775), ceralasertib, or olaparib. | NYHA class >=2 cardiac disease within 6 months (unstable angina, CHF, recent MI, uncontrolled conduction abnormalities, significant arrhythmias). | History of Torsades de pointes unless all risk factors corrected; ventricular arrhythmias or recent MI not studied with AZD1775. | Baseline QTcF >=480 msec or congenital long QT syndrome. | Risk factors for QT prolongation or arrhythmia (e.g., CHF, unstable angina, recent MI, hypokalemia, family history of long QT, uncontrolled conduction abnormality). | Pregnant or breastfeeding. | Serious active infection or serious underlying medical condition that would impair treatment; known HBV, HCV, or HIV infection; need for systemic anti-infectives. | Presence of other active invasive cancers. | Myelodysplastic syndrome or acute myeloid leukemia, or features suggestive of MDS/AML. | Previous allogeneic bone marrow transplant or double umbilical cord blood transplant. | Ceralasertib arm only: concomitant strong or moderate CYP3A inhibitors (2-week washout required). | Ceralasertib arm only: concomitant strong or moderate CYP3A inducers (5-week washout for enzalutamide/phenobarbital; 3 weeks for others). | Ceralasertib arm only: concomitant CYP3A4 and/or CYP2B6 substrates with narrow therapeutic index. | Ceralasertib arm only: risk of brain perfusion problems (e.g., carotid stenosis, presyncope/syncope, TIAs). | Ceralasertib arm only: uncontrolled hypertension (>= Grade 2) requiring intervention. | Ceralasertib arm only: diagnosis of ataxia telangiectasia. | Ceralasertib arm only: other malignancy active or treated within past 3 years (except specified in protocol). | Ceralasertib arm only: unresolved toxicities from prior therapy >= Grade 2 (except alopecia, Grade 2 neuropathy). | Ceralasertib arm only: relative hypotension (<90/60 mm Hg) or clinically relevant orthostatic hypotension (>20 mm Hg fall). | Ceralasertib arm only: non–leukocyte-depleted whole blood transfusion within 120 days before genetic sample collection.

patient_inclusion_criteria: Female; Age 36 years; Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; Cytology-positive pleural effusion (recurrent disease); BRCA1 positive; Prior optimal debulking surgery; Prior adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. trial_title: Phase I/II Trial Immunotherapy With Durvalumab and Tremelimumab With Continuous or Intermittent MEK Inhibitor Selumetinib in NSCLC
brief_summary: This phase I/II trial studies the best dose of selumetinib and how well it works with durvalumab and tremelimumab in treating participants with stage IV non-small cell lung cancer or that has come back. Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as durvalumab and tremelimumab, may help the body's immune system attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of tumor cells to grow and spread. Selumetinib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for ce...

KRAS status is unknown and not an explicit exclusion here. Thus D is appropriate.

trial_title: A Phase I Dose Escalation / Dose Expansion Study of NBTXR3 Activated by Radiotherapy for Patients with Advanced Cancers Treated with an Anti-PD-1 Therapy
brief_summary: The 1100 study is an open-label, Phase I, dose escalation and expansion prospective clinical study to assess the safety of intratumoral injection of NBTXR3 activated by radiotherapy in combination with anti-PD-1 therapy.

prior_therapies: Prior anti-PD-1 therapy allowed; participants may be anti-PD-1 naive or have primary/secondary resistance per cohort; Expansion Cohorts 1 and 3 require prior anti-PD-1 primary or secondary resistance; Expansion Cohort 2 requires anti-PD-1 naive; Washout: no prior checkpoint inhibitor within 2 weeks before NBTXR3 injection; Washout: no prior systemic anti-neoplastic therapy (including investigational agents) within 4 weeks before NBTXR3 injection; Prior radiation allowed; injectable lesion may be in a previously irradiated field for specified HNSCC cohorts
reasoning: Disease and stage match NSCLC (metastatic), and anti–PD-1–naïve status is compatible with allowed cohorts. However, the trial excludes patients with extensive metastatic burden (>5 lesions); the patient has bone and liver metastases with a recent MRI showing numerous lesions, suggesting a lesion count likely exceeding the protocol limit, and the presence of an injection-amenable lesion is uncertain.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; ECOG 0; De novo metastatic disease; Metastases to bone and liver; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years with complete response; Recent MRI shows numerous lesions; No past medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Osimertinib
judge_comment: Disease and stage match (metastatic NSCLC), and prior anti–PD-1 status is compatible with allowed cohorts—thus ≥2 core anchors match. The trial’s >5-lesion exclusion cannot be applied without a confirmed count; “numerous lesions” is ambiguous and should not be inferred into a mismatch per rubric. Uncertainty about an injection-amenable lesion is unknown, not a soft conflict. Therefore, absent a clear soft mismatch or hard exclusion, the grade should be A, not D.

trial_title: PROMISE-005: A Phase II Randomized Study Assessing the Efficacy of Stereotactic Body Radiotherapy (SBRT) in Patients With Oligometastatic Breast or Lung Cancer
brief_summary: This study is being done to determine if stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) when delivered to all sites of disease in participants with 1-5 metastases will increase the length of time before participants' disease gets worse.
interventions: {'id': 206605534, 'name': 'Stereotactic Body Radiotherapy/SBRT', 'description': 'Radiation to each metastatic site should be delivered to a minimum dose of 30 Gy in 5 fractions (BED of 48 Gy10). The exact dose of radiotherapy will be determined by the treating radiation oncologist. Preferred regimens for lung metastases include 50 Gy in five fractions, 48 Gy in four fractions, or 54 Gy in three fractions, although lower doses may be employed to respect dose limits to critical structures such as the esophagus. Recommended SBRT dosing for other sites includes 27 to 30 Gy in three fractions or 24 Gy in one fraction for bone metastases.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'RADIATION'}; {'id': 206605535, 'name': 'Systemic Therapy/Standard of Care', 'description': 'Standard of care systemic therapy, including chemotherapeutics, targeted therapies, immunomodulatory agents, and hormonal therapies will be delivered at the discretion of the treating oncologist. If the treating physicians recommend discontinuing systemic therapy during SBRT, general guidelines for stopping and reinitiating systemic regimen are as follows: Hormonal therapies and immunotherapy can be continued during SBRT. Consideration can be given to holding cytotoxic chemotherapy beginning 3 to 7 days prior to the initiation of SBRT until 3 to 7 days after the completion of SBRT. Similarly, consideration can be given to holding biologic agents during SBRT and for 0 to 3 days before and after.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}

reasoning: Disease, age, and ECOG match, but the trial requires oligometastatic disease (≤5 SBRT-amenable lesions) while the patient has numerous lesions, which is a mismatch. Additionally, for EGFR-mutant NSCLC the trial requires documented progression on first-line TKI, which is not clearly established.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; ECOG 0; De novo metastatic disease; Metastases to bone and liver; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years with complete response; Recent MRI shows numerous lesions; No past medical issues

judge_comment: The trial explicitly requires an oligometastatic state with ≤5 SBRT-amenable lesions. The patient’s “numerous lesions” definitively fails this required setting, which constitutes a hard exclusion per the rubric. The EGFR-TKI progression requirement is unclear and should not trigger F, but the oligometastatic requirement alone does. Therefore, the correct grade is F, not D.

exclusion_criteria: Inability to swallow oral medications or significant gastrointestinal disorder that may alter drug absorption | Risk factors for torsade de pointes including uncontrolled heart failure, severe hypokalemia (potassium < 3 mM/L), history of long QT syndrome, or requirement for concomitant QT-prolonging medications | Requirement for strong CYP3A4/5 agonists or inhibitors during study participation | Uncontrolled or severe intercurrent medical condition including uncontrolled brain metastases (stable treated or untreated brain metastases allowed under specified conditions) | Major surgery within 4 weeks before first dose | Receipt of cancer-directed therapy or investigational agent within 2 weeks (6 weeks for mitomycin C or nitrosoureas) or 5 half-lives, whichever is shorter, before first dose; unresolved toxicities > Grade 1 except specified | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Serious active infection requiring intravenous antibiotics | Known HIV infection or active hepatitis B or C infection | Important medical illness or abnormal laboratory finding increasing risk in the investigator's opinion | Prior or concurrent malignancy that may interfere with safety or efficacy assessment | History of clinically significant dry eye or other corneal abnormality, or contact lens wearer unwilling to abstain from use during treatment | Known allergy or hypersensitivity to components of TVB-2640 | Prior history of hypersensitivity, drug- or radiation-induced, or other immune-mediated pneumonitis
prior_therapies: Prior platinum doublet chemotherapy required; Prior immune checkpoint inhibitor required unless contraindicated; If EGFR mutation or ALK rearrangement present, prior appropriate targeted therapy with progression required; Washout: No systemic anticancer therapy or investigational agent within 2 weeks (6 weeks for mitomycin C or nitrosoureas) or 5 half-lives, whichever is shorter; prior toxicities recovered to < Grade 1
reasoning: Stage and NSCLC diagnosis match, but the trial requires documented KRAS-mutant NSCLC and prior platinum doublet chemotherapy plus an immune checkpoint inhibitor; this patient has EGFR exon 19–mutant disease and has only received osimertinib.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; ECOG 0; De novo metastatic disease; Metastases to bone and liver; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years with complete response; Recent MRI shows numerous lesions; No past medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Osimertinib
judge_comment: No hard exclusion applies because KRAS status is not definitively known (cannot infer KRAS-wildtype from EGFR+ per rubric). Disease and metastatic setting match, but there are clear soft mismatches: trial requires KRAS-mutant NSCLC and prior platinum doublet plus immune checkpoint inhibitor, while the patient has EGFR-mutant disease and only prior osimertinib. Thus D is appropriate.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase 0/I Dose Escalation Study of Mycophenolate Mofetil Combined With Radiation Therapy in Glioblastoma
brief_summary: This is a phase 0/1 dose-escalation trial to determine the maximum tolerated dose of Mycophenolate Mofetil (MMF) when administered with radiation, in patients with glioblastoma or gliosarcoma.
interventions: {'id': 206018706, 'name': 'Mycophenolate Mofetil', 'description': '500-2000mg orally twice daily, one week prior to re-resection (2 participants at each of 4 dose levels: 500mg, 1000mg, 1500mg and 2000mg)', 'other_names': ['MMF'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206018707, 'name': 'Radiation Therapy', 'description': '40.5 Gy in 15 fractions', 'other_names': ['RT'], 'intervention_type': 'RADIATION'}; {'id': 206018708, 'name': 'Re-resection (as part of standard of care)', 'description': 'Re-resection or biopsy of tumor as part of standard of care', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'PROCEDURE'}; {'id': 206018709, 'name': 'Temozolomide', 'description': 'Temozolomide capsules are an approved oral chemotherapeutic drug for the treatment of adult patients with newly diagnosed GBM/GS concomitantly with radiotherapy and then as adjuvant treatment. inclusion_criteria: Glioblastoma or gliosarcoma (recurrent or newly diagnosed) | Karnofsky Performance Status >= 60% | Phase 0: Candidate for clinically indicated re-resection or biopsy | Phase 1, Recurrent: Candidate for clinically indicated re-irradiation | Phase 1, Recurrent: No more than one prior course of radiation for GBM | Phase 1, Newly Diagnosed: Candidate for upfront standard-of-care chemoradiation | ANC >= 1,500 /µL
exclusion_criteria: No histopathological diagnosis of the tumor | Gliomatosis cerebri pattern (involvement of 3 or more lobes) | Leptomeningeal disease | Use of bevacizumab within 8 weeks of enrollment | Known history of HIV | Active hepatitis B infection | Active hepatitis C infection | Active systemic infection | Active central nervous system infection | Grade 4 lymphopenia | Creatinine clearance < 25 mL/min | History of organ transplantation | Known hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase deficiency | Serious intercurrent disease | Allergic reaction or hypersensitivity to mycophenolate mofetil or mycophenolic acid | Medical contraindication to mycophenolate mofetil per treating physician | Known immunosuppressive condition from autoimmune disease, immune deficiency syndrome, or chronic immunosuppressive therapy | Inability to undergo brain MRI with and without contrast | Pregnant or lactating | Known phenylketonuria | Phase 0: Biopsy patients unlikely to have sufficient tissue to spare for research | Phase 1: Increase in steroid requirement within 7 days of enrollment | Phase 1, Recurrent: Radiation within 6 months prior to enrollment | Phase 1, Recurrent: Surgery within 4 weeks of planned re-irradiation | Phase 1, Newly Diagnosed: History of hypersensitivity to temozolomide or dacarbazine | Phase 1, Newly Diagnosed: Prior chemotherapy or radiation therapy for glioblastoma or gliosarcoma

Eligibility for the Phase 0 surgical cohort is unknown.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Recurrent glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; ECOG 1; Age 40; Male; Prior gross total resection; Completed adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Completed adjuvant temozolomide; Recurrence three months after completing adjuvant therapy; No other medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Prior gross total resection; Prior radiation therapy with concurrent temozolomide; Prior adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: No hard exclusion is established. The grader misread the timeline (recurrence was 3 months after adjuvant temozolomide, not after radiation), so the “radiation within 6 months” conflict is unknown, not a soft mismatch. Disease and recurrent setting match; other anchors (line/prior specifics like re-irradiation candidacy and 6‑month RT interval) are unknown. With exactly one confirmed anchor and no soft conflicts, the correct grade is B.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: Pilot Trial of Nivolumab Plus Cabozantinib for Advanced Solid Tumors in Patients With HIV Infection
brief_summary: This phase I trial investigates the side effects of cabozantinib and nivolumab in treating patients with cancer that may have spread from where it first started to nearby tissue, lymph nodes, or distant parts of the body (advanced) and who are undergoing treatment for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Cabozantinib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as nivolumab, may help the body's immune ...

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: Duration of Immune Checkpoint Therapy in Locally Advanced or Metastatic Urothelial Carcinoma: a Randomized Phase 3 Non-Inferiority Trial (IMAGINE)
brief_summary: This phase III trial compares survival in urothelial cancer patients who stop immune checkpoint inhibitor treatment after being treated for about a year to those patients who continue treatment with immune checkpoint inhibitors. Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as avelumab, durvalumab, pembrolizumab, atezolizumab, and nivolumab, may help the body's immune system attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of tumor cells to grow and spread. Stopping immune checkpoint in...
interventions: {'id': 205962726, 'name': 'Pembrolizumab', 'description': 'Given IV', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205962727, 'name': 'Nivolumab', 'description': 'Given IV', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205962728, 'name': 'Atezolizumab', 'description': 'Given IV', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205962729, 'name': 'Durvalumab', 'description': 'Given IV', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205962730, 'name': 'Avelumab', 'description': 'Given IV', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}

exclusion_criteria: Progressive disease by RECIST 1.1 after 12–15 months of ICI | Toxicity from ICI therapy that makes continuation clinically unacceptable | History of tuberculosis | Active hepatitis B infection | Active hepatitis C infection | Uncontrolled HIV infection | History of allogeneic organ transplantation | Current systemic immunosuppressive medication > 10 mg/day prednisone equivalent | Another primary malignancy with active disease, except malignancy treated with curative intent and no active disease for >= 2 years, or adequately treated non-melanoma skin cancer or carcinoma in situ | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Patients of reproductive potential unwilling to use effective contraception
prior_therapies: At least one cycle of FDA-approved PD-1/L1 ICI-containing standard-of-care therapy; Completed 12–15 months of PD-1/L1 ICI with CR/PR/SD at registration
reasoning: Disease/setting matches metastatic urothelial carcinoma, but the trial requires patients with CR/PR/SD after 12–15 months of ongoing PD-1/L1 therapy; this patient has progressed after second-line therapy and there’s no evidence of 12–15 months non-progression on ICI, creating a line/prior-exposure mismatch.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progression after second-line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab; Bone and liver metastases; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD; Age 55 years; Male sex

However, the trial requires 12–15 months of ongoing PD-1/L1 therapy with CR/PR/SD, which the patient clearly lacks due to progression after second-line therapy. This is a clear soft mismatch on line/prior-exposure, so D is appropriate.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: NiteCAPP: Web-based Interventions for Insomnia in Rural Dementia Caregivers: Examination of Sleep, Arousal, Mood, Cognitive, and Immune Outcomes
brief_summary: The goal of this project evaluate the efficacy of NiteCAPP in improving insomnia in a rural dementia caregiver sample (n of 100 caregiver and PWD dyads). We will measure both the short term (post-treatment) and long term (6 and 12 months) effects of the intervention on CG sleep, arousal, inflammation, health, mood, burden and cognitive function, and PWD sleep.
interventions: {'id': 206503744, 'name': 'NiteCAPP CARES', 'description': 'Web-based intervention that will include 4 weekly sessions and 4 bimonthly boosters. Each session is to be completed individually by CG (with PWD to extent able) in a single sitting (less than 45 mins). Each session should be completed in 7 days with next session released only after prior one completed. Session 1 focuses on sleep education, sleep hygiene, and stimulus control. Session 2 focuses on sleep compression, relaxation, and problem solving. Session 3 focuses on coping and stress management and cognitive therapy. Session 4 focuses on a review of skills and plan for maintenance of behavior change.', 'other_names': ['Web CBT-I'], 'intervention_type': 'BEHAVIORAL'}; {'id': 206503745, 'name': 'NiteCAPP SHARES', 'description': 'Web-based intervention that will include 4 weekly sessions and 4 bimonthly boosters. Each session is to be completed individually by CG (with PWD to extent able) in a single sitting (less than 45 mins). Each session should be completed in 7 days with next session released only after prior one completed. Session 1 focuses on expanded sleep education and sleep hygiene. Session 2 focuses insomnia education and sleep hygiene support. Session 3 focuses on targeted sleep education and sleep in dementia. Session 4 focuses on a review of skills and plan for maintenance of behavior change. Boosters review skills, encourage practice, and troubleshoot issues.', 'other_names': ['Web Sleep Hygiene and Related Education (Web-SHARE)'], 'intervention_type': 'BEHAVIORAL'}
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years (caregiver) | Insomnia diagnosis (caregiver) | Insomnia duration >= 6 months (caregiver) | Adequate opportunity and circumstances for sleep (caregiver) | Insomnia symptoms: difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or early morning awakening (>=1) (caregiver) | Daytime dysfunction due to insomnia (caregiver) | Baseline sleep diary: sleep onset latency or wake after sleep onset > 30 minutes on >= 3 nights (caregiver) | Probable/possible Alzheimer's disease (person with dementia) | Nighttime Behavior Inventory: >=1 problem on >= 3 nights/week (person with dementia) | Sleep Apnea questionnaire score < 32 (person with dementia)
exclusion_criteria: Cognitive impairment: Telephone Interview for Cognitive Status (TICS) < 25 (caregiver) | Sleep disorder other than insomnia, including sleep apnea (AHI > 15) (caregiver) | Bipolar disorder (caregiver) | Seizure disorder (caregiver) | Major psychopathology except depression or anxiety (e.g., suicidal, psychotic) (caregiver) | Severe untreated psychiatric comorbidity (caregiver) | Use of psychotropic or other medications that alter sleep (e.g., beta-blockers) (caregiver) | Non-pharmacological treatment for sleep or mood outside the trial (caregiver)
prior_therapies: No prescribed or over-the-counter sleep medications for >= 1 month or stable dose for >= 6 months (caregiver); No sleep medications for >= 1 month or stable dose for >= 6 months (person with dementia)
reasoning: Age/sex and dementia status align, and no conflicting prior therapies are noted, but the trial requires the person with dementia to have probable/possible Alzheimer’s disease and to be part of a caregiver-insomnia dyad. The patient’s amyloid-negative profile suggests non-AD and there is no evidence of the required caregiver/insomnia criteria, making this a likely subtype/setting mismatch rather than a definitive exclusion.
patient_biomarkers: Elevated p-tau; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative
patient_inclusion_criteria: Male; Age 68 years; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated p-tau
patient_prior_therapies: (none)
judge_comment: No hard exclusion applies: disease includes dementia, age/sex OK, and required AD subtype/caregiver status are not definitively contradicted. However, there is a specific soft mismatch: trial requires probable/possible AD while patient is amyloid-negative (implied biomarker miss) and the setting targets caregiver–insomnia dyads, which the patient likely does not meet. This fits a D under the rubric.

trial_title: Phase I/II First-in-Human Study of TT-10 (PORT-6), an Adenosine 2A Receptor Antagonist, and PORT-7, an Adenosine 2B Receptor Antagonist, as Single Agents and in Combination in Participants With Advanced Selected Solid Tumors

To determine the maximum tolerated dose or the recommended phase 2 dose of TT-10, TT-4 and TT-10 + TT-4, (Dual Blockade) 3. To obtain a preliminary estimate...
