judge_comment: No hard exclusions apply. Disease and stage match, but the CRPC cohort requires prior taxane-based chemotherapy in addition to second-generation hormonal therapy, which the patient lacks—this is a clear soft mismatch on the Line/prior anchor, yielding D per rubric.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Coaching Dementia Caregivers to Master Care-Resistant Behavior and Improve Coping Strategies
brief_summary: 266 family caregivers will be randomly assigned to either immediate intervention or delayed intervention groups. All caregivers will complete baseline surveys and 3 weeks of daily diaries. The immediate intervention group will receive 12 weeks of CuRB-IT. They will complete 3 rounds of 3-week daily diaries followed by an intermittent survey at 12 week intervals for the next 33 weeks. The delayed intervention group will receive 12 weeks of attention, complete 1 round of 3-week daily diaries fo...
interventions: {'id': 206065737, 'name': 'CuRB-IT', 'description': '9 1-hour coaching sessions delivered over a videoconferencing platform (Zoom); 6 delivered weekly, 3 delivered biweekly', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'BEHAVIORAL'}
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Provides unpaid caregiving | Care recipient is spouse/partner, sibling, parent, or grandparent (including in-law) aged >= 60 years | Lives with or shares cooking facilities with the care recipient | Care recipient has mild cognitive impairment or dementia per Quick Dementia Rating System | Provides help with >= 2 instrumental activities of daily living or >= 1 activity of daily living | Care recipient is resistant to assistance with at least one instrumental or activity of daily living
exclusion_criteria: Unable to speak/read English | No reliable access to a smartphone or internet
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease area aligns (dementia), but the trial enrolls unpaid caregivers of persons with dementia. The patient is the care recipient, not a caregiver, creating a clear setting/inclusion mismatch.
patient_biomarkers: Elevated p-tau; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative
patient_inclusion_criteria: Male; Age 68 years; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated p-tau
patient_prior_therapies: (none)
judge_comment: The trial explicitly requires the participant to be an unpaid caregiver; the patient is the care recipient. This is a required setting/role the patient definitively lacks, which per HARD EXCLUSIONS (“Required biomarker/subtype/stage/setting mismatch”) should trigger an F. The grader correctly identified the mismatch but misclassified it as a soft mismatch (D) instead of a hard exclusion.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 1 Clinical Study of NXP800 in Subjects With Advanced Cancers and Expansion in Subjects With Ovarian Cancer
brief_summary: The purpose of the dose escalation phase is to evaluate the safety profile of escalating doses and dose schedules of NXP800. In the expansion phase the preliminary efficacy in subjects with ARID1a mutated ovarian clear cell and ovarian endometrioid cancers will be estimated.
interventions: {'id': 206418506, 'name': 'NXP800', 'description': 'NXP800 is an anti-neoplastic, oral small molecule.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
diseases_targeted: Solid Tumor; Ovarian Clear Cell Carcinoma; Ovarian Endometrioid Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Life expectancy >= 12 weeks | Histologically or cytologically confirmed advanced/metastatic/progressive solid tumor with no effective therapy available or appropriate (Part A) | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | ECOG performance status <=2 (Part A) | ARID1A-mutated clear cell ovarian carcinoma (>=50% clear cell, no serous differentiation) or endometrioid ovarian carcinoma (Part B) | Disease progression within 6 months after completion of platinum-based therapy (Part B) | If BRCA mutation present, prior treatment with a PARP inhibitor required (Part B) | 1 to 3 prior systemic lines of therapy, including at least one line containing bevacizumab (Part B) | ECOG performance status 0–1 (Part B)
exclusion_criteria: Radiotherapy, endocrine therapy, chemotherapy, or investigational agent within 28 days (42 days for nitrosoureas or mitomycin-C) before first dose | Ongoing toxicities from prior therapy > Grade 2 (except alopecia in Part B) | Active/progressive brain metastases; treated brain metastases must be stable for >= 28 days (Part A) or >= 12 weeks off corticosteroids (Part B) | Pregnancy or lactation
prior_therapies: Washout >= 28 days for radiotherapy, endocrine therapy, chemotherapy, or investigational agents (>= 42 days for nitrosoureas or mitomycin-C) before first dose; May continue bisphosphonates for bone metastases; May continue GnRH agonists for prostate cancer; Progression within 6 months after completion of platinum-based therapy required (Part B); At least 1 and no more than 3 prior systemic lines required (Part B); Prior bevacizumab-containing line required (Part B); If BRCA mutation, prior PARP inhibitor required (Part B)
reasoning: Disease and advanced/recurrent setting match, but the ovarian expansion cohort (Part B) requires prior PARP inhibitor use for BRCA-mutated patients (not given here) and ARID1A mutation (status unknown). The solid-tumor dose-escalation (Part A) requires no effective therapy available, yet given BRCA1 positivity and no prior PARP, a standard PARP therapy is available, making eligibility likely mismatched.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Female; Age 36 years; Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; Cytology-positive pleural effusion (recurrent disease); BRCA1 positive; Prior optimal debulking surgery; Prior adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab
patient_prior_therapies: Optimal debulking surgery; Adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab
judge_comment: No hard exclusions. Disease matches and setting is advanced/recurrent. However, Part B requires prior PARP use for BRCA-mutated patients (patient lacks this), creating a clear line/prior-exposure mismatch; ARID1A requirement is unknown (not an F). Part A’s ‘no effective therapy available’ likely not met given BRCA1 with available PARP therapy. Thus a specific soft mismatch → D.

This Phase III trial builds on the efficacy and safety data reported in the previous Phase I...

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Pilot Trial of Spectroscopic MRI-guided, Dose-Escalated Proton Radiation Therapy and Bevacizumab for Recurrent Glioblastoma
brief_summary: The purpose of this research is to find hidden cancer with an experimental magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan called spectroscopic magnetic resonance imaging (sMRI). That spectroscopic MRI scan will be used to increase the area of the brain receiving radiation and then the dose of radiation in attempt to kill more of the cancer. Proton radiotherapy and bevacizumab (Avastin) are used to minimize the possible side effects of this approach.
interventions: {'id': 206024059, 'name': 'Intensity Modulated Proton Therapy (IMPT)', 'description': 'Participants will receive radiation therapy delivered via intensity modulated proton therapy (IMPT) simultaneous integrated boost technique over a period of 10 days, 5 days per week for approximately 2 weeks.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'RADIATION'}; {'id': 206024060, 'name': 'Bevacizumab', 'description': 'Bevacizumab will be administered intravenously (IV), beginning at a dose of 10 mg/kg every 2-3 weeks until disease progression.', 'other_names': ['Avastin'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Recurrent glioblastoma or variants (e.g., gliosarcoma) confirmed by MRI outside initial high-dose RT field, biopsy/resection, or advanced imaging (PET, perfusion MRI, MR spectroscopy). | Pathologic diagnosis of glioblastoma (or gliosarcoma) by 2021 WHO criteria (initial and/or re-resection; reclassification allowed). | Total enhancing recurrence on T1 post-contrast MRI with maximum linear measurement <= 6 cm. | Prior brain radiation therapy for glioma with conventional fractionation (1.8–2 Gy/fraction), total dose <= 63 Gy. | Elapsed time from prior brain radiation: >= 4 months for marginal/out-of-field failures; >= 6 months for in-field failures. | Washout from prior agents before study treatment: >= 28 days or 5 half-lives (whichever shorter) for experimental agents; >= 28 days for cytotoxics (>= 14 days for vincristine; >= 21 days for procarbazine and temozolomide). | Age >= 18 years. | Able to undergo MRI scans. | Life expectancy > 12 weeks. | ECOG performance status 0-2. | ANC >= 1500/µL. | Platelets >= 75000/µL. | Hemoglobin >= 9.0 g/dL (transfusion allowed). | Total bilirubin <= 2 mg/dL. | AST (SGOT) <= 2.5 x ULN. | Serum creatinine <= 1.8 mg/dL. | Urine protein/creatinine ratio < 1.0 or urine dipstick protein <= 2+ (if >2+, require UPC < 1.0 or 24-hour urine protein <= 1 g). | If on full-dose anticoagulation: no active high-risk bleeding condition and stable in-range INR (typically 2–3) or stable LMWH.
exclusion_criteria: Brain malignancies other than glioblastoma or variants by 2021 WHO (benign lesions like meningioma allowed). | Glioma without prior standard first-line therapies including an initial course of radiation therapy. | History of a second course of brain radiation therapy. | Multifocal disease across multiple brain lobes (multiple nodules in same region allowed if total linear diameter <= 6 cm). | Prior treatment with bevacizumab. | Concurrent chemotherapy with study therapy other than bevacizumab. | Recurrent glioblastoma located in regions with known sMRI artifact: temporal lobe below floor of third ventricle, orbitofrontal cortex, prefrontal cortex, medial frontal gyrus, brainstem, or cerebellum. | Pregnant or breastfeeding. | Prior invasive malignancy (except non-melanoma skin cancer) unless disease-free >= 1 year (non-invasive tumors allowed). | Unstable angina or CHF requiring hospitalization within 6 months. | Transmural myocardial infarction within 6 months. | Stroke or TIA within 6 months. | Significant vascular disease or clinically significant peripheral vascular disease. | Acute bacterial or fungal infection requiring IV antibiotics at registration. | COPD exacerbation or other respiratory illness requiring hospitalization or precluding therapy at registration. | Hepatic insufficiency with clinical jaundice and/or coagulation defects. | AIDS (per CDC definition). | Unwilling/unable to use acceptable contraception if of childbearing potential and sexually active. | Allergic reaction to bevacizumab. | History of hypertensive crisis or hypertensive encephalopathy. | Non-healing wound, ulcer, or bone fracture within 90 days. | CTCAE v4 grade >= 3 hemorrhage within 30 days. | Major surgery, open biopsy, or significant traumatic injury within 28 days (except craniotomy). | Concurrent investigational agents.
prior_therapies: Prior standard first-line therapy for glioma including a first course of brain radiation (conventional fractionation 1.8–2 Gy/fx, total dose <= 63 Gy) required.; Interval from prior brain radiation: >= 4 months (marginal/out-of-field failures) or >= 6 months (in-field failures) before study treatment.; Washout prior to study: >= 28 days or 5 half-lives from experimental agents; >= 28 days from cytotoxic agents (>= 14 days from vincristine; >= 21 days from procarbazine and temozolomide).
reasoning: Disease and setting match (recurrent glioblastoma; age 40; ECOG 1), but the trial requires ≥4–6 months since prior brain radiation before study treatment, and the patient recurred 3 months after completing adjuvant chemoradiation, making timing a likely mismatch.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Recurrent glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; ECOG 1; Age 40; Male; Prior gross total resection; Completed adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Completed adjuvant temozolomide; Recurrence three months after completing adjuvant therapy; No other medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Prior gross total resection; Prior radiation therapy with concurrent temozolomide; Prior adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: No hard exclusion is triggered. Disease and setting match; prior standard therapy aligns and no prior bevacizumab. The grader’s cited timing issue is inferred and misread: “3 months after completing adjuvant therapy” is not the interval from last radiation to study start. Time-from-RT requirement is unknown and should be neutral, not a soft mismatch. With ≥2 core anchors matching (stage/setting and line/prior), the correct grade is A.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. trial_title: A Phase 1b Study of Serabelisib in Combination with an Insulin Suppressing Diet (Study ISD) and with or Without Nab-paclitaxel in Adult Subjects with Advanced Solid Tumors with PIK3CA Mutations with or Without PTEN Loss
brief_summary: This study will evaluate the feasibility of optimizing the safety and tolerability of serabelisib (an investigational PI3K inhibitor) when combined with an ISD and with or without nab-paclitaxel with a goal of reducing side effects and enhancing anticancer activity.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 2 Study to Evaluate the Triplet Combination of Pemetrexed Plus AB928 (Etrumadenant) + AB122 (Zimberelimab) in Patients With Previously Treated Advanced or Metastatic MTAP Deficient Urothelial Carcinoma
brief_summary: This is a Phase 2 open-label, single-arm trial for patients with MTAP-deficient advanced urothelial cancer who had received prior immunotherapy. This is a single site study at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center. This study will allow patients in second line of treatment for advanced urothelial ca or beyond. All patients must have been previously treated with immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) therapy as per current standard of care.
interventions: {'id': 206136741, 'name': 'Pemetrexed', 'description': 'Given by vein (IV)', 'other_names': ['LY23151', 'Alimta®', 'MTA', 'Multitargeted Antifolate', 'NSC-698037'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206136742, 'name': 'Zimberelimab', 'description': 'Given by vein (IV)', 'other_names': ['AB122'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206136743, 'name': 'Etrumadenant', 'description': 'Given by PO', 'other_names': ['AB928', 'Etruma'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}

previously treated brain metastases allowed only if stable >= 4 weeks and no ongoing steroids | Another malignancy within 2 years, except non-melanoma skin cancer, controlled localized prostate cancer, controlled papillary thyroid carcinoma, or in situ carcinoma | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Uncontrolled large third-space fluid (e.g., pleural or peritoneal effusion) not amenable to drainage | Active inflammatory bowel disease | Active autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, systemic sclerosis, systemic lupus erythematosus, or autoimmune vasculitis | Systemic corticosteroids > 10 mg prednisone equivalents daily or other immunosuppressive medications within 14 days (except allowed uses) | History of primary immunodeficiency | Prior organ transplantation, including allogeneic stem-cell transplant | Live vaccines within 4 weeks prior to first dose and while on trial (COVID-19 vaccines allowed) | Active hepatitis A, B, or C | Known HIV infection or AIDS | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness (e.g., active infection, current pneumonitis, symptomatic congestive heart failure, unstable angina, symptomatic arrhythmia, interstitial lung disease) | Uncontrolled psychiatric illness or social situations limiting compliance | Known allergy or hypersensitivity to study drug formulations | Major surgery within 28 days prior to first dose or not fully recovered | Current dialysis | Prior checkpoint inhibitor therapy discontinued due to grade 4 toxicity | Prior antifolate therapy in neoadjuvant or metastatic setting

patient_inclusion_criteria: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progression after second-line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab; Bone and liver metastases; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD; Age 55 years; Male sex

Disease, metastatic setting, and line/prior-exposure (post–PD-1) all match; required biomarker (MTAP) is unknown, which should be treated as neutral, not a soft mismatch. Renal function does not fall under the core anchors and is not listed as a hard exclusion. With ≥2 core anchors matching and no core-anchor soft mismatch, the correct grade is A.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Effect Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) in the Treatment of Anxiety and Depression in Patients With Inflammatory Bowel Disease

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: An Open-Label, Phase 1/2, Safety, Pharmacokinetic and Proof-of-Concept Study of ARN-509 in Patients With Progressive Advanced Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer
brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to assess the safety and activity of ARN-509 in men with advanced castration resistant prostate cancer. Patients will first be enrolled into Phase 1 of the study to identify a tolerable dose for the Phase 2 portion of the study. In the Phase 2, 3 different cohorts of patients will be enrolled to evaluate the safety and activity of ARN-509.
interventions: {'id': 206631394, 'name': 'ARN-509 (Phase 1)', 'description': 'ARN-509 will be administered at a starting dose of 30 milligram per day (mg/day), with escalations to 60 mg, 90 mg, 120 mg, 180 mg, 240 mg, 300 mg, 390 mg, and 480 mg daily.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206631395, 'name': 'ARN-509 (Phase 2)', 'description': 'ARN-509 will be administered at Maximum Tolerated Dose (MTD) and/or Recommended Phase 2 Dose (RP2D), determined in Phase 1.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed prostate cancer | Non-metastatic CRPC with PSA >= 8 ng/mL (within 3 months) | Non-metastatic CRPC with PSA doubling time <= 10 months | Progressive metastatic CRPC by PSA progression | Progressive metastatic CRPC by radiographic progression | Ongoing androgen deprivation therapy with a GnRH analog/inhibitor or orchiectomy | Serum testosterone <= 50 ng/dL | ECOG 0-1 | Life expectancy >= 3 months | Prior abiraterone therapy >= 6 months before progression (post-abiraterone cohort)
exclusion_criteria: Distant metastases including CNS, vertebral, or meningeal involvement (for non-metastatic cohort) | Brain metastases or untreated spinal cord compression | Prior treatment with enzalutamide (MDV3100) | Prior treatment with abiraterone | Prior treatment with ketoconazole | Concurrent treatment with medications known to have seizure potential | Concurrent corticosteroids (must taper off as soon as possible if already on) | QTc > 450 msec | History of seizure or condition predisposing to seizure | Severe or uncontrolled systemic disease | HIV infection
prior_therapies: Ongoing androgen deprivation therapy required; Prior abiraterone therapy >= 6 months required for post-abiraterone cohort
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with prior treatment with enzalutamide (MDV3100), which this patient received. All other factors aside, this hard exclusion renders the patient ineligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Male sex; Age 66 years; Castration-resistant prostate cancer; Metastatic disease; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Androgen deprivation therapy (leuprolide); Abiraterone (Zytiga); Enzalutamide (progression on)
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes prior enzalutamide (MDV3100). The patient has progressed on enzalutamide, triggering a hard exclusion. Other factors (disease, age, sex) align, but the explicit exclusion mandates grade F per rubric.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: A Randomized Phase II/III Study of Azacitidine in Combination With Lenalidomide (NSC-703813) vs. Azacitidine Alone vs. Azacitidine in Combination With Vorinostat (NSC-701852) for Higher-Risk Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS) and Chronic Myelomonocytic Leukemia (CMML)
brief_summary: This randomized phase II/III trial studies how well azacitidine works with or without lenalidomide or vorinostat in treating patients with higher-risk myelodysplastic syndromes or chronic myelomonocytic leukemia. Drugs used in chemotherapy, such as azacitidine, work in different ways to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells, stopping them from dividing, or by stopping them from spreading. Lenalidomide may stop the growth of cancer cells by stopping blood flow to the can...

diseases_targeted: Myelodysplastic Syndrome; Myelodysplastic Syndrome With Excess Blasts; Myelodysplastic Syndrome With Excess Blasts-1; Chronic Myelomonocytic Leukemia; Chronic Myelomonocytic Leukemia-1; Chronic Myelomonocytic Leukemia-2
inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) meeting FAB RAEB (5-20% marrow blasts) or WHO RAEB-1 (5-9% marrow blasts) or RAEB-2 (10-19% marrow blasts and/or 5-19% blood blasts) | Diagnosis of chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) meeting FAB criteria (10-19% marrow blasts and/or 5-19% blood blasts) or WHO CMML-1 (<10% marrow blasts and/or <5% blood blasts) or CMML-2 (10-19% marrow blasts and/or 5-19% blood blasts) | IPSS risk intermediate-2 (1.5-2.0 points) or high (>= 2.5 points); intermediate-1 (0.5-1.0 points) allowed only if >= 5% myeloblasts | Baseline disease assessment specimens obtained within 30 days prior to registration | Zubrod performance status 0-2 | Females of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy test within 10-14 days prior to registration; if assigned lenalidomide, second test within 24 hours prior to cycle 1 and adherence to dual contraception; men agree to condom use with FCBP | Pretreatment cytogenetics required within 30 days prior to registration per cooperative group specifications
exclusion_criteria: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) | Prior treatment with lenalidomide, azacitidine, vorinostat, or decitabine | Prior radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or other cytotoxic therapy for conditions other than MDS within 12 months | Prior allogeneic stem cell or bone marrow transplantation (autologous transplant permitted) | Use of histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor agents for anticancer treatment | Use of valproic acid for epilepsy within 30 days prior to registration | Pre-existing neurotoxicity/neuropathy >= grade 2, or prior >= grade 3 allergic reaction/hypersensitivity or rash to thalidomide not resolved to < grade 2 | Serious medical condition, laboratory abnormality, or psychiatric illness that poses unacceptable risk or prevents informed consent | History of thromboembolic event or condition requiring current anticoagulation with warfarin or low molecular-weight heparin | Known or suspected hypersensitivity to mannitol | White blood cell count > 30,000/µL at registration | Active second malignancy within 3 years, except adequately treated basal/squamous cell skin cancer or in situ cervical cancer
prior_therapies: Hematopoietic growth factors stopped >= 14 days before registration; Prior low-dose cytarabine for MDS allowed if discontinued >= 28 days before registration; Prior hydroxyurea for CMML allowed if discontinued >= 7 days before registration
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for MDS/CMML, not PMM2-CDG. Additionally, the patient is 8 years old, which is below the trial’s minimum age of 18.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; Moderate cerebellar dysfunction; ICARS score 35; Age 8 years; Female sex
patient_prior_therapies: (none)
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard exclusion due to disease mismatch (trial is for MDS/CMML; patient has PMM2-CDG), and also an age hard exclusion (trial minimum age 18; patient is 8). Either suffices for grade F.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Randomized Phase II Trial of Erlotinib, Cabozantinib, or Erlotinib Plus Cabozantinib as 2nd or 3rd Line Therapy in Patients With EGFR Wild-Type NSCLC
brief_summary: This randomized phase II trial studies how well giving erlotinib hydrochloride and cabozantinib-s-malate alone or in combination works as second or third line therapy in treating patient with stage IV non-small cell lung cancer. Erlotinib hydrochloride and cabozantinib-s-malate may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. It is not yet known whether giving erlotinib hydrochloride together with cabozantinib-s-malate is more effective than erlotinib...

inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung carcinoma confirmed cytologically or histologically | Predominant non-squamous histology; small cell components excluded | Stage IV or recurrent disease by AJCC 7th edition | Measurable disease per RECIST v1.1 | Tumor tissue available for MET IHC testing | One to two prior lines of chemotherapy for advanced disease | Any prior chemotherapy completed per required washout | Discontinued investigational agents >= 4 weeks before registration | Recovered to baseline or CTCAE v4.0 <= grade 1 from prior therapy toxicities (except alopecia and non-clinically significant AEs) | Brain metastases status meeting protocol criteria (stable if present); baseline brain imaging per protocol | Radiation-related toxicities resolved to <= grade 1 | ECOG performance status 0-2 | Anticipated life expectancy > 3 months | Acceptable bone marrow, renal, and hepatic function within 2 weeks prior to registration | QTcF <= 500 ms within 28 days before registration | Able to swallow tablets | Step 2: Radiographic progressive disease after >= 2 courses on Arm A or Arm B | Step 2: Registered within 4 weeks of last dose from Step 1 | Step 2: ECOG performance status 0-2 | Step 2: Recovered to baseline (pre-Step 1) or CTCAE v4.0 <= grade 1 from prior therapy toxicities
exclusion_criteria: Insufficient tumor pathology material (tumor block or 10 unstained slides) for required testing | Prior erlotinib or other EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy | Prior VEGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy | Prior MET tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy or MET monoclonal antibody | Radiation therapy to thoracic cavity, abdomen, or pelvis within 3 months; to bone or brain within 14 days; or to any other site within 28 days prior to registration | Clinically significant gastrointestinal bleeding within 6 months | Hemoptysis >= 2.5 mL within 3 months | Other signs of pulmonary hemorrhage within 3 months | Tumor invading the gastrointestinal tract or endotracheal/endobronchial tumor within 28 days prior to registration | Cavitating pulmonary lesion(s) within 28 days prior to registration | Tumor in contact with, invading, or encasing major blood vessels within 28 days prior to registration | History of major thrombotic events (deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism) within 6 months | Therapeutic anticoagulation or antiplatelet therapy (except low-dose aspirin <= 81 mg/day and prophylactic LMWH) | Concomitant strong CYP3A4 inducers | Congestive heart failure NYHA class III or IV | Uncontrolled hypertension | History of congenital long QT syndrome | Unstable angina within 6 months | Clinically significant cardiac arrhythmias within 6 months | Stroke or transient ischemic attack or other ischemic event within 6 months | Myocardial infarction within 6 months | Gastrointestinal disorders with high risk of perforation or fistula | High risk of fistula including PEG tube placement within 3 months | Uncontrolled, significant intercurrent or recent illness | Prior malignancy within 2 years requiring systemic treatment or currently active | Pregnant or breastfeeding | HIV infection on antiretroviral therapy | Chronic active hepatitis B | Step 2: Intervening anticancer treatment or major surgery between Step 1 and Step 2 (except palliative bone radiation finished >= 2 weeks before Step 2 registration) | Step 2: Central nervous system progression | Step 2: Intercurrent illness or complication limiting ability to safely tolerate erlotinib plus cabozantinib
prior_therapies: Required: 1-2 prior lines of chemotherapy for advanced NSCLC; Prior adjuvant chemotherapy allowed if > 12 months before first-line systemic therapy (otherwise counts as one line); Discontinue investigational agents >= 4 weeks before registration
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with prior EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy, and the patient has received osimertinib (an EGFR TKI). Additionally, the trial requires 1–2 prior lines of chemotherapy for advanced disease, which the patient has not had.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; ECOG 0; De novo metastatic disease; Metastases to bone and liver; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years with complete response; Recent MRI shows numerous lesions; No past medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Osimertinib
judge_comment: Correct: The trial explicitly excludes prior EGFR TKI therapy, and the patient received osimertinib (an EGFR TKI), which is a hard exclusion → F. The noted lack of required prior chemotherapy further disfavors eligibility but is not needed for the F. Additionally, the trial targets EGFR wild-type, while the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion, another hard exclusion.

trial_title: Investigator-Initiated, Pilot Translational Study of Circulating Tumor Cells to Identify Predictive Factors of Response to Abiraterone Acetate in Men With Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer
brief_summary: This research study is a Pilot clinical trial. Pilot clinical trials often examine new tests (such as laboratory or radiology tests) in patients who receive either standard cancer treatments or new treatments that have been well-tested in many patients on other trials. It is often difficult to determine how prostate cancer is going to behave when a new treatment is started. Physicians have no way to predict how a patient's tumor will respond to treatment. Although scientists have learned abou...

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase I/II Trial of Intraperitoneal Administration of Adipose Tissue Derived Mesenchymal Stem Cells Infected With a NIS-Expressing Derivative Manufactured From a Genetically Engineered Strain of Measles Virus in Patients With Recurrent Ovarian Cancer
brief_summary: This phase I/II trial studies the side effects and best dose of oncolytic measles virus encoding thyroidal sodium iodide symporter (MV-NIS) infected mesenchymal stem cells and to see how well it works in treating patients with ovarian, primary peritoneal or fallopian tube cancer that has come back. Mesenchymal stem cells may be able to carry tumor-killing substances directly to ovarian, primary peritoneal and fallopian tube cancer cells.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-Blind Study of Erlotinib in Combination With Ramucirumab or Placebo in Previously Untreated Patients With EGFR Mutation-Positive Metastatic Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
brief_summary: The main purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ramucirumab in combination with erlotinib as compared to placebo in combination with erlotinib in previously untreated participants with stage IV non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) harboring an activating epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutation (Exon 19-Del and Exon 21 L858R). Safety and tolerability of ramucirumab in combination with erlotinib will be assessed in Part A before proceeding to Part B. The purpose ...

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase III, Randomized, Open-Label, Controlled, Multi-Center, Global Study of First-Line MEDI4736 (Durvalumab) Monotherapy and MEDI4736 (Durvalumab) in Combination With Tremelimumab Versus Standard of Care Chemotherapy in Patients With Unresectable Stage IV Urothelial Cancer

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase III, Randomized, Multi-Center, Open-Label, Comparative Global Study to Determine the Efficacy of Durvalumab or Durvalumab and Tremelimumab in Combination With Platinum-Based Chemotherapy for First-Line Treatment in Patients With Metastatic Non Small-Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) (POSEIDON)
brief_summary: This is a randomized, open-label, multi-center, global, Phase III study to determine the efficacy and safety of durvalumab + tremelimumab combination therapy + Standard of care (SoC) chemotherapy or durvalumab monotherapy + SoC chemotherapy versus SoC chemotherapy alone as first line treatment in patients with metastatic non small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) with tumors that lack activating epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations and anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) fusions.
interventions: {'id': 206152505, 'name': 'Durvalumab', 'description': 'IV infusions every 3 weeks for 12 weeks (4 cycles) and every 4 weeks thereafter until disease progression or other discontinuation criteria', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206152506, 'name': 'Tremelimumab', 'description': 'IV infusions every 3 weeks for 12 weeks (4 cycles). For Treatment Arm 3, Pemetrexed maintenance therapy can be given either q3w or q4w (dependent on Investigator decision and local standards)\\] until objective disease progression.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Histologically or cytologically confirmed Stage IV NSCLC | Confirmed tumor PD-L1 status prior to randomization | Tumors lack activating EGFR mutations and ALK fusions | No prior chemotherapy or other systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC | ECOG 0-1 | No prior exposure to immune-mediated therapy (excluding therapeutic anticancer vaccines)
exclusion_criteria: Mixed small-cell lung cancer and NSCLC histology or sarcomatoid variant | Active or prior documented autoimmune or inflammatory disorders | Untreated or unstable brain metastases or spinal cord compression; requires stability off steroids | Active infection including tuberculosis, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, or HIV
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC; No prior exposure to immune-mediated therapy (excluding therapeutic anticancer vaccines)
reasoning: The trial requires tumors to lack activating EGFR mutations and excludes any prior systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC; the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion and has received osimertinib. These are hard exclusions.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; ECOG 0; De novo metastatic disease; Metastases to bone and liver; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years with complete response; Recent MRI shows numerous lesions; No past medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Osimertinib
judge_comment: The trial requires EGFR-wildtype (lack of activating EGFR mutations) and no prior systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC. The patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion and has received osimertinib. Both are explicit hard exclusions, so F is correct.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. trial_title: Randomized Phase III Trial of Local Consolidation Therapy (LCT) After Nivolumab and Ipilimumab for Immunotherapy-Naive Patients With Metastatic Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (LONESTAR)
brief_summary: This phase III trial studies how well nivolumab and ipilimumab works with or without local consolidation therapy in treating patients with stage IV non-small cell lung cancer. Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as nivolumab and ipilimumab, may help the body's immune system attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of tumor cells to grow and spread. Local consolidation therapy, such as surgery or radiation therapy, may improve survival outcomes in patients with non-smal...

inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed non-small cell lung cancer; neuroendocrine carcinomas (e.g., small cell, carcinoid) excluded; carcinomas with neuroendocrine differentiation eligible | Stage IV measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | For lung adenocarcinoma: absence of EGFR sensitizing mutation and ALK fusion when standard therapies are available; testing by CLIA-certified tumor or plasma assay | One prior line of chemotherapy and/or targeted therapy for metastatic disease permitted (frontline, including maintenance); prior antiangiogenic therapy permitted if used frontline | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Adequately treated brain metastases or asymptomatic small (<=1 cm) brain metastases allowed if neurologically stable and off corticosteroids or on <=10 mg daily prednisone (or equivalent) for >=2 weeks | For cohort 1: prior palliative radiotherapy allowed if at least one other non-irradiated lesion amenable to LCT remains | Cohort 2: radiologic progression during induction phase prior to randomization | Cohort 2: start platinum doublet plus immune checkpoint inhibitor within 6 weeks after last day of prior immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy | Cohort 2: willingness to undergo pre-treatment and on-treatment tumor biopsies (or archival tissue if unsafe to biopsy) | Cohort 2: radiotherapy for symptomatic metastases at time of progression permitted | WBC >= 2000/µL | Neutrophils >= 1500/µL | Platelets >= 100000/µL | Hemoglobin > 9.0 g/dL | Serum creatinine <= 1.5 x ULN or creatinine clearance >= 50 mL/min | AST <= 3 x ULN | ALT <= 3 x ULN | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN (Gilbert syndrome allowed if total bilirubin < 3.0 mg/dL)
exclusion_criteria: Prior systemic immunotherapy for metastatic NSCLC (e.g., PD-1/PD-L1 or CTLA-4 inhibitors) | Any approved anti-cancer therapy, including chemotherapy or hormonal therapy, within 3 weeks prior to study treatment (except hormone-replacement therapy or oral contraceptives) | Prior pneumonitis requiring corticosteroids within 60 days before first dose of nivolumab | Active, known, or suspected autoimmune disease (exceptions: vitiligo, type I diabetes, residual hypothyroidism on replacement, psoriasis not requiring systemic treatment, or conditions not expected to recur) | Systemic immunosuppressive treatment >10 mg/day prednisone equivalents within 14 days of study drug administration (with specified exceptions) | Positive hepatitis B surface antigen or positive hepatitis C indicating acute or chronic infection | Known HIV infection or AIDS | History of severe hypersensitivity to monoclonal antibodies or allergy to study drug components | Women must not be breastfeeding
prior_therapies: One prior line of chemotherapy and/or targeted therapy for metastatic disease permitted (frontline, including maintenance); Prior antiangiogenic therapy permitted if used in frontline setting
reasoning: The trial requires absence of EGFR sensitizing mutations for lung adenocarcinoma, but the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion. Therefore, this is a required biomarker mismatch and a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; ECOG 0; De novo metastatic disease; Metastases to bone and liver; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years with complete response; Recent MRI shows numerous lesions; No past medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Osimertinib
judge_comment: The EGFR-wildtype requirement is specified only for lung adenocarcinoma; histology is not provided, so per rubric you cannot assume adenocarcinoma and cannot invoke a hard exclusion. With no definitive hard exclusions, stage/setting and prior-exposure/line anchors both match (metastatic NSCLC; immunotherapy-naive; one prior targeted line permitted). Thus the correct grade is A, not F.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: A Double Blind, Randomized, Placebo-controlled, Phase 1/2 Study to Assess the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, Pharmacodynamics, and Effects on Clinical Outcomes of Pegtibatinase (TVT-058), Administered Subcutaneously in Patients with Cystathionine Beta-Synthase Deficient Homocystinuria (COMPOSE)
brief_summary: Homocystinuria caused by Cystathionine Beta-Synthase (CBS) Deficiency is a rare autosomal-recessive metabolic condition characterized by an excess of homocysteine (Hcy) in the plasma, tissues and urine. It is due to reduced or absent activity of the CBS enzyme, and is also known as classical homocystinuria. The symptoms associated with homocystinuria are variable in severity and time of onset across patients. Some affected individuals may have mild signs of the disorder; others may have multi...

exclusion_criteria: Previous exposure to pegtibatinase or prior participation in a pegtibatinase trial | Use of injectable polyethylene glycol (PEG)–containing drugs within 3 months prior to screening and during study participation | Known hypersensitivity to PEG-containing products or any components of pegtibatinase | Positive test for HIV antibody, hepatitis B surface antigen, or hepatitis C antibody | History of organ transplantation | Chronic immunosuppressive therapy | Substance abuse | Pregnant or breastfeeding or planning pregnancy/breastfeeding during the study | Concurrent disease or condition that would interfere with study participation or safety in the opinion of the investigator | Planned major surgery during the study period | High risk of poor treatment compliance or not completing the study in the investigator's opinion
prior_therapies: No investigational product or investigational medical device within 30 days prior to screening
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets cystathionine beta-synthase–deficient homocystinuria, while the patient has OTC deficiency. Additionally, the patient is 3 months old, which is outside the trial’s 12–65 year age range, and the required CBS biomarker is not met.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; Age 3 months; Male; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Stable on dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers
patient_prior_therapies: Dietary protein restriction; Ammonia scavengers
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard disease mismatch (OTC deficiency vs CBS-deficient homocystinuria), a hard age window conflict (3 months vs 12–65 years), and a required biomarker mismatch (CBS required, patient has OTC). Any one warrants F; multiple are present.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: Randomized Phase II Trial of Osimertinib With or Without Local Consolidation Therapy (LCT) for Patients With EGFR-Mutant Metastatic NSCLC (NORTHSTAR)
brief_summary: This phase II trial studies how well osimertinib, surgery, and radiation therapy work in treating patients with stage IIIB or IV non-small cell lung cancer with EGFR mutations. Osimertinib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. Radiation therapy uses high energy x-rays to kill tumor cells and shrink tumors. Giving osimertinib, surgery, and radiation therapy may work better at treating non-small cell lung cancer with EGFR mutations.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase II, Randomized, Multi-Center, Double-Blind, Comparative Global Study to Determine the Efficacy and Safety of Durvalumab in Combination With Olaparib for First-Line Treatment in Platinum-Ineligible Patients With Unresectable Stage IV Urothelial Cancer
brief_summary: A Phase II, Randomized, Multi-Center, Double-Blind, Comparative Global Study to Determine the Efficacy and Safety of Durvalumab in Combination With Olaparib for First-Line Treatment in Platinum-Ineligible Patients With Unresectable Stage IV Urothelial Cancer

patient_inclusion_criteria: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progression after second-line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab; Bone and liver metastases; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD; Age 55 years; Male sex

judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: the trial requires no prior systemic therapy for unresectable Stage IV (patient is post-second line) and explicitly excludes prior immune-mediated therapy (patient received pembrolizumab). Either condition alone warrants F. The grader’s reasoning correctly identified these.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.

brief_summary: The main purpose of this study is to learn if a new combination of chemotherapy, in combination with low-dose radiation, will be safe for the patient, and at the same time provide the best opportunity to cure the bone marrow cancer. The combination of chemotherapy and radiation described in the study is considered 'low intensity.' Although the chemotherapy agents used in this study and for transplant are FDA approved, the chemotherapy treatment and conditioning regimens or combinations listed...

reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets adult hematologic malignancies/aplastic anemia, not PMM2-CDG. Additionally, the trial requires age ≥18, while the patient is 8 years old.

judge_comment: Disease mismatch (PMM2-CDG not among trial diseases) and age <18 vs trial minimum age 18 are both hard exclusions. Grade F is correct per rubric.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: Phase 1 Study of Combination Osimertinib, Platinum, Etoposide for Patients With Metastatic EGFR Mutant Lung Cancers With Concurrent RB1 and TP53 Alterations
brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to test the safety of combining Osimertinib with either Cisplatin or Carboplatin (at different dose levels) and Etoposide, to find out what effects, if any, this combination of drugs has on people with EGFR mutant lung cancer.
interventions: {'id': 206070236, 'name': 'Osimertinib', 'description': 'Osimertinib 80mg daily', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206070237, 'name': 'Platinum', 'description': 'Cisplatin 60mg/m2 or Cisplatin 45mg/m2 Carboplatin AUC 5 or Carboplatin AUC 4', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206070238, 'name': 'Etoposide', 'description': 'Etoposide 100mg/m2 or Etoposide 80mg/m2', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (biopsy-proven) | Somatic activating EGFR mutation in tumor or cfDNA | Concurrent TP53 alteration by IHC or NGS | Concurrent RB1 alteration by IHC or NGS | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 with a non-irradiated indicator lesion | Karnofsky >= 70% | Age > 18 years
exclusion_criteria: Pregnant or lactating | Prior EGFR TKI other than osimertinib or osimertinib started > 9 weeks before enrollment | Radiotherapy within 1 week prior to protocol treatment | Major surgery within 1 week prior to protocol treatment | Active clinically significant interstitial lung disease | Unresolved > grade 1 toxicity from previous treatment | Pure small cell lung cancer histology | QTcF > 475 msec or clinically significant ECG rhythm, conduction, or morphology abnormalities | Cisplatin-specific: creatinine clearance < 60 mL/min | Cisplatin-specific: hearing impairment requiring assistive device | Cisplatin-specific: neuropathy | Cisplatin-specific: provider deems patient unsuitable for cisplatin
prior_therapies: Osimertinib allowed if started within the last 9 weeks; No prior EGFR TKI other than osimertinib
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients who started osimertinib more than 9 weeks before enrollment, and this patient has been on osimertinib for 2 years. Additionally, the trial requires concurrent TP53 and RB1 alterations, which are not documented for this patient.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; ECOG 0; De novo metastatic disease; Metastases to bone and liver; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years with complete response; Recent MRI shows numerous lesions; No past medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Osimertinib
judge_comment: Explicit exclusion applies: trial excludes patients who started osimertinib >9 weeks before enrollment, while the patient has been on osimertinib for 2 years. That alone mandates F. Mention of missing TP53/RB1 is not needed but does not change the outcome.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 1b Study of Combination of Avelumab and Taxane Based Chemotherapy in Platinum Refractory or Ineligible Metastatic Urothelial Cancer
brief_summary: This study evaluates the safety and efficacy of the combination of Avelumab, (a fully human anti-programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1) IgG1 antibody) in combination with a taxane chemotherapy (docetaxel) in patients with metastatic urothelial cancer who are either ineligible to receive cisplatin based chemotherapy, refractory to cisplatin in first line setting or have disease relapse after receiving cisplatin based chemotherapy within a year in the neoadjuvant or adjuvant setting.
interventions: {'id': 205955735, 'name': 'Avelumab', 'description': 'Avelumab is a fully human anti-programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1) IgG1 antibody', 'other_names': ['MSB0010718C'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205955736, 'name': 'Docetaxel', 'description': 'Docetaxel is a antineoplastic agent belonging to the taxoid family', 'other_names': ['Taxotere'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Age 18–85 years | Histologically or cytologically confirmed locally advanced or metastatic urothelial (transitional cell) carcinoma; mixed histologies allowed if urothelial is predominant | Progressed after at least 1 prior platinum-containing regimen for inoperable locally advanced/metastatic urothelial carcinoma or recurrence, or cisplatin-ineligible by renal, hearing, or neuropathy criteria, or progression within 12 months of neoadjuvant/adjuvant chemotherapy | Biopsy material available (archival acceptable if fresh not feasible) | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Estimated life expectancy >= 3 months | At least one measurable lesion per RECIST v1.1 | Adequate hematologic function | Adequate hepatic function | Adequate renal function (creatinine clearance > 30 mL/min)
exclusion_criteria: Concurrent anticancer treatment | Prior therapy with any drug targeting T cell coregulatory proteins | Major surgery within 4 weeks or not fully recovered within 4 weeks | Concurrent systemic corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive agents (short-term steroids for allergic reactions or on-study immune AEs allowed) | Use of any investigational drug within 28 days before starting trial drug | Active central nervous system metastases (appropriately treated CNS metastases allowed) | Previous malignant disease within 5 years except basal/squamous cell skin cancer, cervical carcinoma in situ, or prostate adenocarcinoma Gleason 6–7, pT2b | Prior organ transplantation including allogeneic stem-cell transplantation | Known HIV infection or active HBV or HCV infection | Active or history of autoimmune disease or immune deficiencies (type 1 diabetes, vitiligo, psoriasis, or thyroid disease not requiring immunosuppression allowed) | Known monoclonal antibody hypersensitivity, history of anaphylaxis, or uncontrolled asthma | Persisting toxicity from prior therapy > grade 1 (grade <= 2 sensory neuropathy allowed) | Pregnancy or lactation | Clinically significant cardiovascular disease (stroke < 6 months, myocardial infarction < 6 months, unstable angina, congestive heart failure >= NYHA class II, or serious arrhythmia requiring medication) | Other severe acute or chronic medical conditions including immune colitis, inflammatory bowel disease, immune pneumonitis, pulmonary fibrosis, or psychiatric conditions including recent or active suicidal ideation or behavior
prior_therapies: Prior platinum-containing chemotherapy for locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma with progression; Progression within 12 months of neoadjuvant or adjuvant platinum-containing chemotherapy
reasoning: Explicit exclusion: the trial prohibits prior therapy with T cell coregulatory inhibitors (PD-1/PD-L1), and the patient received pembrolizumab.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progression after second-line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab; Bone and liver metastases; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD; Age 55 years; Male sex
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes prior therapy targeting T cell coregulatory proteins; the patient received pembrolizumab (PD-1). This is a hard exclusion per rubric, so F is correct.

Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as atezolizumab, may help the body's immune system attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of tumor cells to grow and spread. Cobimetinib...

reasoning: The trial requires prior anti–PD-1/PD-L1 therapy with progression within 6 months of initiation, but the patient has only received osimertinib (no prior PD-1/PD-L1), so the required treatment setting is not met. KRAS status is also unspecified, but the prior PD-1 requirement alone is disqualifying.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; ECOG 0; De novo metastatic disease; Metastases to bone and liver; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years with complete response; Recent MRI shows numerous lesions; No past medical issues

judge_comment: The trial explicitly requires prior anti–PD-1/PD-L1 therapy with progression within 6 months (a required setting the patient definitively lacks). This constitutes a hard exclusion per the rubric. Other factors (KRAS status unknown) are neutral. Therefore F is correct and the grader’s reasoning is appropriate.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: BRIGHTSTAR: A Pilot Trial of Local Consolidative Therapy (LCT) With Brigatinib in Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitor-Naive ALK-Rearranged Advanced NSCLC
brief_summary: This early phase I trial studies the side effects and how well local consolidative therapy (LCT) and brigatinib works in treating patients with non-small cell lung cancer that is stage IV or has come back (recurrent). Giving LCT, such as surgery and/or radiation, after initial treatment may kill any remaining tumor cells. Brigatinib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. Giving LCT and brigatinib may work better in treating patients with non...

exclusion_criteria: Another primary malignancy (exceptions: adequately treated non-melanoma skin cancer or cervical carcinoma in situ; definitively treated non-metastatic prostate cancer; or malignancy relapse-free for >= 2 years) | Prior TKI therapy including ALK-targeted TKIs (except ongoing first-line brigatinib per inclusion) | More than 1 prior regimen of chemotherapy or immunotherapy for locally advanced or metastatic disease | Symptomatic CNS metastases or escalating corticosteroid dose for CNS disease within 7 days before enrollment | Current spinal cord compression | Pulmonary interstitial disease, drug-related pneumonitis, or radiation pneumonitis at screening | Known or suspected hypersensitivity to brigatinib or its excipients | Malabsorption syndrome or other GI condition that could affect oral absorption of brigatinib | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Significant, uncontrolled, or active cardiovascular disease (e.g., MI within 6 months, unstable angina within 6 months, decompensated CHF within 6 months, clinically significant atrial arrhythmia or bradyarrhythmia, any ventricular arrhythmia, stroke or TIA within 6 months) | Uncontrolled hypertension | Ongoing or active infection, including need for IV antibiotics | Known HIV infection | Any condition that would compromise patient safety or interfere with study evaluations

reasoning: The trial requires ALK-rearranged NSCLC and TKI-naive or ≤8 weeks on first-line brigatinib, but the patient has EGFR exon 19–mutated disease and prior osimertinib exposure. This is a required biomarker mismatch and conflicts with the trial’s prior TKI exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; ECOG 0; De novo metastatic disease; Metastases to bone and liver; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years with complete response; Recent MRI shows numerous lesions; No past medical issues

While ALK status is not provided (so biomarker mismatch alone shouldn’t trigger F), the prior-TKI exclusion is sufficient for an F. The grader’s final grade is correct.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 1/2a Double-Blind, Randomized, Placebo-Controlled Trial to Assess the Safety and Efficacy of Oral Administration of EcoActive on Intestinal Adherent Invasive Escherichia Coli (AIEC) in Patients With Inactive Crohn's Disease (CD)
brief_summary: This study will evaluate the safety of oral administration of EcoActive to patients with inactive Crohn's disease and how it affects the levels of AIEC in stool.

inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Inactive Crohn's disease in clinical and objective remission with Harvey-Bradshaw Index (HBI) < 4 | Permitted Crohn's disease medications expected to remain stable during the study | Crohn's disease history >= 6 months | CRP within normal range at screening | Fecal calprotectin <= 150 µg/g at screening | Adherent-invasive Escherichia coli (AIEC) detected in stool | Females of childbearing potential must use effective contraception during the study | Negative pregnancy test for women of childbearing potential
exclusion_criteria: Active Crohn's disease with HBI >= 4 | Ongoing gastrointestinal pathology: colorectal tumor or gastrointestinal bleeding | Active malignancy or any malignant disease within the past 5 years | Indeterminate colitis or ulcerative colitis | Colectomy or partial colectomy (less than ileo-transverse colonic anastomosis) | Colonic or small bowel stoma | Active perianal lesions | Pregnant or nursing, or planning pregnancy during the study | Severe uncontrolled diseases including heart disease, congestive heart failure, hypertension, lung disease, endocrine disease, clinically significant renal disease (glomerular filtration rate < 60 mL/min), hepatic disease, or hematological disorders | Use of supplemental probiotics (pills or tablets) | History of or planned procedures aimed at modifying the gastrointestinal microbiota within the past year | Topical gastrointestinal treatment (e.g., enemas) within 2 weeks prior to screening or planned during the study | Bowel cleansing or preparation for endoscopy, CT/MRI within 4 weeks prior to screening or planned during the study | Receipt of antibiotics within 4 weeks prior to screening or planned during the study | Known allergy or hypersensitivity to an excipient in the study drug or placebo | Receipt of mesalamine-based therapies within 4 weeks prior to screening | Severe psychiatric, psychological, or neurological disorders | Alcohol, drug, or medication abuse within the past year
prior_therapies: Stable dose of permitted Crohn's disease medications during the study
reasoning: The trial requires inactive Crohn’s disease and explicitly excludes active perianal lesions; the patient has active, draining perianal fistulizing Crohn’s disease with a seton in place. These explicit exclusions make the patient ineligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active draining perianal fistula with seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: the trial explicitly excludes active perianal lesions, while the patient has an active draining perianal fistula. Therefore F is correct. Other mismatches (inactive disease required) also support ineligibility but are not needed to justify F.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: A Phase Ib Study of Nivolumab in Patients With Autoimmune Disorders and Advanced Malignancies (AIM-NIVO)
brief_summary: This phase Ib trial studies the side effects of nivolumab and to see how well it works in treating patients with autoimmune disorders and cancer that has spread to other places in the body or cannot removed by surgery. Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as nivolumab, may help the body's immune system attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of tumor cells to grow and spread.

steroid/immunosuppressive therapy within 7 days before first dose | Grade 3 thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, or anemia | Cytogenetic or sequencing abnormalities associated with MDS/MPN (e.g., del(5q), chromosome 7 abnormalities, JAK2 V617F) | Ongoing or untreated hematologic malignancy or myeloproliferative disorder, or prior history of hematologic malignancy/myeloproliferative disorder | Prior PD-1/PD-L1/PD-L2 or EZH2 inhibitor therapy | Prior monoclonal antibody within 4 weeks before day 1 | Active second invasive malignancy within 5 years (except curatively treated basal or squamous cell skin cancer or carcinoma in situ of the cervix) or receiving treatment for another cancer | Known brain metastases or carcinomatous meningitis (unless previously treated and stable >= 4 weeks, no new/enlarging lesions, and off steroids >= 7 days) | Allergic reactions to compounds similar to pembrolizumab or tazemetostat | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment in the past 2 years | History of non-infectious pneumonitis requiring steroids or current pneumonitis | QTcF > 450 msec | Major surgery within 3 weeks before first dose | Use of strong or moderate CYP3A inhibitors or inducers within 14 days before first dose | Inability to take oral medication or malabsorption/uncontrolled gastrointestinal condition that may impair tazemetostat bioavailability | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness (active infection, interstitial lung disease, symptomatic congestive heart failure, unstable angina, cardiac arrhythmia, uncontrolled hypertension, stroke within 6 months, or psychiatric/social conditions limiting compliance) | Pregnant or breastfeeding; planning to conceive or father children or donate sperm during treatment and for 6 months after last dose | Known hepatitis B surface antigen positivity or detectable hepatitis C virus RNA | Receipt of a live vaccine within 30 days before treatment start
prior_therapies: Arm A requires prior platinum-based chemotherapy with progression on or within 12 months; No chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or radiotherapy within 4 weeks prior to first dose; No investigational agents or devices within 4 weeks prior to first dose; No monoclonal antibody therapy within 4 weeks prior to first dose; No transfusion of blood products or colony-stimulating factors within 4 weeks prior to first dose; No systemic corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive therapy within 7 days prior to first dose; No live vaccines within 30 days prior to treatment start

patient_inclusion_criteria: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progression after second-line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab; Bone and liver metastases; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD; Age 55 years; Male sex

judge_comment: The trial explicitly requires PD-1/PD-L1 naïvety and excludes prior PD-1 exposure. The patient received pembrolizumab (PD-1), which is a hard exclusion per the rubric example. Therefore F is correct regardless of other matches.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Target Validation Study of Fimepinostat in Children and Young Adults With Newly Diagnosed Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG), Recurrent Medulloblastoma, or Recurrent High-Grade Glioma (HGG)
brief_summary: This trial studies how well fimepinostat works in treating patients with newly diagnosed diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma, or medulloblastoma, or high-grade glioma that have come back. Fimepinostat may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth.
interventions: {'id': 205947918, 'name': 'Fimepinostat', 'description': 'Fimepinostat capsules', 'other_names': ['CUDC-907'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205947919, 'name': 'Therapeutic Conventional Surgery', 'description': 'Undergo surgery', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'PROCEDURE'}
diseases_targeted: Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma; Medulloblastoma (recurrent); Anaplastic Astrocytoma (recurrent); Glioblastoma (recurrent); Malignant Glioma (recurrent)
inclusion_criteria: Newly diagnosed diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (WHO grade II–IV); biopsy feasible; may enroll before or after standard-of-care radiation; no prior therapy before fimepinostat except temozolomide during radiation or prior radiation; if post-radiation, enroll within 14 weeks of completion | Recurrent medulloblastoma (WHO grade IV), any molecular subtype; locally recurrent or disseminated disease allowed if resection/biopsy clinically indicated | Recurrent high-grade glioma including anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO grade III) and glioblastoma (WHO grade IV); locally recurrent or disseminated disease allowed if resection/biopsy clinically indicated | Recurrent DIPG eligible if biopsy/resection feasible outside the pons (e.g., cerebellar extension or metastatic site) | Able to swallow intact fimepinostat capsules or mini-tabs without chewing or crushing | Body surface area >= 0.5 m^2 | Tumor tissue collection required as part of standard of care (minimum equivalent to ~4–6 stereotactic core biopsies) | Prior therapy allowed for recurrent medulloblastoma and recurrent HGG (surgery, chemotherapy, radiation); must have recovered from acute side effects of prior anti-cancer therapies | Myelosuppressive chemotherapy washout: >= 21 days (>= 42 days if prior nitrosourea) | Hematopoietic growth factor washout: >= 14 days after long-acting or >= 7 days after short-acting growth factors | Biologic anti-neoplastic agent washout: >= 7 days | Monoclonal antibody washout: >= 21 days | Radiotherapy washout: >= 2 weeks after local palliative RT; >= 3 months after craniospinal RT or RT to > 50% pelvis | Major surgery washout: >= 21 days | Dexamethasone on a stable or decreasing dose for >= 7 days prior to enrollment if receiving | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1000/µL | Platelet count >= 100000/µL (transfusion independent for >= 7 days) | Creatinine clearance or GFR >= 70 mL/min/1.73 m^2 or age/sex-specific serum creatinine within limits | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN for age | ALT (SGPT) <= 110 U/L | Serum albumin >= 2 g/dL | Seizure disorder permitted if well controlled | Diarrhea < grade 2 (CTCAE v5.0) | Non-fasting glucose < 125 mg/dL without antihyperglycemics, or fasting glucose <= 160 mg/dL without antihyperglycemics if non-fasting > 125 mg/dL | QTc < 480 msec | Women of childbearing potential and men agree to use adequate contraception during study and for 30 days after last dose
exclusion_criteria: Not recovered from acute adverse events due to prior therapies administered > 4 weeks earlier | Prior therapy with single-agent or combination histone deacetylase (HDAC) and PI3K inhibitors | Receiving any other investigational agent | History of allergic reaction to compounds of similar chemical or biological composition to fimepinostat | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness (e.g., active infection, symptomatic congestive heart failure, unstable angina, cardiac arrhythmia) or psychiatric/social condition limiting compliance | Active HIV infection with potential life-threatening consequences associated with immunosuppressive therapy | History of type 1 or type 2 diabetes mellitus | Gastrointestinal condition that could interfere with absorption or metabolism of fimepinostat
prior_therapies: Recurrent medulloblastoma and recurrent high-grade glioma: prior surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation allowed; Newly diagnosed DIPG: no prior therapy before fimepinostat except temozolomide during radiation or prior radiation; Recovered from acute toxicities of prior anti-cancer therapy; Washout: myelosuppressive chemotherapy >= 21 days (>= 42 days if nitrosourea); Washout: hematopoietic growth factors >= 14 days (long-acting) or >= 7 days (short-acting); Washout: biologic anti-neoplastic agents >= 7 days; Washout: monoclonal antibodies >= 21 days; Washout: radiotherapy >= 2 weeks (local palliative) or >= 3 months (craniospinal or > 50% pelvis); Washout: major surgery >= 21 days
reasoning: Although the disease (recurrent glioblastoma) matches a trial cohort, the patient is 40 years old, which exceeds the trial’s maximum age of 39—a hard age window exclusion.
