question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Effect and Safety of Electroconvulsive Therapy Plus Usual Care for the Acute Management of Severe Agitation in Dementia
brief_summary: This study will explore the effect of ECT treatments plus usual care (ECT+UC) in reducing severe agitation in patients with moderate to severe dementia including Alzheimer's Disease, Vascular dementia, Frontotemporal dementia, and Dementia with Lewy Bodies. The study will also determine the tolerability/safety outcomes of ECT+UC.
interventions: {'id': 205456480, 'name': 'Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)', 'description': 'Stimulus method of delivery will be RUL electrode placement, and ultra-brief (UB) pulse width (0.25-0.37ms). At the first ECT session, seizure threshold (ST) will be determined by titration with the empirical dose titration method and subsequent treatments will be approximately 6 times the ST. Following other NIMH sponsored multicenter ECT studies (PRIDE, U01 MH055495), stimulus settings will be adjusted as needed during the ECT course based on seizure quality and treatment efficacy. Participants will be administered anesthesia.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DEVICE'}
diseases_targeted: Alzheimer Dementia; Vascular Dementia; Frontotemporal Dementia; Dementia with Lewy Bodies
inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of Alzheimer's dementia per NIA-AA criteria | Diagnosis of vascular dementia with MRI evidence of microvascular ischemic disease and no clinical/radiologic evidence of stroke | Diagnosis of frontotemporal dementia | Diagnosis of dementia with Lewy bodies | Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) <= 15 | Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory (CMAI) threshold for severe agitation as specified | At least one failed pharmacological intervention to manage behavioral symptoms | Medically stable for safe ECT based on physical exam, urinalysis, and serum chemistries (and brain imaging when indicated) | Comprehension of English | Authorized legal representative able and willing to provide informed consent | Age >= 40 years
exclusion_criteria: Current co-morbid delirium by Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) or clinical diagnosis | Vascular dementia due to stroke (abrupt onset, step-wise decline, MRI evidence of hemorrhagic/embolic stroke, or exam consistent with current/prior stroke) | Schizophrenia | Bipolar disorder | Schizoaffective disorder | Active substance use disorder within the past 6 months | Treatment with ECT, transcranial magnetic stimulation, or vagal nerve stimulation within the past 3 months
prior_therapies: At least one failed pharmacological intervention for behavioral symptoms
reasoning: The trial requires MMSE ≤ 15, while the patient’s MMSE is 19, which fails a mandatory inclusion criterion. Other required features (severe agitation with prior failed pharmacologic management) are unknown but the MMSE mismatch alone is a hard exclusion.
patient_biomarkers: Elevated p-tau; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative
patient_inclusion_criteria: Male; Age 68 years; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated p-tau
patient_prior_therapies: (none)
judge_comment: The trial requires MMSE ≤ 15, and the patient has MMSE 19, which is a definitive failure of a required stage/severity criterion—treated as a hard exclusion per the rubric. Thus F is appropriate regardless of other unknowns (e.g., severe agitation, prior failed pharmacologic management).

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase I Study of Avelumab in Combination With AXL Inhibitor AVB-S6-500 in Patients With Advanced Urothelial Carcinoma
brief_summary: The purpose of this research study is to test the safety of avelumab and AVB-S6-500 and see what effects (good and bad) this combination treatment has on patients with advanced urothelial carcinoma.
interventions: {'id': 205991076, 'name': 'Avelumab', 'description': 'Avelumab: 800 mg IV every two weeks (on days 1 and 15 of a 28-day cycle)', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 205991077, 'name': 'AVB-S6-500', 'description': 'AVB-S6-500: 10mg/kg IV every 2 weeks (on days 1 and 15 of a 28-day cycle) Potential dose reduction: AVB-S6-500: 5mg/kg IV weekly (on days 1, 8, 15 and 22 of a 28-day cycle)', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Histologically confirmed locally advanced unresectable (T4b or N2/N3) or metastatic urothelial carcinoma (renal pelvis, ureter, bladder, or urethra) | Progressed after at least 1 prior platinum-containing regimen for advanced/unresectable or metastatic disease OR progression/recurrence within 12 months of completing neoadjuvant or adjuvant cisplatin-based chemotherapy OR ineligible for cisplatin (ECOG 2, neuropathy >= 2, GFR < 60 mL/min, hearing loss >= 2, or NYHA class III+ heart failure) OR declined platinum-based chemotherapy | Available pretreatment tumor specimen or willingness to undergo biopsy | ECOG performance status <= 2 | At least one measurable lesion per RECIST 1.1 | Adequate hematologic and end-organ function | Women of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy test at screening | Agreement to use highly effective contraception or remain abstinent during treatment and for at least 30 days after last dose
exclusion_criteria: Concurrent systemic anticancer treatment or investigational drug within 28 days (palliative radiation allowed if measurable disease exists outside the field) | Prior therapy with PD-1 or PD-L1 inhibitors | Systemic corticosteroids > 10 mg prednisone equivalent or other immunosuppressive agents within 28 days before start (short-term <= 7 days, replacement doses <= 10 mg, topical/intranasal/inhaled allowed) | Untreated or symptomatic central nervous system metastases (eligible >= 4 weeks after surgery/radiation with stable/improved follow-up imaging) | Active second malignancy or malignancy within 3 years except basal/squamous cell skin cancer, cervical carcinoma in situ, or pT2 prostate adenocarcinoma with Gleason <= 7 (no dominant pattern 4) | Prior organ transplantation including allogeneic stem-cell transplantation | Known hepatitis B virus infection or untreated hepatitis C (treated HCV eligible) | Hypersensitivity to monoclonal antibodies or biologic drugs, history of anaphylaxis, or uncontrolled asthma | Persisting toxicity from prior therapy > grade 1 (grade <= 2 sensory neuropathy allowed) | Pregnant or lactating | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic immunosuppression (type 1 diabetes, vitiligo, psoriasis, or thyroid disorders not requiring systemic immunosuppression allowed) | History of interstitial lung disease/pneumonitis (including drug-induced) or evidence of active pneumonitis (radiation fibrosis allowed) | Active infection requiring systemic therapy | Severe infections within 4 weeks prior to first dose (including hospitalization for infection, bacteremia, or severe pneumonia) | Live or attenuated vaccine within 4 weeks prior to first dose, within 5 months after last dose, or anticipated need during the study | Other severe acute or chronic medical or psychiatric conditions, or laboratory abnormalities, that increase risk or may interfere with study participation or interpretation
prior_therapies: Progression after at least one prior platinum-containing chemotherapy regimen for advanced/unresectable or metastatic disease; Progression or recurrence within 12 months after completing neoadjuvant or adjuvant cisplatin-based chemotherapy; Cisplatin-ineligible per protocol criteria; Declined platinum-based chemotherapy; No systemic anticancer therapy within 28 days before starting study treatment
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with prior PD-1/PD-L1 therapy, and the patient received pembrolizumab (PD-1). Although the disease stage matches, this hard exclusion makes the patient ineligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progression after second-line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab; Bone and liver metastases; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD; Age 55 years; Male sex
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: Trial explicitly excludes prior PD-1/PD-L1 therapy; patient received pembrolizumab (PD-1). This is a hard exclusion, so F is correct.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: A Pilot Study of Condensed Busulfan, Melphalan, and Fludarabine Conditioning Prior to Ex-vivo CD34+ Selected Allogeneic Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation
brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to see if a condensed version of the chemotherapy regimen busulfan, melphalan, fludarabine (bu/mel/flu) and the drug antithymocyte globulin (ATG-also referred to as rATG or thymoglobulin) can have the same or fewer number of severe side effects in people with various blood cancers 30 days after they receive an allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation.
interventions: {'id': 206019838, 'name': 'Busulfan 3.2 mg/kg/day', 'description': 'Busulfan 3.2 mg/kg/day, with dose adjustments made according to pharmacokinetic (PK) levels.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206019839, 'name': 'Fludarabine', 'description': 'Fludarabine (25mg/m2/ day) administered on days -6, -5, -4, -3, and -2.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206019840, 'name': 'Melphalan', 'description': 'Melphalan (70mg/m2/day) administered on days -6 and -5.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206019841, 'name': 'Antithymocyte globulin (ATG)', 'description': "ATG will be given based on a dynamic nomogram based on the patient's absolute lymphocyte count at the start of conditioning and can result in 2 or 3 days of ATG administration.", 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206019842, 'name': 'Busulfan 0.8 mg/kg', 'description': 'Busulfan 0.8 mg/kg every 6 hours x 10 doses, with dose adjustments made according to PK levels.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206019843, 'name': 'Allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (Allo-HCT)', 'description': 'Allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation following the conditioning regimen.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'PROCEDURE'}
diseases_targeted: Acute Myeloid Leukemia; Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia; Acute Leukemias of Ambiguous Lineage; Chronic Myeloid Leukemia; Myelodysplastic Syndromes; Myeloproliferative Neoplasms; MDS/MPN Overlap Syndrome; Chronic Myelomonocytic Leukemia; Severe Aplastic Anemia; Hodgkin Lymphoma; Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma; Multiple Myeloma
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Acute myeloid leukemia in CR1 with intermediate/high-risk features or relapsed AML in >= CR2 | Acute leukemias of ambiguous lineage in >= CR1 | Acute lymphoblastic leukemia in CR1 with high-risk features or ALL in >= CR2 | Chronic myeloid leukemia with failed/intolerant TKI therapy, or BCR-ABL mutation with poor TKI response (e.g., T315I), or in accelerated/blast phase with <10% blasts after therapy, or in second chronic phase | Myelodysplastic syndromes, myeloproliferative neoplasms, or MDS/MPN overlap meeting intermediate-or-higher risk, life-threatening cytopenias, high-risk cytogenetics/genomics (e.g., chr 7 or 3 abnormalities, TP53 mutation, complex or monosomal karyotype), or therapy-related/evolving disease | Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML-1 or CMML-2) | Severe aplastic anemia | Relapsed Hodgkin lymphoma responding to therapy and relapsed after autologous HCT or ineligible for autologous HCT | Relapsed non-Hodgkin lymphoma responding to therapy and relapsed after autologous HCT or ineligible for autologous HCT | High-risk multiple myeloma following autologous HCT or relapsed multiple myeloma following autologous HCT with chemosensitive disease | Serum bilirubin <= 2 mg/dL (unless specified exceptions) | AST < 3 x ULN | ALT < 3 x ULN | Alkaline phosphatase < 3 x ULN | Creatinine clearance >= 50 mL/min | Left ventricular ejection fraction >= 45% | FEV1 >= 50% predicted | DLCO (corrected) >= 50% predicted | ECOG <=2
exclusion_criteria: Active extramedullary disease | Active central nervous system malignancy | Active or uncontrolled infection at time of allo-HCT | Prior allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation | Prior autologous HCT within the last 6 months (except high-risk multiple myeloma patients) | HIV I/II or HTLV I/II seropositivity | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Unwilling to use contraception during the study period | Unable to give informed consent or comply with protocol
prior_therapies: Failed or intolerant prior BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy for CML; Relapse after autologous hematopoietic cell transplant (Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin lymphoma); Prior autologous hematopoietic cell transplant for multiple myeloma (high-risk or relapsed)

patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; Moderate cerebellar dysfunction; ICARS score 35; Age 8 years; Female sex

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: An Open-label, Randomized, Controlled Phase 3 Study of Enfortumab Vedotin in Combination With Pembrolizumab Versus Chemotherapy Alone in Previously Untreated Locally Advanced or Metastatic Urothelial Cancer
brief_summary: This study is being done to see how well two drugs (enfortumab vedotin and pembrolizumab) work together to treat patients with urothelial cancer. The study will compare these drugs to other drugs that are usually used to treat this cancer (standard of care). The patients in this study will have cancer that has spread from their urinary system to other parts of their body.
interventions: {'id': 206107588, 'name': 'Enfortumab vedotin', 'description': 'Enfortumab vedotin administered as an IV infusion on Days 1 and 8 of every 3-week cycle', 'other_names': ['ASG-22CE', 'ASG-22ME', 'PADCEV'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206107589, 'name': 'Pembrolizumab', 'description': 'IV infusion on Day 1 of every 3-week cycle', 'other_names': ['Keytruda'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206107590, 'name': 'Cisplatin', 'description': 'administered as IV infusion on Day 1 of each 3-week cycle', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206107591, 'name': 'Carboplatin', 'description': 'Dosed according to local guidelines and will be administered as IV infusion on Day 1 of each 3-week cycle', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206107592, 'name': 'Gemcitabine', 'description': 'IV infusion on Days 1 and 8 of every 3 week cycle', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}

exclusion_criteria: Prior enfortumab vedotin or other MMAE-based antibody-drug conjugate | Prior PD-1 or PD-L1 inhibitor for any malignancy | Prior agent directed to another stimulatory or coinhibitory T-cell receptor | Anticancer treatment (chemotherapy, biologics, or investigational agents) not completed >=4 weeks prior to first dose | Uncontrolled diabetes | Estimated life expectancy <12 weeks | Active central nervous system metastases | Clinically significant toxicities from prior therapy not resolved to <= Grade 1 or baseline | Active systemic infection requiring antimicrobial treatment at randomization | Known active hepatitis B, active hepatitis C, or HIV infection | Another invasive malignancy within 3 years or residual disease from prior malignancy | Cerebrovascular event, unstable angina, myocardial infarction, or NYHA Class IV symptoms within 6 months | Radiotherapy within 2 weeks prior to randomization | Major surgery within 4 weeks prior to randomization | Severe (>= Grade 3) hypersensitivity to enfortumab vedotin excipients | Active keratitis or corneal ulcerations | Autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment in the past 2 years | History of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, organizing pneumonia, drug-induced pneumonitis, idiopathic pneumonitis, or active pneumonitis on screening CT | Prior allogeneic stem cell or solid organ transplant | Live attenuated vaccine within 30 days prior to randomization

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Autologous Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation for Refractory Crohn's Disease
brief_summary: Unfortunately, some patients with Crohn's disease (CD) fail to respond to the best clinical treatments and some only experience temporary benefit. For severe Crohn's disease, there is an experimental treatment called "high dose immunoablation" followed by autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). This study removes over active lymphocytes (immunoablation) and replaces them using blood stem cells that have been taken from the patient's own body. The aim of the study is to rese...
inclusion_criteria: Age 13–28 years. | Confirmed Crohn disease for >= 6 months prior to screening. | Active disease at registration: PCDAI > 30 plus at least two of the following: elevated CRP; endoscopic evidence of active disease confirmed by histology; active small bowel Crohn disease on CT or MR enterography. | Refractory course despite >= 3 immunosuppressive/biologic agents (e.g., azathioprine, methotrexate, infliximab/adalimumab/certolizumab) or intolerance/toxicity to these drugs. | Current problems unsuitable for surgery or at risk for short bowel syndrome.
exclusion_criteria: Pregnancy or unwillingness to use adequate contraception. | Renal impairment: creatinine clearance < 30 mL/min. | Cardiac disease: refractory congestive heart failure; left ventricular ejection fraction < 40%; chronic atrial fibrillation requiring oral anticoagulation; uncontrolled ventricular arrhythmia; pericardial effusion with hemodynamic consequences. | Pulmonary impairment: diffusion capacity < 40%. | Psychiatric disorders including active drug or alcohol abuse. | Concurrent or recent malignancy (excluding non-melanoma skin cancer). | Uncontrolled hypertension: resting systolic blood pressure >= 140 mmHg and/or diastolic >= 90 mmHg despite at least 2 antihypertensive agents. | Infection with HIV, HTLV-1/2, hepatitis viruses, or other infection considered a contraindication. | Current clinically relevant abscess or significant active infection. | Perianal fistula without free drainage (seton or natural free drainage required). | History of tuberculosis or increased risk; positive TB testing (e.g., Quantiferon Gold) or other evidence of active TB. | Abnormal chest X-ray consistent with active infection or neoplasm. | Significant malnutrition: BMI <= 18 kg/m^2 or serum albumin < 20 g/L. | Other chronic disease causing significant organ failure. | Previous poor compliance. | Concurrent enrollment in another protocol using an investigational drug or hematopoietic growth factor within 4 weeks before entry.
prior_therapies: Refractory to >= 3 immunosuppressive/biologic agents (e.g., azathioprine, methotrexate, anti-TNF agents).
reasoning: The patient is 32 years old, which is outside the trial’s eligible age range of 13–28 years, constituting a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active draining perianal fistula with seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: Age is a hard exclusion: patient is 32 while the trial requires 13–28 years. Disease matches, but hard exclusion applies, so F is correct.

Patients will receive pharmaceutical grade P5P according to their normal oral P5P dosing regimen, as previously established by their physicians.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. trial_title: Establishing Evidence-based Treatment for Speech and Language in Primary Progressive Aphasia
brief_summary: Primary progressive aphasia (PPA) is a progressive neurological disorder that causes a gradual decline in communication ability as a result of selective neurodegeneration of speech and language networks in the brain. PPA is a devastating condition affecting adults as young as their 40's or 50's, depriving them of the ability to communicate and function in society. There has been significant progress in discovering the neurobiological mechanisms that underlie PPA and in identifying its clinica...
interventions: {'id': 205697628, 'name': 'Lexical Retrieval Training (LRT)', 'description': 'In person or via teletherapy: Participants work on producing spoken and written names of personally relevant target items using a self-cueing hierarchy. Treatment focuses on the use of strategies that capitalize on spared cognitive-linguistic abilities to support word retrieval. The participant completes two (one hour each) sessions per week with a clinician plus daily home practice exercises.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'BEHAVIORAL'}; {'id': 205697629, 'name': 'Video-Implemented Script Training for Aphasia (VISTA)', 'description': 'In person or via teletherapy: Participants work on producing personally relevant scripts of 4-6 sentences in length. Length and complexity of scripts are individually tailored. The participant completes 30 minutes per day of home practice, during which they speak in unison with a video/audio model of a healthy speaker clearly articulating the scripts. Biweekly (one hour each) sessions with a clinician target clear and accurate script production, script memorization, and conversational usage of scripts.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'BEHAVIORAL'}

inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Diagnosis of myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm per WHO | CMML-1 or CMML-2 or higher-risk MDS (IPSS-R > 3.5 or TP53 mutation) with > 5% blasts, or MDS/MPN (other than CMML) with > 5% bone marrow blasts | Relapsed cohort: no response after 6 cycles of azacitidine, decitabine, guadecitabine, or decitabine-cedazuridine (ASTX727), or relapse/progression after any number of cycles | HMA-naive cohort: previously untreated CMML-1 or CMML-2 with intermediate-2 or high-risk IPSS, or higher-risk MDS (IPSS-R > 3.5 or TP53 mutation) with > 5% blasts, or MDS/MPN (other than CMML) with > 5% bone marrow blasts | ECOG performance status 0-2 | Left ventricular ejection fraction >= 50% | Serum creatinine <= 1.5 mg/dL | Serum albumin >= 3.2 g/dL (no IV albumin within 72 hours) | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 mg/dL | AST and ALT <= 2.5 x ULN | Creatine kinase <= 2.5 x ULN | Women of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy test prior to treatment | Agrees to use acceptable contraception during study and for 2 months after last tagraxofusp dose
exclusion_criteria: Persistent clinically significant toxicities >= Grade 2 from prior therapy (excluding alopecia, nausea, fatigue) | Chemotherapy, wide-field radiation, or biologic therapy within 14 days prior to study entry | Investigational agent within 14 days prior to study entry or concurrent investigational therapy | Prior treatment with tagraxofusp or hypersensitivity to its components | Active malignancy requiring therapy (except non-melanoma skin cancer, carcinoma in situ including superficial bladder cancer, cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, or organ-confined prostate cancer without progression) | Clinically significant cardiovascular disease (e.g., uncontrolled or NYHA Class 3 or 4 heart failure, uncontrolled angina, recent myocardial infarction, unstable angina, stroke within 6 months, uncontrolled hypertension, or significant arrhythmias not controlled by medication) | Uncontrolled, clinically significant pulmonary disease (e.g., COPD, pulmonary hypertension) posing significant risk | Known or suspected CNS involvement; if suspected, must be ruled out by imaging and/or CSF examination | Receiving immunosuppressive therapy (except <= 10 mg prednisone equivalent and tacrolimus for GVHD prophylaxis); active GVHD therapy must be stopped >= 14 days before study drug and no evidence of >= Grade 2 GVHD | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness including uncontrolled infection, disseminated intravascular coagulation, or psychiatric illness limiting compliance | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Known HIV infection | Active or chronic hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection | Oxygen-dependent | Any condition placing patient at unacceptably high risk for toxicities | Hydroxyurea permitted only if receiving prior to study entry and only during Cycle 1; use after Cycle 1 only with PI approval
prior_therapies: Relapsed cohort: prior hypomethylating agent (azacitidine, decitabine, guadecitabine, or decitabine-cedazuridine) >= 6 cycles with no response, or relapse/progression after any number of cycles; HMA-naive cohort allowed; Washout: no chemotherapy, wide-field radiation, biologic therapy, or investigational agents within 14 days prior to study entry; Hydroxyurea permitted during Cycle 1 only if patient was receiving it prior to study entry
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets CMML/MDS/MPN, not PMM2-CDG. Additionally, the patient is 8 years old while the trial requires age ≥18.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; Moderate cerebellar dysfunction; ICARS score 35; Age 8 years; Female sex
patient_prior_therapies: (none)
judge_comment: There is a hard exclusion due to disease mismatch (trial targets CMML/MDS/MPN, not PMM2-CDG) and another hard exclusion for age (trial requires ≥18; patient is 8). Under the rubric, any hard exclusion results in grade F. The grader correctly assigned F and cited appropriate reasons.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase II Multi-Arm (Basket) Trial Investigating the Safety and Efficacy of IO102-IO103 in Combination With Pembrolizumab, as First-Line Treatment for Patients With Metastatic NSCLC, SCCHN, or Metastatic mUBC
brief_summary: A Phase II Multi-Arm (basket) Trial Investigating the Safety and Efficacy of IO102-IO103 in Combination with pembrolizumab, as First-line Treatment for Patients with Metastatic Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC), Squamous Cell Carcinoma of Head or Neck (SCCHN), or Metastatic Urothelial Bladder Cancer (mUBC)
interventions: {'id': 205822618, 'name': 'IO102-IO103 in combination with pembrolizumab', 'description': 'The experimental drug IO102-IO103 is for SC injection and consist of IDO and PD-L1 peptides', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
diseases_targeted: Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (metastatic); Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma (metastatic); Urothelial Carcinoma (metastatic)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed metastatic NSCLC (Arm A), no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease | No known sensitizing EGFR or ALK mutations (NSCLC) | Recurrent or metastatic SCCHN considered incurable by local therapies, no prior therapy (Arm B) | Documented HPV status for oropharyngeal cancer (SCCHN) | Advanced/unresectable or metastatic urothelial carcinoma of renal pelvis, ureter, bladder, or urethra; transitional cell histology dominant if mixed (Arm C) | Metastatic UBC not eligible for any cisplatin therapy (Arm C) | All solitary metastases biopsied to confirm metastasis from primary indication | PD-L1 TPS >= 50% (NSCLC, Arm A) | PD-L1 CPS >= 20 (SCCHN, Arm B) | PD-L1 CPS >= 10 (mUBC, Arm C) | Age >= 18 years | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | Provision of blood sample and archival or new tumor tissue (non-irradiated lesion preferred) | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Recovered from major surgery prior to starting treatment | Adequate organ function per protocol
exclusion_criteria: Positive pregnancy test or pregnant/breastfeeding | Prior anti–PD-1/PD-L1/PD-L2 or other T-cell co-regulatory agent used in adjuvant/neoadjuvant setting with discontinuation due to >= Grade 3 immune-related adverse event | Prior systemic anti-cancer therapy in the first-line metastatic setting (neoadjuvant/adjuvant allowed if completed >= 6 months before metastatic diagnosis) | Unresolved toxicities from prior therapies > Grade 1 (except <= Grade 2 neuropathy) | Prior radiotherapy to the lung > 30 Gy within 6 months before start; radiation-related AEs not recovered; steroid requirement; or history of radiation pneumonitis | Life expectancy < 3 months or rapidly progressing disease | Live or live-attenuated vaccine within 30 days prior to first dose | Participation in a trial with an investigational agent within 30 days prior to entry or investigational device within 6 months (unless in follow-up and >= 6 months since last dose) | Immunodeficiency | Systemic or topical corticosteroids at immunosuppressive doses within 2 weeks prior to treatment initiation (> 10 mg/day hydrocortisone or > 5 mg/day prednisone equivalent) | Another malignancy that is progressing or required active treatment within the past 2 years (exceptions: certain in situ or skin cancers) | Active CNS metastases and/or carcinomatous meningitis (unless previously treated and radiologically and clinically stable without steroids >= 14 days) | Severe hypersensitivity (>= Grade 3) to IO102, IO103, pembrolizumab, or excipients | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment in past 2 years (replacement therapy allowed) | History of non-infectious pneumonitis requiring steroids or current pneumonitis | Active infection requiring systemic therapy | Known HIV infection | Adrenal insufficiency (basal cortisol < 140 nmol/L or < 5 µg/dL) | Known chronic Hepatitis B (HBsAg reactive) or active Hepatitis C infection (HCV RNA detected) | Any condition, therapy, or lab abnormality that may confound results or is not in the patient’s best interest per investigator | Psychiatric or substance abuse disorders interfering with trial requirements | Planning to conceive or father children during treatment and required post-treatment period | History of allogeneic tissue/solid organ transplant | Progressive disease within 6 months of completion of curatively intended systemic treatment for locoregionally advanced SCCHN | Nasopharyngeal tumors (any histology) excluded (SCCHN)
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease; Neoadjuvant/adjuvant therapy allowed if completed >= 6 months before metastatic diagnosis; No prior anti–PD-1/PD-L1/PD-L2 or other T-cell co-regulatory agent leading to discontinuation for >= Grade 3 immune-related AE; Not eligible for any cisplatin therapy (mUBC); Palliative radiotherapy (<= 2 weeks) to non-CNS disease allowed with >= 1-week washout; No investigational agents within 30 days prior to study entry
reasoning: This trial is first-line only and explicitly excludes patients with any prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease; the patient received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab and is post–second line. Additionally, the trial requires PD-L1 CPS ≥10 for mUBC, which is unknown here but the prior therapy already disqualifies.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progression after second-line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab; Bone and liver metastases; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD; Age 55 years; Male sex
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: the trial explicitly excludes anyone with prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease (first-line setting only), while the patient is post–second line with prior enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab. PD-L1 status being unknown is not needed to trigger F. The grader’s F is correct.

trial_title: MAIN-CAV: Phase III Randomized Trial of Maintenance Cabozantinib and Avelumab vs Maintenance Avelumab After First-Line Platinum-Based Chemotherapy in Patients With Metastatic Urothelial Cancer
brief_summary: This phase III trial compares the effect of adding cabozantinib to avelumab versus avelumab alone in treating patients with urothelial cancer that has spread from where it first started (primary site) to other places in the body (metastatic). Cabozantinib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. Immunotherapy with monoclonal antibodies, such as avelumab, may help the body's immune system attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of...

inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, renal pelvis, ureter, or urethra (excluding small-cell histology). | Received 4–6 cycles of first-line platinum-based chemotherapy (gemcitabine-cisplatin, gemcitabine-carboplatin, MVAC or ddMVAC). | No more than 1 prior line of chemotherapy for metastatic or locally advanced disease. | Neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy allowed if given >= 12 months prior to registration. | Tumor response of CR, PR, or SD after completion of first-line platinum-based chemotherapy by treating physician assessment. | Last dose of first-line chemotherapy 3–10 weeks before randomization. | Age >= 18 years. | ECOG performance status 0–1. | Not pregnant and not nursing. | HIV-infected patients on effective antiretroviral therapy with undetectable viral load within 6 months are eligible. | Autoimmune/rheumatologic conditions controlled without systemic immunosuppression (<= 10 mg prednisone equivalent) are eligible; stable endocrine disorders and type 1 diabetes are eligible.
exclusion_criteria: Prior immunotherapy with IL-2, IFN-alpha, anti-PD-1, anti-PD-L1, anti-PD-L2, anti-CD137, or CTLA-4 (including ipilimumab), or other agents targeting T-cell co-stimulation or immune failure NYHA class III or IV. | Uncontrolled hypertension: sustained BP > 150/90 mm Hg despite optimal therapy. | QTcF > 500 ms (unless resolved on repeat testing) or any history of congenital long QT incidental events). | Significant gastrointestinal disorders with high risk of perforation/fistula or obstruction (e.g., unresolved active peptic ulcer disease, cholecystitis, diverticulitis, symptomatic cholangitis or appendicitis, malabsorption) within 28 days. | Active infection requiring systemic treatment within 14 days before randomization. | Serious non-healing wound, ulcer, or bone reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with prior anti–PD-1/PD-L1 therapy, and the patient received pembrolizumab. Additionally, this is a maintenance study immediately after first-line platinum with response, which does not fit this post–second-line, progressed setting.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progression after second-line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab; Bone and liver metastases; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD; Age 55 years; Male sex

judge_comment: Correct: The trial explicitly excludes prior anti–PD-1/PD-L1 therapy, and the patient received pembrolizumab. That is a HARD EXCLUSION → F. The noted maintenance-setting mismatch further supports ineligibility but is not needed once the hard exclusion applies.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: A Phase 3, Multicenter, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Mitapivat in Pediatric Subjects With Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency Who Are Regularly Transfused, Followed by a 5-Year Open-label Extension Period
brief_summary: ACTIVATE-KidsT (AG348-C-022) is a multicenter study designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of treatment with mitapivat compared with placebo in pediatric participants with pyruvate kinase deficiency (PK deficiency) who are regularly receiving blood transfusions. Randomization will be stratified by age (1 to \< 6 years, 6 to \< 12 years, 12 to \< 18 years) and splenectomy status. Participants will be dos...

reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets pyruvate kinase deficiency with PKLR mutations, while the patient has ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency. Additionally, the patient is 3 months old, below the trial’s minimum age of 1 year.

trial_title: Precise Infliximab Exposure and Pharmacodynamic Control to Achieve Deep Remission in Pediatric Crohn's Disease
brief_summary: Approximately 3 million people in the United States are living with inflammatory bowel disease, which includes Crohn's Disease (CD). There are limited treatment options approved for use in children and adults with Crohn's disease. Physicians need better ways to inform decisions on treatment. The main reason for this research study is to determine if a computer program that calculates an individualized dose based on a patient's blood testing results (precision dosing) can better achieve the be...
interventions: {'id': 205970604, 'name': 'RoadMAB', 'description': 'The RoadMAB Dashboard is a real-time decision support system that incorporates PK model-informed Bayesian estimation to provide precision dosing at the point of care.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DEVICE'}; {'id': 205970605, 'name': 'Infliximab', 'description': 'Conventional dosing. Induction: 5-7.5 mg/kg at 0, 2, and 6 weeks. Maintenance: 5-10 mg/kg at every 4-8 weeks based on results of drug concentration monitoring for a flat target of 5-10 μg/mL.\n\nPrecision dosing. Induction: 5-12.5 mg/kg at 0, 2, and 6 weeks to target a week6 concentration of 18-24 μg/mL with dosing support provided by the RoadMABTM clinical decision support tool. Maintenance: 5-15 mg/kg every 4-8 weeks to achieve apriori pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic targets (CRP, disease activity scores and fecal calprotectin) with dosing support provided by the RoadMABTM clinical decision support tool.', 'other_names': ['Avsola', 'Inflectra', 'Ixifi', 'Remicade', 'Renflexis'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}

exclusion_criteria: Active central nervous system involvement by malignancy | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness | Active infection requiring systemic therapy | Hematopoietic stem cell transplant within 90 days or graft-versus-host disease grade > 1 | Severe pulmonary disease with hypoxemia | History of another malignancy except adequately treated non-melanoma skin cancer or lentigo maligna, superficial bladder cancer, carcinoma in situ of the cervix without evidence of disease, and asymptomatic prostate cancer without known metastatic disease and no requirement for therapy | Concurrent treatment with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors or within 15 days of starting study treatment | Prior exposure to a CDK9 inhibitor | Receipt of investigational or approved anticancer therapies within 5 half-lives or 14 days prior to start of study treatment (whichever is shorter) | Mean corrected QT interval > 470 msec or history of long QT syndrome | T-cell leukemias
prior_therapies: Washout from prior investigational or approved anticancer therapy: >= 5 half-lives or 14 days before study treatment (whichever is shorter)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for relapsed/refractory hematologic malignancies, not PMM2-CDG. Additionally, the patient is 8 years old, below the trial’s minimum age of 18.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; Moderate cerebellar dysfunction; ICARS score 35; Age 8 years; Female sex
patient_prior_therapies: (none)
judge_comment: Correct: There is a clear hard exclusion due to disease mismatch (trial is for specific hematologic malignancies; patient has PMM2-CDG) and an age conflict (trial min age 18 vs patient age 8). Either warrants an F per the rubric.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A First-in-Human, Multicenter, Phase 1/2, Open-Label Study of XTX301 in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors
brief_summary: This is a first-in-human, multicenter, Phase 1/2, open-label study designed to evaluate the safety and tolerability of XTX301 as monotherapy in patients with advanced solid tumors.
interventions: {'id': 206552153, 'name': 'XTX301', 'description': 'XTX301 monotherapy', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
diseases_targeted: Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma; Melanoma; Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer; Ovarian Cancer; Castrate-Resistant Prostate Cancer; Triple-Negative Breast Cancer; Cervical Cancer; Colorectal Cancer (MSI-H/dMMR); Endometrial Cancer (MSI-H/dMMR)
inclusion_criteria: Locally advanced or metastatic solid tumor that has failed standard therapy, lacks survival benefit from standard therapy, or for which standard therapy is not available (Phase 1A) | Select advanced solid tumors for Part 1B: melanoma, NSCLC, HNSCC, TNBC, cervical cancer, MSI-H/dMMR colorectal cancer, or MSI-H/dMMR endometrial cancer | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 (Phase 2) | HNSCC (Cohort 2A): locally recurrent or metastatic; previously treated with 1–2 lines; unless contraindicated, prior PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor and/or platinum-based chemotherapy required | Melanoma (Cohort 2B): unresectable or metastatic; previously treated with 1–2 lines; unless contraindicated, prior PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor required; if BRAF V600 mutation present, prior targeted therapy required; uveal melanoma excluded | NSCLC (Cohort 2C): locally advanced or metastatic; previously treated with 1–2 lines; unless contraindicated, prior PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor and platinum-based regimen required; if actionable driver present (e.g., EGFR, ALK, ROS1, NTRK, BRAF V600E), prior targeted therapy required | Ovarian cancer (Cohort 2D): epithelial ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal cancer with platinum-resistant disease; prior response to first-line platinum lasting >= 180 days; platinum-intolerant also eligible; unless contraindicated, if BRCA mutation known, prior PARP inhibitor required | Castrate-resistant prostate cancer (Cohort 2E): metastatic CRPC; prior androgen receptor pathway inhibitor and/or chemotherapy; surgical or ongoing medical castration maintained | Triple-negative breast cancer (Cohort 2F): metastatic TNBC with relapse after 2–4 prior lines (neoadjuvant/adjuvant counts as 1) | ECOG performance status 0–2 (Phase 1) | ECOG performance status 0–1 (Phase 2) | Adequate organ function | Part 1B: lesions amenable to biopsy and willingness to provide fresh tumor biopsies pre- and on-treatment | Recovered from recent major surgery with no ongoing complications prior to study drug
exclusion_criteria: Prior treatment with IL-12 therapy (any form, including recombinant, prodrug, or intratumoral) | Known liver metastasis on imaging | Ongoing non-disease-related necrosis such as active ulcer, nonhealing wound, or intercurrent bone fracture | Active primary CNS malignancy, CNS metastases, or carcinomatous meningitis | Active autoimmune disease | History of Grade >= 3 immune-related adverse events from prior immunotherapy unless resolved with therapy within 14 days | Immunodeficiency diagnosis or chronic systemic immunosuppression exceeding prednisone 10 mg daily (or equivalent) within 7 days before first dose | Active hepatitis B infection | Active hepatitis C infection | Prior treatment with gene therapy | History of organ transplant | History of hematopoietic stem-cell transplant
prior_therapies: Failed, no benefit from, or no available standard therapy (Phase 1); HNSCC: prior PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor and/or platinum-based chemotherapy unless contraindicated; Melanoma: prior PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor; if BRAF V600 mutated, prior BRAF-targeted therapy; NSCLC: prior PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor and platinum-based chemotherapy; prior targeted therapy if actionable driver present (e.g., EGFR, ALK, ROS1, NTRK, BRAF V600E); Ovarian cancer: prior response to first-line platinum >= 180 days; prior PARP inhibitor if BRCA mutated; platinum-intolerant eligible; CRPC: prior androgen receptor pathway inhibitor and/or chemotherapy; ongoing surgical or medical castration; TNBC: 2–4 prior lines in the metastatic setting; neoadjuvant/adjuvant counts as 1 line
reasoning: While the disease type (mCRPC) and prior AR-targeted therapies fit, the trial explicitly excludes patients with known liver metastasis on imaging, and the patient has liver metastases.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Male sex; Age 66 years; Castration-resistant prostate cancer; Metastatic disease; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Androgen deprivation therapy (leuprolide); Abiraterone (Zytiga); Enzalutamide (progression on)
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes patients with known liver metastases on imaging, and the patient has PSMA PET–avid liver metastases. This is a hard exclusion, so grade F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: The ENERGY Study: An Open-Label Study to Evaluate the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, and Pharmacodynamics of INZ-701 in Infants With Ectonucleotide Pyrophosphatase/ Phosphodiesterase 1 (ENPP1) Deficiency or ATP-binding Cassette Sub-family C Member 6 (ABCC6) Deficiency
brief_summary: The primary purpose of Study INZ701-104 (the ENERGY study) is to assess the safety and tolerability of INZ-701 in infants with ENPP1 Deficiency or with ABCC6 Deficiency.

exclusion_criteria: Clinically significant disease or laboratory abnormality unrelated to ENPP1 or ABCC6 deficiency that may preclude participation, including uncontrolled thyroid disease or unrelated connective tissue, bone, mineral, or muscle disease | Care withdrawn or receiving end of life care or hospice only | Known malignancy | Known intolerance to INZ-701 or any excipients | Concurrent participation in another non-Inozyme interventional study | Receipt of any non-Inozyme investigational new drug within 5 half-lives or within 4 weeks prior to first dose, whichever is longer, or use of an investigational device
prior_therapies: No investigational drug within 5 half-lives or 4 weeks prior to first dose
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial enrolls infants with ENPP1 or ABCC6 deficiency (GACI), whereas the patient has genetically confirmed OTC deficiency. Therefore the patient does not meet the required disease/biomarker cohort.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; Age 3 months; Male; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Stable on dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers
patient_prior_therapies: Dietary protein restriction; Ammonia scavengers
judge_comment: Correct: The patient has OTC deficiency, while the trial only includes ENPP1 or ABCC6 deficiency (GACI). This is a hard disease/required biomarker mismatch, triggering an F regardless of other factors.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Clinical, Imaging, and Endoscopic Outcomes of Children Newly Diagnosed With Crohn's Disease
brief_summary: Crohn's disease (CD) is a condition that causes inflammation (swelling, redness) of the lining and wall of the small intestine, large intestine, or both. CD may be associated with abdominal cramps/pain, diarrhea, blood in the stool, weight loss, or delayed growth in children. While the exact cause of CD is not certain it is thought that the immune system located in the intestine reacts abnormally to the large number of bacteria contained there. The investigators think that diet, exposure to a...
interventions: {'id': 206227805, 'name': 'Anti-TNF therapy', 'description': "Use of anti-TNF therapy for children and adolescents with newly diagnosed Crohn's disease guided by a clinical decision support tool", 'other_names': ['Remicade, Inflectra, Renflexis, Avsola, Humira, Amgevita, Hulio, Hadlima, Hyrimoz, Idacio'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 6 years and < 18 years | Suspected Crohn disease at initial evaluation (Phase 1) | Negative stool culture for enteric pathogens and negative Clostridium difficile toxin if presenting with diarrhea | History of C. difficile requires >= 6 weeks from treatment start and negative repeat stool for C. difficile toxin | Diagnosed with macroscopic Crohn disease involving terminal ileum and/or colon by endoscopy and/or MRE (Phase 2) | Received at least one initial therapy upon diagnosis: corticosteroids, immunomodulator, aminosalicylic acids (5-ASA), defined nutritional therapy, or anti-TNF (adalimumab or infliximab) (Phase 2) | Commenced adalimumab or infliximab as first therapy or within 180 days of diagnosis, with or without concomitant immunomodulator (Phase 2) | Ileal and rectal biopsies obtained, or acceptable alternatives with documented terminal ileum inflammation by MRE and endoscopic findings (Phase 2)
exclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of Crohn disease following abdominal resectional surgery/appendectomy at initial presentation | High likelihood (>50%) of needing bowel resection within 3 months of diagnosis (e.g., perforation, obstructive stricture) | Use of oral corticosteroids for non-gastrointestinal indications within 4 weeks prior to diagnostic assessment and biosampling | Use of any investigational drug within 4 weeks prior to diagnostic assessment and sampling | Pregnancy | Poorly controlled medical conditions (e.g., diabetes, congestive heart failure) | Previous treatment with immunomodulators within 1 year of enrollment for other medical conditions | Previous treatment with anti-TNF therapy within 2 years of enrollment for other medical conditions | Previous treatment with non-anti-TNF biologics or small molecules for non-IBD indications within 6 months (except dupilumab) | Inability to undergo MRE | Diagnosis of Crohn disease using video capsule endoscopy only with normal ileocolonoscopy and normal MRE (Phase 2) | Orofacial Crohn disease only (Phase 2) | Esophageal, gastric, duodenal, and/or jejunal Crohn disease only (Phase 2) | Severe complex fistulizing perianal disease +/- abscess or perianal disease requiring ongoing surgical intervention (seton placement or I&D alone not exclusionary) (Phase 2) | Perianal Crohn disease only without luminal disease (Phase 2) | Internal fistulizing disease at diagnosis (Phase 2) | Initial IBD treatment with non-anti-TNF biologic or small molecule therapy (Phase 2) | Received any anti-TNF agent other than adalimumab or infliximab (Phase 2) | Unlikely to return for clinical, endoscopic, or MRE follow-up (Phase 2) | Baseline endoscopy video unavailable for central reading without approved alternative documentation (Phase 2) | Underwent bowel resection within 3 months of diagnosis (Phase 2)

reasoning: Age window conflict: the trial enrolls participants aged 6–17, while the patient is 32. Additionally, the study focuses on newly diagnosed pediatric Crohn’s, not a refractory adult case.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active draining perianal fistula with seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: Age window conflict (patient 32 vs trial 6–17) is a hard exclusion, so F is correct. The grader’s added note about newly diagnosed pediatric setting further supports ineligibility but the age alone triggers F.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). exclusion_criteria: History of arthritis with onset before age 17 years or current inflammatory joint disease other than rheumatoid arthritis. | Prior exposure to any JAK inhibitor. | Prior exposure to adalimumab. | Prior exposure to any TNF inhibitor other than infliximab, etanercept, certolizumab pegol, or golimumab. | Prior exposure to any non-TNFi biologic DMARD or targeted synthetic DMARD.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?

There will be no comparison of coformulated favezelimab/pembrolizumab plus EV versus coformulated vibostolimab/pembrolizumab plus EV. If ORR and/or DRR are substantially better...

judge_comment: Disease mismatch (PMM2-CDG vs PKP2-ACM), age below minimum (8 < 18), and required biomarker mismatch (PKP2 truncating variant required) are all hard exclusions. Grade F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? trial_title: A Phase II Study of Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation With Briquilimab-Based Conditioning in Participants With GATA2 Deficiency
brief_summary: Background: People with GATA2 deficiency have a mutation on the GATA2 gene. This gene affects immune function. People with this disease are prone to serious infections; in time, they may develop blood cancers. A hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplant can cure GATA2 deficiency, but using stem cells donated by other people can cause serious side effects. Objective: To test a new drug (Briquilimab) to see if it can make HSC transplants safer. Eligibility: People aged 6 to 70 years who have GAT...
interventions: {'id': 206555416, 'name': 'Mycophenolate Mofetil', 'description': '15 mg/kg IV three times per day starting on day +5 until approximately day +30 (+/- 2 days)', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206555417, 'name': 'Tacrolimus', 'description': '0.02 mg/kg IV daily starting on day +5', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206555418, 'name': 'Post-Transplant Cyclophosphamide', 'description': '50 mg/kg IV daily on days +3 and +4', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206555419, 'name': 'Total Body Irradiation', 'description': '200cGy on day -1', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'RADIATION'}; {'id': 206555420, 'name': 'Hematopoietic Cell Transplant', 'description': 'stem cell transplant on day 0', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'PROCEDURE'}; {'id': 206555421, 'name': 'Briquilimab', 'description': 'Single 0.6 mg/kg IV infusion administered between days -13 and day -10', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206555422, 'name': 'Cyclophosphamide', 'description': '14.5 mg/kg IV daily on days -6 and -5; for 7/8 Unrelated or Haploidentical Donor, prior to transplant.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206555423, 'name': 'Fludarabine', 'description': '30 mg/m2 IV over 30 minutes daily. For 8/8 Matched Related or Unrelated Donor, fludarabine dose will be on days -4, -3, and -2. For 7/8 Unrelated or Haploidentical Donor, fludarabine dose will be on days -6, -5, -4, -3, and -2.', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Age 6–70 years | Germline deleterious mutation in GATA2 confirmed by targeted sequencing | Clinical manifestations consistent with GATA2 deficiency (e.g., severe/recurrent infections; monocytes <190/µL, B cells <61/µL, NK cells <126/µL; myelodysplastic syndrome by WHO) | Early-stage GATA2 deficiency: hypocellular marrow for age, <5% blasts, and normal/favorable cytogenetics (good/very good risk groups plus trisomy 8) | Availability of suitable donor: 8/8 HLA-matched related or unrelated, 7/8 HLA-matched unrelated, or haploidentical related donor | Karnofsky or Lansky performance status >= 40% | Left ventricular ejection fraction > 40% | Total bilirubin <= 2.5 x ULN | AST and ALT <= 5 x ULN | Adult creatinine <= 2.0 mg/dL and creatinine clearance >= 30 mL/min | Pediatric creatinine < 1.5 mg/dL and creatinine clearance > 30 mL/min/1.73m^2 | Pulmonary function: FEV1 and adjusted DLCO > 30%; if unable to perform due to age, no dyspnea at rest and no supplemental oxygen requirement | HBV or HCV seropositive allowed if HBV DNA <100 IU/mL or HCV RNA undetectable and hepatology approval
exclusion_criteria: Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation-Comorbidity Index (HCT-CI) score > 8 | Receipt of investigational agents within 4 weeks before treatment initiation (except virus-specific T cells for treatment of viral infection/reactivation prior to allogeneic HCT) | History of hematologic malignancy (e.g., AML, CMML); MDS allowed | History of allergic reactions to compounds similar to study agents (fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, tacrolimus, mycophenolate, G-CSF) | Presence of active malignancy (virus-driven malignancies allowed); MDS allowed | HIV infection | Pregnancy | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness or social situations limiting compliance with study requirements
prior_therapies: No investigational agents within 4 weeks before treatment initiation (except virus-specific T cells for viral infection/reactivation)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets GATA2 deficiency, not OTC deficiency. Additionally, the trial requires age 6–70 years and a confirmed GATA2 germline mutation, while the patient is 3 months old with an OTC mutation.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; Age 3 months; Male; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Stable on dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers
patient_prior_therapies: Dietary protein restriction; Ammonia scavengers
judge_comment: Clear hard exclusions: disease mismatch (GATA2 vs OTC), age below minimum (3 months vs 6 years), and required GATA2 mutation absent. F is appropriate and the reasoning aligns with the rubric.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Pilot Trial of Enfortumab Vedotin Schedule De-escalation in Metastatic Urothelial Carcinoma
brief_summary: This is a non-randomized two arm open-label phase 2 pilot study in adult subjects with locally advanced or metastatic urothelial cancer. The study will investigate an alternative administration schedule of EV given as monotherapy and in combination with pembrolizumab.
interventions: {'id': 206015742, 'name': 'Enfortumab vedotin', 'description': 'EV will be administered at standard dose of 1.25 mg/kg IV on days 1 and 8 with pembrolizumab 200 mg IV on day 1 of a 21-day cycle for 6 cycles', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206015743, 'name': 'Pembrolizumab', 'description': 'Pembrolizumab will be administered on day 1 of a 21-day cycle', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Histologically and radiographically confirmed locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma | Measurable disease per RECIST v1.1 | ECOG performance status 0-2 | Age >= 18 years | Prior systemic therapy completed >= 14 days before treatment | Normal organ and marrow function
exclusion_criteria: Prior monomethyl auristatin E (MMAE)-based antibody-drug conjugate for urothelial cancer | Baseline sensory or motor neuropathy grade >= 2 | Uncontrolled diabetes (HbA1c > 8%) | Uncontrolled or untreated central nervous system metastases | Leptomeningeal disease | Active untreated infection requiring systemic antimicrobial therapy | Symptomatic congestive heart failure, unstable angina, or uncontrolled cardiac arrhythmia | Psychiatric illness or social situation limiting compliance with study requirements | Another invasive malignancy within 3 years requiring treatment or with residual disease requiring treatment (adjuvant endocrine therapy for breast cancer allowed) | Known HIV-positive on combination antiretroviral therapy | History of interstitial lung disease or pneumonitis (including drug-induced) or active pneumonitis on screening CT | Prior allogeneic stem cell or solid organ transplant | Active tuberculosis | Pregnant or breastfeeding | EV/pembrolizumab arm: prior immunotherapy with immune-related adverse event requiring cessation or immunosuppression | EV/pembrolizumab arm: active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment within the past 2 years | EV/pembrolizumab arm: receiving high-dose steroids > 20 mg/day prednisone or equivalent at enrollment
prior_therapies: Prior systemic therapy completed >= 14 days before treatment
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with prior MMAE-based antibody-drug conjugate therapy for urothelial cancer, and the patient received enfortumab vedotin (an MMAE-based ADC). Although the disease and setting match, this hard exclusion makes the patient ineligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progression after second-line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Received enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab; Bone and liver metastases; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD; Age 55 years; Male sex
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes prior MMAE-based ADC exposure; the patient previously received enfortumab vedotin (MMAE-based), which is a hard exclusion per the rubric. Thus F is correct.

exclusion_criteria: Other known causes of hemolysis in addition to PKD | Venous thromboembolism or arteriothromboembolic event within the prior 12 months | Bridging fibrosis, cirrhosis, or active hepatitis on liver biopsy | Cardiac T2* <10 ms by MRI | Left ventricular ejection fraction <45% | Severe iron overload warranting exclusion per investigator | Documented HIV infection | Active viral hepatitis | Poorly controlled hypertension | Pulmonary hypertension | Cardiac arrhythmia | Congestive heart failure | Stroke or myocardial infarction within the prior 12 months | Active hematologic or solid organ malignancy (except non-melanoma skin cancer or carcinoma in situ) | History of malignancy without evidence of disease for <3 years | Uncontrolled seizure disorder | ALT >2.5 x ULN | AST >2.5 x ULN | Serum creatinine > ULN unless eGFR >=60 mL/min/1.73m2 | Need for supplemental oxygen in the prior 2 weeks (in absence of acute infection) | Clinically significant pulmonary disease impairing ability to tolerate procedures | Contraindication to leukapheresis | Karnofsky Index <70% (>=16 years) or Lansky <70% (<16 years) | Participation in another clinical trial with an investigational drug within 14 days before consent | Pregnant, breastfeeding, or planning pregnancy within 24 months; inadequate contraception | Previous allogeneic or other hematopoietic stem cell transplant
prior_therapies: No investigational drugs within 14 days prior to consent; Mitapivat discontinued >=90 days before start of mobilization
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency, while the patient has Ornithine Transcarbamylase deficiency. Additionally, the patient is 3 months old, below the trial’s 8–55 year age range.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; Age 3 months; Male; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Stable on dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers
patient_prior_therapies: Dietary protein restriction; Ammonia scavengers

prior_therapies: Prior participation in the COMPOSE pegtibatinase study; Completed 24-week blinded period on full target dose in the HARMONY study

trial_title: Resilient Together for Dementia: a Live Video Resiliency Dyadic Intervention for Persons with Dementia and Their Care-partners Early After Diagnosis
brief_summary: This study will evaluate the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the novel Resilient Together for Dementia (RT-D) intervention for couples following dementia diagnoses. The primary target is emotional distress, and the program aims to prevent chronic distress in at-risk couples.

RT-D was developed based on the Recovering Together (RT) dyadic intervention for acute neurological illnesses and is being adapted to address the needs of couples navigating new dementia diagnoses.', 'other_names': ['RT-D'], 'intervention_type': 'BEHAVIORAL'}; {'id': 206013417, 'name': 'MEUC', 'description': 'The MEUC condition was also developed based on the comparison trial in the Recovering Together dyadic intervention, and was adapted based on feedback from prior studies. The program is self-guided and provides educational information similar to the RT-D condition, but with no skills practice or weekly sessions with a therapist.', 'other_names': ['Minimally enhanced usual care'], 'intervention_type': 'BEHAVIORAL'}
inclusion_criteria: Recent (~3 months) chart-documented Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) diagnosis | ADRD symptom onset after age 65 | Early stage dementia with Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) score 0.5 or 1.0 | Cognitive awareness of problems and ability to understand study protocol as determined by standardized teach-back assessment | English-speaking adults (>=18 years) in a dyad | Dyad lives together | At least one partner with clinically significant emotional distress at screening: >7 on Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale subscales or <5 on the Geriatric Depression Scale
exclusion_criteria: Patient deemed inappropriate by the neurology team | Either partner has a co-occurring terminal illness | Diagnosis of dementia with clinical profile that would preclude participation (e.g., frontotemporal dementia-behavioral variant) as determined by treatment team
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial requires early-stage dementia (CDR 0.5–1.0) soon after diagnosis, whereas the patient has moderate-stage dementia (MMSE 19), indicating they do not meet the required stage/setting.
patient_biomarkers: Elevated p-tau; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative
patient_inclusion_criteria: Male; Age 68 years; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated p-tau
patient_prior_therapies: (none)
judge_comment: The trial requires early-stage dementia (CDR 0.5–1.0) shortly after diagnosis. The patient has moderate-stage dementia (MMSE 19), definitively lacking the required stage/setting. inclusion_criteria: Histologic and/or cytologic confirmation of prostate adenocarcinoma | Agree to tumor biopsy of a primary or metastatic lesion during screening or provide archival biopsy obtained after development of castration resistance within 1 year prior to randomization | Serum testosterone <50 ng/dL during screening | Progressed on one prior second-generation androgen receptor signaling inhibitor (abiraterone, enzalutamide, apalutamide, or darolutamide) | Progressive metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer at screening | At least 1 metastatic lesion on CT, MRI, or bone scan obtained within 28 days prior to randomization | Adequate organ function at screening and reconfirmed on Study Day -1 or Day 1
exclusion_criteria: Prior treatment with a therapeutic targeting CD46 | Small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma (pure or mixed) or any non-adenocarcinoma component on histology | More than one prior second-generation ARSI in any setting | Receipt of any systemic anticancer therapy within 28 days prior to randomization | Receipt of any prior radiation therapy within 28 days prior to randomization | Known actionable mutation or gene alteration (e.g., BRCA1) with available approved therapies unless not appropriate or patient refuses such therapy | CTCAE Grade >=2 peripheral neuropathy at screening from any etiology | Any prior chemotherapy; exception: one prior taxane-based chemotherapy in the castration-sensitive setting allowed if completed >12 months before randomization | Known hypersensitivity to FG-3246 components or analogs or history of allergic/anaphylactic reaction to human, humanized, or chimeric monoclonal antibodies | Diagnosis of any other malignancy within the past 5 years except adequately treated basal cell or squamous cell carcinoma of the skin | Requires treatment with a strong CYP3A4 inhibitor or inducer that cannot be safely discontinued
prior_therapies: Required: exactly one prior second-generation ARSI (abiraterone, enzalutamide, apalutamide, or darolutamide); Allowed: one prior taxane-based chemotherapy in the castration-sensitive setting if completed >12 months before randomization; Washout: no systemic anticancer therapy within 28 days prior to randomization; Washout: no prior radiation therapy within 28 days prior to randomization
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with more than one prior second-generation ARSI; this patient received both abiraterone and enzalutamide. Therefore, they fail a hard exclusion despite otherwise matching mCRPC, age, and sex.
