question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Evaluating the Efficacy and Safety of Mirikizumab in Adults Over 60 With Moderate to Severe Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis: A Phase IV Multicenter Interventional Study
brief_summary: This research study looks at how safe and effective a medicine called Mirikizumab is for treating older adults (aged 60 and above) who have moderate to severe Crohn's disease (CD) or ulcerative colitis (UC). These two conditions, known as inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), cause inflammation (swelling and irritation) in the digestive tract. Older adults with these conditions often have other health issues and face increased risks and complications, making it challenging for them to use certai...
interventions: {'id': 206259044, 'name': 'Mirikizumab', 'description': "Mirikizumab will be administered to participants according to FDA-approved dosing guidelines for moderate-to-severe Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis. Participants will receive scheduled doses throughout the study period at predefined intervals. Clinical assessments, patient-reported outcomes, biomarker analyses, and safety monitoring will occur at baseline and at Weeks 12, 24, and 48.", 'other_names': ['Mirikizumab Treatment Group'], 'intervention_type': 'BIOLOGICAL'}
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 60 years | Moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease (CDAI >= 220) or moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis (Mayo Score >= 6) | Able to provide informed consent
exclusion_criteria: Major gastrointestinal surgery within 3 months | Active infection requiring antibiotic or antiviral treatment | Active malignancy or history of malignancy within 5 years (except fully resected basal cell or squamous cell skin cancer with no metastatic disease for >= 3 years) | Participation in another clinical trial with investigational therapy within 30 days | Contraindication or known hypersensitivity to biologic medications, specifically mirikizumab | Unstable angina, myocardial infarction, or cardiovascular procedures within the past 6 months | Uncontrolled hypertension (systolic >= 160 mmHg or diastolic >= 100 mmHg despite treatment) | Congestive heart failure (NYHA Class III or IV) | Clinically significant arrhythmias or other unstable cardiovascular conditions
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial requires age 60–99, but the patient is 32, which is outside the allowed window. Although the disease (Crohn’s disease) matches, the age criterion is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active draining perianal fistula with seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: Patient is 32, while trial minimum age is 60. Age window conflict is a hard exclusion per rubric, so F is correct. Disease otherwise matches; no need to assess anchors once hard exclusion applies.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: 18-month Double-blind, Randomized, Placebo-controlled, Multicenter, Phase 3 Study to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of Oral Nizubaglustat (AZ-3102) in Late-infantile and Juvenile Forms of Niemann-Pick Type C Disease and in Late-infantile and Juvenile-onset Forms of GM1 Gangliosidosis or GM2 Gangliosidosis
brief_summary: An 18-month double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, multicenter, Phase 3 study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of oral nizubaglustat (AZ-3102) in late-infantile and juvenile forms of GM1 gangliosidosis or GM2 gangliosidosis
interventions: {'id': 206423285, 'name': 'AZ-3102', 'description': 'Nizubaglustat', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}; {'id': 206423286, 'name': 'Placebo', 'description': 'Placebo', 'other_names': [], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Confirmed GM1 gangliosidosis or Tay-Sachs, Sandhoff, or GM2AB variant | Age >= 4 years | Neurologic symptom onset between 1 and 10 years of age | Ataxic disturbances with total SARA score >= 3 and <= 30 at Baseline | Females of childbearing potential who are sexually active willing to follow contraceptive guidance | Male participants with a female partner of childbearing potential willing to follow contraceptive guidance
exclusion_criteria: Medical conditions other than GM1 or GM2 gangliosidosis that would confound scientific rigor or interpretation | Body weight < 10 kg | Another neurologic disease present | Moderate or severe hepatic impairment | Moderate or severe renal impairment | Platelet count < 100 x10^9/L | Anti-epileptic treatment dose not stable within previous 3 months or new anti-epileptic treatment within 1 month before Baseline | Prior investigational drug use within 3 months before Screening | Prior participation in a clinical study involving gene therapy or stem cell transplantation within 2 years prior to Screening | Positive serum pregnancy test (women of childbearing potential)
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial enrolls GM1/GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs/Sandhoff/GM2AB) while the patient has PMM2-CDG, which is not included.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; Moderate cerebellar dysfunction; ICARS score 35; Age 8 years; Female sex
patient_prior_therapies: (none)
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion. The trial enrolls GM1/GM2 gangliosidosis, while the patient has PMM2-CDG. Therefore F is correct regardless of other anchors.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: A Phase II, Open Label Study to Evaluate the Safety of Triheptanoin for the Prevention of Hypoglycemia in Patients With Medium Chain Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency (MCADD)
brief_summary: This is a medical research study to test a medication in patients 4 years of age and older with a disease called medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD). The medication is triheptanoin, which is currently FDA approved for the treatment of long chain fatty acid oxidation disorders (FAODs). Previous research suggests that triheptanoin may also be effective in the treatment MCADD. This study will investigate the safety and efficacy (how well it works) of triheptanoin patients with...
interventions: {'id': 206413892, 'name': 'Triheptanoin', 'description': 'Open-label design with doses of triheptanoin up to 1.0 gm/kg/day. The dose will be titrated from Day 1-24.', 'other_names': ['Dojolvi'], 'intervention_type': 'DRUG'}
inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of MCADD with molecular confirmation | Age >= 4 years | Negative pregnancy test for females of childbearing potential | Use of effective contraception during the study (females of childbearing age and sexually active males)
exclusion_criteria: Use of any investigational drug within 30 days before screening | Active infection (viral or bacterial) or other intercurrent illness at screening | Any clinically significant abnormality or condition increasing risk in the investigator's judgment | Known hypersensitivity to triheptanoin | Breastfeeding or lactating | Type 1 or type 2 diabetes | Use of medications that can cause hypoglycemia | Use of antimetabolite medications (e.g., hydroxyurea, 5-fluorouracil, methotrexate)
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets MCADD, while the patient has OTC deficiency. Additionally, the patient is 3 months old, below the trial’s minimum age of 4 years.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; Age 3 months; Male; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Stable on dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers
patient_prior_therapies: Dietary protein restriction; Ammonia scavengers
judge_comment: There is a hard exclusion due to disease mismatch (OTC vs MCADD). Additionally, the patient is below the trial’s minimum age (3 months vs ≥4 years). Either hard exclusion warrants grade F. The grader’s F and reasoning are correct.
